meanings.definition: too willing to believe that someone is telling the truth, that people's intentions in general are good, or that life is simple and fair. People are often naive because they are young and/or have not had much experience of life:
examples: She was very naive to believe that he'd stay with her.

It was a little naive of you to think that they would listen to your suggestions.

meanings.definition: too ready to believe someone or something, or to trust that someone’s intentions are good, esp. because of a lack of experience:
examples: It was naive of her to think that she would ever get her money back.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you are too willing to believe that someone is telling the truth or that life is pleasant or fair:

meanings.definition: trust based on not having much experience:

stark naked (= completely naked)
buck/butt naked (= completely naked)

meanings.definition: Something that is naked does not have its usual covering:

a naked hillside (= one without trees or plants)

meanings.definition: A naked feeling or quality is not hidden, although it is bad:

meanings.definition: not wearing any clothes

meanings.definition: a type of bond where a company borrows money without offering security

meanings.definition: the position in which the hands are together and pointing upwards at the centre of the chest, used in yoga (= physical and mental exercises originally from India):

meanings.definition: weak, silly, or emotional:

meanings.definition: the word or words that a person, thing, or place is known by:

meanings.definition: the opinion or reputation that someone or something has:
examples: She went to court to clear her name (= prove that the bad things said about her were not true).

meanings.definition: someone who is famous or has a good reputation:
examples: It seemed like all the big names in football were there.

meanings.definition: to give someone or something a name:

meanings.definition: to say what something or someone's name is:

meanings.definition: to choose someone or something:

meanings.definition: a word or words that a person or thing is known by:

meanings.definition: A name is also a reputation, esp. a good one:

meanings.definition: A name is also a famous person or thing:
examples: He’s a big name in the field of fashion.

meanings.definition: to give a name to someone or something:

meanings.definition: a well-known and successful company, person, or product:

meanings.definition: limited to a small area of interest, activity, or thought:
examples: They are unable to see beyond the narrow world of the theatre.

meanings.definition: A narrow result is one that could easily have been different because the amount by which someone failed or succeeded was very small:
examples: The election was won by the very narrow margin of only 185 votes.
The opposition had a narrow defeat.
We won a narrow victory.

meanings.definition: to become less wide or to make something less wide:
examples: The road narrows after the bridge.
He narrowed his eyes in suspicion.

meanings.definition: to become less:
examples: The retailer's loss narrowed to $3 million from $10 million a year earlier.

meanings.definition: having a small distance from one side to the other:
examples: Scenes from the movie were filmed in some of Rome’s ancient, narrow streets.

meanings.definition: Narrow also means slight, esp. as a measure of difference:
examples: He was defeated in the election by a narrow margin.

meanings.definition: Narrow also means only just successful:
examples: He had a narrow escape, getting out of the car just before it burst into flames.

meanings.definition: limited in range:

meanings.definition: to become or make something narrower or smaller:
examples: The road narrows from four lanes to two when you leave town.

meanings.definition: the state of not knowing
not having knowledge about something:
examples: a nescient interpretation of the facts

meanings.definition: added to adjectives to form nouns that refer to a quality or a condition:
examples: happiness
sadness
nervousness
selfishness
kindness

meanings.definition: a cold or frozen sweet dish made with cream, candied fruit (= fruit preserved in sugar), and chestnuts, or a mixture of these fruits and nuts used in such a dish:
examples: Nesselrode is a very Christmassy creamy jelly with chestnuts, brandy, and lots of dried fruit.
a Nesselrode pudding with chestnuts

meanings.definition: the imaginary creature that some people believe lives in Loch Ness in Scotland, also known as "the Loch Ness monster":
examples: The picture of Nessie, which shows a dark neck rising out of the lake, was later proved to be a fake.

meanings.definition: a structure built by birds or insects to leave their eggs in to develop, and by some other animals to give birth or live in:
examples: a bird's nest
a wasps'/hornets' nest
a rat's nest
Cuckoos are famous for laying their eggs in the nests of other birds.
The alligators build their nests out of grass near the water's edge.

meanings.definition: a comfortable home:
examples: One day the children grow up and leave the nest.

meanings.definition: a place where something unpleasant or unwanted has developed:
examples: The diplomats have been sent home because their embassy has become a nest of spies.

meanings.definition: a set of things that are similar but different in size and have been designed to fit inside each other:
examples: I'd like a nest of tables for the living room.

meanings.definition: to build a nest, or live in a nest:
examples: We've got some swallows nesting in our roof at the moment.
Farm buildings are ideal nesting sites for barn owls.

meanings.definition: to fit one object inside another, or to fit inside in this way:
examples: nested coffee tables
dolls that nest inside one another

meanings.definition: to put a piece of information, text, etc. inside another, or at a lower level in a system:
examples: Each document has a root element and all elements must be nested within other elements.
Text documents often comprise nested regions like lists within lists or procedures within procedures.

meanings.definition: a structure or other place where creatures, esp. birds, give birth or leave their eggs to develop
an amount of money that has been saved or kept for a special purpose:
examples: Regular investment of small amounts of money is an excellent way of building a nest egg.

meanings.definition: money saved or kept for a special purpose:
examples: I have a little nest egg that I'm saving for college.

meanings.definition: a sum of money that has been saved or kept for a special purpose:
examples: Regular investment of small amounts of money is an excellent way of building a nest egg.
a retirement nest egg

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         empty nester
the activity of building a nest, or of caring for eggs or baby birds or animals in a nest:
examples: The trees are attractive to birds for nesting.
Turtle nesting has declined by about 22%.
Scientists observe that frog breeding, bird nesting, and flowering are all happening earlier in the year.

meanings.definition: the activity of getting the home ready for a new baby:
examples: Nesting is a common instinct that many people experience during pregnancy.
I think nesting has begun - I just want to stay at home and fold baby clothes!

meanings.definition: (of birds and some animals) caring for eggs or baby birds or animals in a nest:
examples: Photographers should not approach nesting penguins too closely.
Nesting skylarks do not have the cover they need for a successful breeding season.

meanings.definition: for or relating to birds or animals that are caring for their eggs or baby birds or animals in a nest:
examples: The turtles have just entered their nesting season.
The beaches are nesting sites for terns.
Every spring, the geese cross the Himalayas to reach their nesting grounds.
The trees' hollow trunks provide nesting areas for some bird and bat species.
Data suggests that loggerhead turtles have altered their nesting cycles.

meanings.definition: relating to the activity of preparing the home for a new baby:
examples: She had no nesting instincts at all and had nothing prepared for the arrival of the baby.
Don't be upset if the nesting urge doesn't strike you at all.

meanings.definition: fitting inside each other:
examples: She brought back a set of Russian nesting dolls.
In the corner of the room was a set of three nesting tables.

meanings.definition: a box for birds to nest in
to rest yourself or part of your body in a warm, comfortable, and protected position:
examples: She nestled (her head) against his shoulder.

meanings.definition: to be in, or put something in, a protected position, with bigger things around it:
examples: Bregenz is a pretty Austrian town that nestles between the Alps and Lake Constance.

meanings.definition: to be in or put someone or something into a comfortable or protected position:
examples: She nestled the cat in her arms.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         nestle
to rest yourself or part of your body in a warm, comfortable, and protected position:
examples: She nestled (her head) against his shoulder.

meanings.definition: to be in, or put something in, a protected position, with bigger things around it:
examples: Bregenz is a pretty Austrian town that nestles between the Alps and Lake Constance.

meanings.definition: a young bird that has not yet learned to fly and still lives in the nest built by its parents

material made of threads of rope, string, wire, or plastic with spaces between them, allowing gas, liquid, or small objects to go through, or an object made with this material that is used to limit the movement of something:
examples: a fishing net
a butterfly net
Dolphins often get tangled in the nets that are used to catch tuna fish.
The living-room windows have net curtains that let in sunlight but stop passers-by looking in from the street.

meanings.definition: a rectangular piece of material made from string, used to separate the two sides in various sports:
examples: If the ball touches the net during a serve in a game of tennis, you have to serve again.

meanings.definition: the area surrounded by a piece of material made from string into which a ball or puck is put in order to score points in various sports:
examples: His penalty kick placed the ball decisively in the back of the net.
a basketball net

meanings.definition: to catch something using a net:
examples: How many fish did you net this afternoon?

meanings.definition: to get something good or to earn a lot of money from something:
examples: She netted herself a fortune when she sold her company.
Mark's netted himself a top job with an advertising company.
Prosecutors say the defendants netted millions from a variety of schemes.
She netted $10 million for herself from the sale of her company.

meanings.definition: If you net the ball during a game such as football, you score a goal:
examples: He secured a dramatic victory for England by netting the ball half a minute before the end of the game.

meanings.definition: left when there is nothing else to be taken away:
examples: I earn $50,000 gross, but my net income (= income that is left after tax has been paid) is about $36,000.
The net weight of something excludes the weight of the material that it is packed in.

meanings.definition: network: the part of an internet address that shows it belongs to a network or a business
a piece of material made of long, narrow strips woven so that there are spaces between them:
examples: fishing nets
a volleyball net

meanings.definition: (of money received from selling something) left after you have subtracted the cost of what you are selling, and other expenses related to it:
examples: net income/profit
fig. The net result (= result after everything has been considered) of the changes will be fewer trains for most suburban commuters.

meanings.definition: Net weight is the weight of something contained in a package, without including the weight of the package.
Net force is the total amount of force that is in effect on an object at a particular time.
to succeed in getting something of value, esp. as the result of a plan of action:
examples: The deal netted the online video company $23 million.

meanings.definition: (in sports) to hit the ball into a net instead of over it:
examples: He netted an easy backhand in the fifth game to lose the tennis match.

meanings.definition: To net is also to catch something in a net:
examples: They netted five crabs.

meanings.definition: to have left after you have subtracted the cost of what you are selling, and other expenses related to it:
examples: Smithsonian, on a gross of $28 million, netted $7 million with one magazine.

meanings.definition: short form ofInternet
Net is also used at the end of a US Internet address to show that the address belongs to a network:
examples: info@sover.net

meanings.definition: part of an internet address that shows that it belongs to a business, often a network that provides internet services:
examples: Their website address is www.homelove.net.

meanings.definition: the amount of profit that a business has left after tax has been paid:
examples: The company's fourth-quarter net edged higher to $22.4 million from $22 million.

meanings.definition: if something nets a person or a business an amount of money, it produces that amount for them after all costs have been paid:
examples: The sale of the three big oil enterprises could net the country $3 billion.

meanings.definition: to earn an amount of profit after tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: He had netted $1 million before he was 40.
The business was sold in 1998, netting him £174m.
People who decided to sell netted a huge profit.

meanings.definition: to obtain or achieve something good:
examples: His 200 applications netted only three callbacks.

meanings.definition: used to describe an amount of money that is left after tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: Sixty percent of any net gain or loss will be treated as long-term capital gain or loss.
She favored switching the system entirely from a tax on net company profits to one on the gross value of the oil.
The state will see a net increase of $743 million in income, sales, and other tax revenue.
net costs/debt/revenue

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation in which the value of goods sold or exported by one country is more than the value of the same type of goods sold or exported by the other:
examples: The UK became a net exporter of oil.

meanings.definition: used to describe what is left after everything important has been included or removed:
examples: The net result of all the changes in employment levels was a solid gain of 157,000 jobs last month.

meanings.definition: after tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: She earns a salary of $60,000 net.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         internet noun
written on an invoice to show that it must be paid within ten days
abbreviation for net 10 days end of month: written on an invoice to show it must be paid within ten days of the beginning of the following month
written on an invoice to show that it must be paid within 30 days
abbreviation for net 30 days end of month: written on an invoice to show that it must be paid within 30 days of the beginning of the following month
the amount that a property or a piece of land could earn in rent over a year:
examples: We will need a full description of the land and the net annual value for rating.

meanings.definition: a measure of the value of shareholders’ investment in a company, calculated by subtracting its total debt from its total assets and dividing the result by the number of shares that exist
the total value of the assets of a company after its total debt has been subtracted:
examples: A Fund's net asset value will tend to rise when interest rates fall.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         net asset value per share
the value of a share in a company, calculated by subtracting a company’s total debt from its total assets and dividing the result by the number of shares that exist:
examples: In the past 10 years its net asset value per share has almost doubled.

meanings.definition: the total value of a person's or company's assets after their total debt has been subtracted:
examples: Each Fund may invest up to 20% of its net assets in high yield, high risk fixed-income securities.

meanings.definition: the value of an asset calculated by subtracting depreciation (= reduction in its value) from its cost:
examples: The company said the net book value of assets at the date of completion is approximately €800m.

meanings.definition: the value of a company, calculated by subtracting depreciation (= reduction in its value) from the difference between the value of its total assets and total debt:
examples: The company has an estimated net book value of about 88 million.

meanings.definition: the difference between the amount that a company has borrowed and the amount of cash that it has:
examples: Today, the group has net borrowings estimated at as much as £250m.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         internet commerce
a company's assets after its current liabilities (= debts that must be paid within 12 months) have been subtracted from its current assets (= assets that will be used or sold within 12 months):
examples: Shareholder funds and net current assets were in the negative at the end of 2009.

meanings.definition: a company's debts after its current assets (= assets that will be used or sold within 12 months) have been subtracted from its current liabilities (= debts that must be paid within 12 months) :
examples: The figures in the consolidated balance sheet show net current liabilities to have risen to almost £12.5m.

meanings.definition: a curtain made of net, that allows light to enter but stops people seeing into your house from outside:
examples: Kim stared through the net curtain into the grey sky.
There were net curtains as well as heavy red drapes.

meanings.definition: the amount by which the number of emigrants (= people leaving a country to live in another) is greater than the number of immigrants (= people arriving):
examples: The country has high levels of net emigration, as more people leave when times are toughest economically.

meanings.definition: a country that exports more of a particular product that it imports:
examples: Indonesia is a big net exporter of oil.

meanings.definition: the amount by which the number of immigrants (= people arriving to live in a country) is greater than the number of emigrants (= people leaving):
examples: The number leaving the UK fell, leaving a net immigration of 178,000 - another modern record.

meanings.definition: a country that imports more of a particular product that it exports:
examples: China, with 1.3 billion people, will remain a net importer of corn, and help lead the export boom.

meanings.definition: a person's income after all tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: Next year, her net income will increase to almost £19,000, thanks to the increases in tax credits.

meanings.definition: the total income of a company after all tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: These projects have increased the company's net income by more than $20 million.

meanings.definition: the rate of interest earned by a bank account or an investment after tax has been paid:
examples: A saver now gets 3.22% net interest on £2,500 in one of our accounts.

meanings.definition: the difference between the interest received by a person or an organization from investments and the interest they pay for money they have borrowed:
examples: The bank's net profit rose 4.2% in the six months ended June thanks to higher net interest income and lower costs.

meanings.definition: the difference between the interest that a bank pays to people with money in the bank and the interest received from people borrowing money:
examples: The bank's net interest margin, a key measure of loan profitability, rose to 4.61% from 4.52%.

meanings.definition: the amount of money that a company spends on buildings, equipment, etc. after subtracting depreciation (= reduction in value over a period of time):
examples: Latest figures show that net investment is now a quarter of its level of 10 years ago.

meanings.definition: the amount of money lent by a bank over a particular period after the amount that has been paid back during the same period has been subtracted:
examples: Total net lending this year was up 48% to £9.1bn.

meanings.definition: the amount by which a company’s total costs are more than its total sales during a particular period:
examples: The company posted a net loss of $43.2m for 2009, compared with a profit of $1.1m the year before.

meanings.definition: the amount by which money from sales is more than all related costs:
examples: The average net margin for a pharmacy is now 2%.

meanings.definition: the principle that the companies that provide services on the internet should make all information equally available to users, and not make any particular service, website, etc. cheaper or faster to use than any other:
examples: Net neutrality is the idea that Internet providers must treat all content equally. It's opposed by cable and telecom companies that want to offer different tiers of service.

meanings.definition: a company's profit after the costs involved in its daily business are subtracted, but before tax and interest on borrowing are subtracted:
examples: The organization finished its fiscal year with about $20 million in net operating income.

meanings.definition: to be or produce a particular amount of money after tax and other costs have been paid:
examples: The facility showed a gross loss of $2.8m, which, when set against investors' deposits of £1.5m, netted out at $1.36m.

meanings.definition: to be or have a particular amount at the end of a process:
examples: We will net out with several hundred additional jobs over two years.

meanings.definition: to subtract a cost, etc. from an amount of money:
examples: The company has suffered pressure from higher raw material costs and changes in a number of its markets. When these are netted out, earnings will stabilise.

meanings.definition: the difference between the cost of producing goods and the price they are sold for:
examples: Net output in the Scottish economy grew by only 0.4% compared to growth of 2.6% in the UK.

meanings.definition: a P/E ratio (= company's share price in relation to its profits) that is calculated based on the amount of profit that it distributes to shareholders
the present value of an investment's future net cash flow (= difference between the money coming in and going out) after the cost of the original investment has been subtracted:
examples: Countries that have received help so far have seen the net present value of their debt burden fall by an average of 40%.

meanings.definition: the final price paid for goods or services after subtracting tax and any other costs:
examples: Their operating assets were sold for an estimated net price of $80 million, subject to accounting adjustments.

meanings.definition: the profit from selling goods or services after all costs have been paid:
examples: The net proceeds from the sale of the flat should be invested offshore.

meanings.definition: the money received from making shares, bonds, etc. available for sale, after all costs have been paid:
examples: They expect to raise $56.8 million in net proceeds from an offering of 8.6 million shares.

meanings.definition: the money made by a company or part of a company for a particular period after all costs, taxes, etc. have been paid:
examples: Annual net profit fell 20% in the wake of tough competition.
The company posted a net profit of $160m for the first quarter.

meanings.definition: the money made from selling something after all costs, taxes, etc. have been paid:
examples: The ticket agent's profit is calculated as the sum of the net profit from selling tickets and the bonus.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         net margin
a measure of whether a company has enough assets that could easily be changed into cash to pay its debts if sales were to suddenly slow down or stop
the value of an asset if it were sold, after all the costs of selling it have been paid:
examples: The company said it wrote the film's cost down to its net realizable value.

meanings.definition: the profits from particular sales after all costs and taxes have been paid:
examples: The publisher shall be entitled to deduct from its net receipts any direct or first costs.

meanings.definition: a measure in tons of the size of the inside of a ship for carrying goods, which does not include the space used for fuel, engines, etc.
the amount received by the owner of property from rent, after tax, insurance, etc. have been paid:
examples: The building generates $398,308 total net rent annually, from four tenants.

meanings.definition: the situation that exists at the end of a series of events:
examples: The net result of the changes will be increased fares and reduced services.

meanings.definition: the amount of money received from an investment or a company's activities after all costs have been paid:
examples: The average net return is 6.5% investment return minus a 0.5% charge for fees.

meanings.definition: the amount of money received from selling goods or services after all costs have been paid:
examples: The company earned €45,000 in net revenue from the sale.

meanings.definition: a person's salary after taxes, insurance, etc. have been subtracted:
examples: The company provided permanent health insurance that would pay 80% of a person's net salary after six months of sickness.

meanings.definition: the total value of a company's sales after amounts for costs such as returned, damaged, or missing goods, and any price reductions, taxes, etc. have been subtracted:
examples: The company believes that its net sales for the next several quarters will be below prior year period levels.

meanings.definition: to reduce an amount by subtracting tax and other costs:
examples: In most cases, the interest rate paid will be the tax-free rate netted down.

meanings.definition: someone who regularly uses the internet:
examples: A net surfer should always save their favourite internet sites.

meanings.definition: the value of a company's physical assets (= buildings, land, or money), after debts relating to them are taken away:
examples: The shares currently trade at around the value of the company's net tangible assets.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         short ton
the amount of space inside a ship for carrying goods
the weight of a product without its container or package:
examples: Net weight refers only to the weight of the goods in question.

meanings.definition: the ​value of the ​assets (= property and money)​ that a ​person or ​business has, after any ​debts are taken away:
examples: He has a ​net ​worth of about £70 million.
The firm specializes in advising high net worth individuals.

meanings.definition: the value of the assets and money that a person or business has, after their debts are taken away:
examples: He is one of Britain's richest people, with a net worth of about £70 million.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for 
        
         net weight
the profit from an investment after taxes or charges have been taken away:
examples: The fund has a current net yield of 3.85%.

meanings.definition: (of a country, city, etc.) removing as many emissions (= gases that cause the earth to warm up) as it produces:
examples: There are five ways to make the UK net zero.
The main goal was to be a carbon-neutral or net-zero city.

meanings.definition: (of a building or set of buildings) designed to produce as much energy as it uses :
examples: The net zero house has panels on the roof to convert sunlight to electricity.
There are plans to make the warehouse a net zero building.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a situation in which there is a balance between the number of people arriving and leaving, of jobs created and lost, etc.:
examples: Even with net zero immigration and the current birthrate, our population would continue to grow for many years.
He predicts a net-zero to negative growth in new jobs.

meanings.definition: the point at which a country, industry, company, etc. removes as many emissions (= gases that cause the earth to warm up) as it produces:
examples: We have definitely taken the important first steps to reducing our carbon emissions to net zero.
The government pledged to arrive at net-zero by 2021.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is a balance between the number of people arriving and leaving, of jobs created and lost, etc.:
examples: He suggested that immigration should be reduced to at least net zero.
We'll have some move costs, but overall it will come pretty close to net-zero.

meanings.definition: using or involving the internet:
examples: Services that provide free net-based phone calls are increasingly popular.
net-based companies/merchants/retailers

meanings.definition: depending on the internet, for example, to sell products, manage services, or get information:
examples: Security within a net-centric environment has its own challenges for the business user.

meanings.definition: a sport played by two teams of seven players, usually women or girls, in which goals are scored by throwing a ball through a net hanging from a ring at the top of a pole
a small laptop computer designed mainly for using the internet
an abbreviation that consists of the first letters of each word in a phrase and is used when discussing a subject in a chat room or when writing an email:
examples: Netcronyms are a quick way of telling people what you think.
IMO is a netcronym for "in my opinion".

meanings.definition: someone who is very interested in the internet
in a lower position:
examples: The boiler room is somewhere down in the building's nether regions.

meanings.definition: a place, situation, or part of society that is hidden and often unpleasant:
examples: The film shows us a netherworld of drugs and crime.

meanings.definition: the set of rules about behaviour that is acceptable on the internet:
examples: It's considered bad netiquette to use capital letters in an email because it looks like YOU ARE SHOUTING.

meanings.definition: the set of rules about behaviour that is acceptable when communicating with people over the internet:
examples: It is extremely bad netiquette to leave a chat room without saying goodbye.

meanings.definition: a person who uses the internet
especially in ice hockey, the player who stands in the team's goal to try to stop the other team from scoring:
examples: They replaced the netminder with an extra skater.
Their first-choice net-minder will be pressed back into action, despite a knee injury.

meanings.definition: the words, abbreviations, etc. that people use when communicating on the internet

material in the form of a net:
examples: Safety netting was put up around the playing field.
The goal netting was frayed and ripped in places.

meanings.definition: a wild plant with heart-shaped leaves that are covered in hairs that sting (= cause a painful reaction when touched):
examples: stinging nettles
nettle soup/tea

meanings.definition: to make someone annoyed or slightly angry:
examples: She looked up at me sharply, clearly nettled by the interruption.

         nettle
to make someone annoyed or slightly angry:
examples: She looked up at me sharply, clearly nettled by the interruption.

meanings.definition: a condition that causes slightly raised red or white spots to appear on the skin
annoying, and causing problems or difficulties:
examples: He attempted to tackle the nettlesome issue of police and community relations.

to make someone annoyed or slightly angry:

meanings.definition: a large system consisting of many similar parts that are connected together to allow movement or communication between or along the parts, or between the parts and a control centre:
examples: a television network
a road/rail network
Massive investment is needed to modernize the country's phone network.
We could reduce our costs by developing a more efficient distribution network.
a network of spies/a spy network

meanings.definition: a number of computers that are connected together so that they can share information:
examples: We've just spent £1.9 million on improving our computer network.

meanings.definition: people that you know, considered as a group whose members exchange information with each other:
examples: Use your networks - tell everyone you know that you are looking for a job.
I hope that you will participate and share this message with your networks.

meanings.definition: to connect computers together so that they can share information:
examples: Our computer system consists of about 20 personal computers networked to a powerful file-server.

meanings.definition: to meet people who might be useful to know, especially in your job:
examples: I don't really enjoy these conferences, but they're a good opportunity to network.

meanings.definition: a group formed from parts that are connected together:
examples: a transportation network

meanings.definition: A network is also a company that provides programs to a group of television or radio stations, or this company and the group considered together:
examples: the ABC television network

meanings.definition: A network is also a group of computers that are connected and can share information.
A network is also a group of people with the same interests:
examples: a network of political advisers

meanings.definition: to make an effort to meet and talk to a lot of people, esp. in order to get information that can help you
a system of computers connected together so that they can share information:
examples: A domain name identifies a computer or computer network used to access the web.

meanings.definition: a group of people or organizations in different places who work together and share information:
examples: He also has a network of contacts who give him help when he needs it.
a network of agents/dealers/suppliers

meanings.definition: a large system consisting of many similar parts that are connected together:
examples: The bank is planning to expand its network of cash machines.
a television/road/rail network
a telephone/distribution/communications network

meanings.definition: a group of television or radio companies that connect together to broadcast programmes in different places at the same time, or a company that produces these programmes:
examples: He owns American television network ABC.

meanings.definition: to connect computers together, or to connect a piece of electronic equipment to a computer, so that they can share information:
examples: The office computers have all been networked.
You can have your TV networked to your home computer.

meanings.definition: to meet people who might be useful to know, especially in your job:
examples: They network through friends, former co-workers, and professional organizations.
Conferences offer the opportunity to network with other professionals in your field of business.

meanings.definition: the process of deciding in what order tasks need to be done in a particular project, so that it can be finished successfully in the least amount of time:
examples: Arranging the individual jobs is one of the four stages of work involved in network analysis.

meanings.definition: the process of measuring movements of information in various parts of a computer network:
examples: Maybe some sort of network analysis is being done of the kind of ad links you click on.

meanings.definition: a small piece of electronic equipment that you put in computer to connect it to a computer network

a system for selling a product in which someone agrees to buy an amount of it at a wholesale price (= a lower price paid by a business), and then tries to make money by selling the product at a higher price to other people, or getting other people to sell it for them:
examples: They changed the marketing plan, got rid of all the sales people and moved into network marketing.
She is successfully self-employed in a network marketing business.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         multilevel marketing
networked computers are connected together so that they can share information:
examples: Each site will have a minimum of 12 networked computers, a networked printer, and internet access.

meanings.definition: someone who tries to meet people who might be useful to know, especially in their job:
examples: He is a great networker who looks after his colleagues' interests.

meanings.definition: the activity of meeting people who might be useful to know, especially in your job:
examples: Students find networking essential to getting the right job.
Her networking skills were legendary in the business.

meanings.definition: the process of connecting computers together so that they can share information:
examples: The joint project is not simply about computer networking.
Wireless networking is becoming more popular in homes and small offices.

meanings.definition: the process of meeting and talking to a lot of people, esp. in order to get information that can help you:
examples: Students find networking essential to finding the right job.

meanings.definition: the activity of trying to meet people who might be useful to know, especially in your job:
examples: It was a good opportunity to do some networking.
The annual Country Radio Seminar is a large networking event in Nashville.

meanings.definition: the process of connecting two or more computers together so that they can share information:
examples: The website gives information about home networking and setting up a wireless home network.

meanings.definition: a soft cow's milk cheese, originally made in northern France, often in a heart shape:
examples: Neufchâtel is a white, creamy, delicate, and often heart-shaped cheese.
I always visit his shop for the fantastic cheeses, including neufchatel and camembert, which are both local specialities.

meanings.definition: a soft cow's milk cheese made in the US, similar to cream cheese but softer :
examples: Try using low-fat cream cheese, or buy Neufchatel instead of standard cream cheese.
I combined blue cheese and neufchatel cream cheese for the stuffing.

meanings.definition: involving a nerve or the system of nerves that includes the brain:
examples: Some people suffered severe neural damage as a result of the disease.

meanings.definition: a curved structure made of bone or cartilage on the back part of a vertebra (= one of the small bones in the spine) that forms a passage for the spinal cord (= set of nerves in the spine) to pass through:
examples: They complete the neural arch by fusing together, and enclose the vertebral canal, which serves for the protection of the spinal cord.
The vertebral or neural arch is formed by the two pedicles, two laminae, and spinous process.

meanings.definition: a line of cells along the length of the neural tube (= a structure in embryos that develops into the brain and spinal cord in humans and some animals) that develops into different parts of the nervous system:
examples: During the formation of the neural tube, cells called neural crest cells detach to form the peripheral nervous system.
Both neurons and glia of the peripheral nervous system are derived from the neural crest.

meanings.definition: a mathematical representation of text or other types of media that is designed to operate in a similar way to a group of connected nerve cells in an organism:
examples: Neural networks can learn solutions to difficult problems.
The researchers used a huge annotated database to train the neural net.

meanings.definition: a structure in the embryos (= babies before they are born) of humans and some animals that develops into the brain and spinal cord:
examples: There's been a 25 percent drop in neural tube defects (= conditions caused by the neural tube not developing correctly).
This is the neural tube, from which the entire nervous system develops.

meanings.definition: short, severe pains felt suddenly along a nerve, especially in the neck or head
involving short, severe pains felt suddenly along a nerve, especially in the neck or head:
examples: She takes painkillers for the terrible neuralgic pains in her face.
He had severe neuralgic pain when resting.

meanings.definition: causing or feeling very strong, painful emotions:
examples: Political allegiance is a neuralgic subject in this community.
Their populations have become increasingly neuralgic about immigration.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves or relates to a nerve or the system of nerves that includes the brain:
examples: Gut inflammation causes significant changes in neurally controlled gut functions.
Neurally mediated hypotension refers to patients who get lightheaded when standing due to a defect in their nervous system's regulation of blood pressure.

meanings.definition: the thin outer covering of a nerve fibre:
examples: Outside a nerve we find a covering, the neurilemma.
The neurolemma, or primitive sheath, has the appearance of a delicate membrane.

meanings.definition: relating to or consisting of neurilemma (= the thin outer covering of a nerve fibre):
examples: Multiple fibromatous tumours develop from the neurilemmal sheaths of peripheral and cranial nerves.
A dissection of the median nerve samples was conducted to evaluate variations in the area of myelin covering and in the area of neurolemmal sheath.

meanings.definition: relating to nerves and the nervous system, or their study:
examples: neuroscience
A neurotransmitter is a chemical that nerve cells use to communicate with each other and with muscles.
We grow neural connections in the brain.
He became professor of neuro-pathology.
They investigated treatments such as neuro-stimulation for migraines.
A month after the accident, I was moved to a neuro-rehabilitation unit.

meanings.definition: a set of methods for improving communication and relationships, based on the idea that there is a connection between our thoughts, language, and behaviour:
examples: She uses a variety of techniques including psychotherapy and neuro-linguistic programming to treat her clients.
He runs a session for students who are nervous of exams, using neurolinguistic programming.

meanings.definition: relating to the scientific study of the nervous system and how its parts are arranged, including the brain:
examples: Neuroanatomical studies have demonstrated neural connections between these two areas of the brain.
This proposed model is in accordance with neuroanatomical findings.

meanings.definition: relating to the structure of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: Dementia corresponds to a fixed or progressive neuroanatomical abnormality.
They showed evidence of significant neuroanatomical changes in the visual cortex.

meanings.definition: a scientist who studies the structure of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: Broca's Aphasia was first classified by French neuroanatomist and anthropologist Paul Broca in 1861.
Traditionally, neuroanatomists had delineated brain regions pretty much by eye.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the nervous system and how its parts are arranged, including the brain :
examples: They offer courses in anatomy, including gross anatomy, embryology, histology, and neuroanatomy.
His particular area of interest is in neuroanatomy, an increasingly significant area of research in terms of artificial intelligence.

meanings.definition: the structure of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: Knowledge of the neuroanatomy of the pelvis is necessary for the pelvic surgeon to avoid nerve injury.
This conception arose from a misunderstanding of basic neuroanatomy.

meanings.definition: relating to the scientific study of the nervous system, its structure, how it works, and its biochemistry:
examples: It has become evident, especially from recent neurobiological studies, that plasticity is an inherent property of the developing brain.
Neurochemical and neurobiological research has led to advances in understanding the causes of dementia.

meanings.definition: relating to the nervous system, its structure, how it works, its biochemistry, and how it affects people's health:
examples: These neurobiological systems significantly influence physical and cognitive development.
There is increasing interest in the neurobiological mechanisms of emotion regulation in children with behaviour problems.

meanings.definition: a scientist who studies the nervous system, its structure, how it works, and its biochemistry:
examples: She is a neurobiologist at Harvard University.
We hope this technology can help neurobiologists understand how the human brain works.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the nervous system, including the brain, its structure, how it works, and its biochemistry:
examples: She is a fourth year student currently pursuing a doctorate in neurobiology at the University of Liverpool.
The rapid pace of neurobiology research has increased the prospects of developing drugs to prevent neurodegenerative disorders.

meanings.definition: the structure of the nervous system, including the brain, how it works, its biochemistry, and how it affects people's health:
examples: There have been numerous advances in the understanding of the neurobiology of Alzheimer's disease in the past 15 years.
Studies suggest that genetics, neurobiology, and social environment are all important contributing factors to the condition.

meanings.definition: relating to the chemistry of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: She may also be experiencing hormonal or other neurochemical changes.
These specific neurochemical mechanisms have not been clearly documented with scientific studies.

meanings.definition: Neurochemical drugs or other substances affect the nervous system:
examples: Using an ever-expanding range of neurochemical drugs, physicians now treat variants of mood and temperament.
Light affects the body's biological rhythms through hormonal and neurochemical messenger substances released by the pineal gland.

meanings.definition: a drug or a chemical substance in the body that affects the nervous system:
examples: The neurochemical is released when something surprising or important happens.
Those are the three neurochemicals most implicated in depressive disorders.

meanings.definition: a scientist who studies the chemistry of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: He is a research psychiatrist and neurochemist at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.
There is a lot of interesting work done by neurobiologists and neurochemists on the cognition of this group of offenders.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the chemistry of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: He obtained a PhD in pharmacology and neurochemistry from the University of Bristol.
The findings appear in the Journal of Neurochemistry.

meanings.definition: the chemistry of the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: They explored whether environmental lead exposure alters brain neurochemistry, structure, and function.
We are learning a lot about the neurochemistry of emotions.

meanings.definition: involving the nerves gradually stopping working:
examples: neurodegenerative disease

meanings.definition: having or related to a type of brain that is often considered as different from what is usual, for example that of someone who has autism:
examples: The report claimed that around 20% of high school students in America are neurodivergent.
There are many different types of developmental neurodivergent conditions.

meanings.definition: relating to neurodiversity (= the idea that people having a range of different types of brain, including those with and without autism, should be regarded as part of normal human life):
examples: ADHD, Autism, and Dyslexia are all examples of neurodiverse conditions.
Sadly, many people grow up thinking their neurodiverse symptoms are character flaws.

meanings.definition: (of a group of people) including people with a range of different types of brain, for example, those with and without autism:
examples: The whole of society is neurodiverse.
I am the mother of an autistic child, and the wife of a neurotypical partner. We are a neurodiverse family.

meanings.definition: (of a person) having a type of brain that is often considered to be different from what is usual, for example that of someone who has autism. This use is sometimes considered to be incorrect because only groups of people can be "diverse":
examples: I have learnt a lot from my neurodiverse son.
We help families with a neurodiverse child access support.

meanings.definition: the idea that people having a range of different types of brain, including those with and without autism, should be regarded as part of normal human life:
examples: Neurodiversity challenges the view that certain neurological conditions are inherently pathological.
Those in the neurodiversity movement say talk of a cure is insulting because it suggests autistic people need to be "fixed".

meanings.definition: relating to the release of hormones into the bloodstream after being stimulated by a nerve:
examples: a neuroendocrine cell
a neuroendocrine tumour

meanings.definition: relating to the way in which hormones (= chemical substances in the body) and the glands that produce them work together with the nervous system, or to the study of this:
examples: The link between early childhood adversity and alterations in neurobiological and neuroendocrinological processes has been well established.
This evidence opens new perspectives in the study of neuroendocrinological changes in postmenopausal women.

meanings.definition: a scientist who studies the way in which hormones (= chemical substances in the body) and the glands that produce them work together with the nervous system:
examples: She is a professor of biology and a behavioural neuroendocrinologist.
The American neuroendocrinologist argues that the relationship between stress, anxiety, and depression can be measured and demonstrated biologically.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of how hormones (= chemical substances in the body) and the glands that produce them work together with the nervous system:
examples: She completed her training in internal medicine and neuroendocrinology at Guy's Hospital in London.
This represents an exciting research theme in human reproductive biology and neuroendocrinology.

meanings.definition: the way in which hormones (= chemical substances in the body) and the glands that produce them work together with the nervous system:
examples: These findings challenge prevailing concepts on the neuroendocrinology of stress.
Puberty is marked by dramatic changes in neuroendocrinology.

meanings.definition: a thread-like structure that is part of a nerve cell:
examples: Each nerve cell has delicate neurofibrils running through its substance.
A nerve is made up of neurofibrils that provide structural support.

meanings.definition: relating to neurofibrils (= thread-like structures that form part of a nerve cell):
examples: Both conditions are associated with shrinking of the brain and the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.
This significantly increases the risk of more frequent and accelerated development of neurofibrillary pathology.

meanings.definition: a process in which new neurons (= nerve cells that carry information between the brain and other parts of the body) are formed in the brain:
examples: It is one of the few brain regions where neurogenesis occurs.
The growth of new brain cells – a process called neurogenesis – is involved in new memory formation.

meanings.definition: relating to or caused by the nervous system or a problem with the nervous system:
examples: Neurogenic disorders may alter the colon's ability to perform this function.
Back pain and neurogenic symptoms are particularly disabling.

meanings.definition: forming or within nerve tissue:
examples: Capsaicin causes neurogenic inflammation and has analgesic and anti-inflammatory activities.
Radiation may cause new neurogenic tumours and soft-tissue fibrosis.

meanings.definition: A neurogenic body process is one that is controlled by the nervous system:
examples: This release may be mediated by neurogenic reflexes.
This supports and regulates neurogenic activity.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to, is caused by, or is controlled by the nervous system:
examples: The protein may also be involved in neurogenically mediated changes at both central and peripheral nervous system sites.
With fibromyalgia, there is evidence of neurogenically derived inflammatory mechanisms occurring in the peripheral tissues, spinal cord, and brain.

meanings.definition: one of the cells that surround and support nerve tissue in the brain, spinal cord, and ganglia:
examples: Virtually all neurons and neuroglia are already formed at birth.
Myelin is a multi-layered lipid and protein covering, produced by neuroglia.

meanings.definition: relating to neuroglia (= cells that surround and support nerve tissue in the brain, spinal cord, and ganglia):
examples: These develop into the neuroglial cells of the ganglia.
The axons are wrapped around by specialized neuroglial cells that form a thick myelin sheath in places.

meanings.definition: relating to or controlled by a neurohormone (= a chemical substance in the body produced by or affecting nerve tissue):
examples: Neurohormonal levels were estimated from blood samples.
Neurohormonal activation is one of the major responses to heart failure.

meanings.definition: relating to or controlled by both hormones (= chemical substances in the body) and the nervous system:
examples: There has been a rapid increase in information about the effects of stress on neurohormonal mechanisms.
We compared clinical findings, echocardiography results, and neurohormonal factors between these two groups.

meanings.definition: a hormone (= a chemical substance in the body) that is produced by specialized nerve tissue:
examples: Emotionally arousing events mobilize neurohormones.
The role of neurohormones in diabetes-associated heart failure is not fully understood.

meanings.definition: relating to or produced by the neurohypophysis (= part of the pituitary gland):
examples: Neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is a disorder of water balance.
The hypothalamic neurohypophyseal system plays an essential role in the control of hydromineral balance.

meanings.definition: the part of the pituitary gland (= a small organ at the base of the brain) that consists of nerve tissue and that produces hormones (= chemical substances in the body), including oxytocin and vasopressin:
examples: Oxytocin is a hormone present in the rear part of the pituitary gland, the neurohypophysis, of many vertebrates.
Early studies suggested this stimulated the release of vasopressin from the neurohypophysis.

meanings.definition: the study of the relationship between language and the brain
relating to neurology (= the study of the nervous system):
examples: a neurologic examination
neurologic symptoms

meanings.definition: relating to nerves:
examples: neurological disease/damage
Alzheimer's disease is a neurological disorder.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the nerves or brain:
examples: The centre is designed to meet the needs of severely neurologically impaired patients and their families.
Neurologically, there are four standard classifications of memory.

meanings.definition: a doctor who studies and treats diseases of the nerves
the study of the structure and diseases of the brain and all the nerves in the body
the study of the structure and diseases of the brain and the nervous system
the study of how people's brains react to advertising:
examples: In the emerging field of neuromarketing, researchers study the human brain's decision-making processes.

meanings.definition: relating to the nerves that control muscles:
examples: a neuromuscular disorder

meanings.definition: a cell that carries information between the brain and other parts of the body:
examples: Research has shown that aerobic exercise remodels the brain, prompting the growth of new neurons.
Both of these act to decrease the excitability of the neurones.

meanings.definition: (in animals and people) a type of cell that sends and receives messages within the brain and the nerves of the body
relating to neurons (= nerve cells):
examples: The drugs increase neuronal activity as a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.
A computer recorded the pattern of neuronal firing during the subject's sleep.

meanings.definition:
UK for 
        
         neuron
relating to diseases of the nervous system:
examples: neuropathic pain

meanings.definition: damage to or disease affecting the nerves:
examples: Patients may have optic neuropathy.

meanings.definition: relating to the way in which the nervous system, including the brain, works:
examples: Cortisol is the major stress steroid in humans that modulates several neurophysiological processes.
Neurophysiological studies have shown that REM sleep is an essential part of brain function.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to how the nervous system, including the brain, works:
examples: He continues to develop a neurophysiologically based understanding of imagery processes.
It should be possible to infer the dimensions of the information encoded neurophysiologically in the brain.

meanings.definition: a scientist or doctor who studies the way in which the nervous system, including the brain, works:
examples: Neurophysiologists use a variety of methods to explore aspects of nervous function.
Using images of such quality, neurophysiologists are able to determine regions of human brain activation during different controlled arm movements.

meanings.definition: the way in which the nervous system, including the brain, works:
examples: Our knowledge of the neurophysiology of sleep is highly advanced.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the way in which the nervous system, including the brain, works:
examples: Since the development of neurophysiology, there has been a search for localization of function within the brain.

meanings.definition: the ability of the brain to form new connections and reorganize itself as a reaction to new experiences or information:
examples: The capacity of the central nervous system to recover function is technically called neuroplasticity.
Adolescence is a period of increased neural plasticity.

meanings.definition: relating to the relationship between mental illness and the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: This may weaken the brain's response to environmental stress, elevating the risk of developing neuropsychiatric disorders.
Medications for Parkinson's disease are associated with a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including depression, apathy, and anxiety.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves the relationship between mental illness and the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: Strokes in this region of the brain often manifest neuropsychiatrically as depression and anxiety.
They investigated the provision of individualized, evidence-based treatment for neuropsychiatrically complex patients.

meanings.definition: a doctor who is trained in neuropsychiatry (= the part of medicine that studies the relationship between mental illness and the nervous system):
examples: He is a consultant neuropsychiatrist at the Institute of Psychiatry in London.
The two neuropsychiatrists appointed by the court concluded that he was competent to stand trial.

meanings.definition: the part of medicine that studies the relationship between mental illness and the nervous system, including the brain:
examples: She is a consultant psychiatrist specializing in neuropsychiatry.
Experts in neuropsychiatry have proposed a specific category for this disorder.

meanings.definition: relating to the way the nervous system, especially the brain, affects behaviour:
examples: More specific neuropsychological deficits underlying such symptoms have not been established.
A neuropsychological examination did not reveal any evidence of significant neurological trauma to the patient's brain.

meanings.definition: a doctor who studies the way in which the nervous system, especially the brain, affects behaviour:
examples: Many patients with concussions aren't seen by a neuropsychologist for several weeks after a head injury.
As a clinical neuropsychologist, I have seen hundreds of families coping with a brain injury.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the way the nervous system, especially the brain, affects behaviour:
examples: For over a century, researchers in neuropsychology have studied the effects of localized brain damage on cognitive functions.
Both assessments were conducted by an experienced specialist in clinical neuropsychology.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the nervous system and the brain:
examples: Thanks to advances in neuroscience, we now know that adult brains can grow and change.

meanings.definition: relating to the scientific study of the nervous system and the brain:
examples: Modern neuroscientific research has centred on the way the brain physically changes in response to external stimuli.
We start from neuroscientific findings about the involvement of brain structures in decision-making.

meanings.definition: a scientist who studies the nervous system and the brain:
examples: Neuroscientists are able to record the firing of a single nerve cell.

meanings.definition: relating to the way in which the nervous system is involved with the physical senses of touch, smell, taste, hearing, and sight:
examples: These individuals are at increased risk for a wide range of neurosensory impairments.
Severe neurosensory symptoms were noted in 13% of patients.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         neurosis
a mental illness resulting in high levels of anxiety, unreasonable fears and behaviour and, often, a need to repeat actions for no reason:
examples: If you want my opinion, I think she's suffering from some form of neurosis.
She's obsessively clean - it's almost become a neurosis with her.

meanings.definition: a mental condition resulting in unreasonable anxiety and unusual behavior
a doctor who performs operations involving the brain or nerves
operations on any part of the nervous system including the brain, spinal cord, and individual nerves
relating to operations on the nervous system
behaving strangely or in an anxious (= worried and nervous) way, often because you have a mental illness:
examples: neurotic behaviour/tendencies
She's neurotic about her weight - she weighs herself three times a day.

meanings.definition: someone who behaves strangely, often because they have a mental illness
related to or having unreasonable anxiety or unusual behavior:
examples: a deep-seated neurotic fear of flying

meanings.definition: a neurotic person
strangely or in a worried and nervous way, often because you have a mental illness:
examples: He became neurotically jealous of her work life.
She kept looking neurotically over her shoulder.

meanings.definition: the condition of often feeling worried and nervous, often because of a mental illness:
examples: Researchers found that high levels of neuroticism were linked to lower life expectancy.

meanings.definition: a susbstance that is poisonous to nerve tissue:
examples: Mercury is a neurotoxin that can cause nerve and brain damage in small children.
Several tick species have a neurotoxin in their saliva, which can cause paralysis in those who are bitten.

meanings.definition: a chemical that carries messages between neurons or between neurons and muscles
a chemical substance that carries messages from one nerve cell to another in the body
not having, or not associated with, a brain condition, especially autism, that is often considered as different from what is usual:
examples: It is wrong to suggest there could be confusion between a neurotypical child with bad behaviour and a child with autism.
She is better-read than the vast majority of neurotypical people.

meanings.definition: the state of not having, or not being associated with, a brain condition, especially autism, that is often considered as different from what is usual:
examples: How do people on the autism spectrum feel about the idea of neurotypicality?
Many systems are designed around expectations of neurotypicality.

meanings.definition: relating to the nerves and blood vessels:
examples: If the problem is severe enough, the neurovascular bundle of nerves to the arm can become compressed.

meanings.definition: relating to a particular gender (= class of nouns) in some languages:
examples: In German, most nouns related to chemistry are neuter.

meanings.definition: to remove part of an animal's sexual organs, so that it cannot produce young animals:
examples: Has your dog been neutered?

meanings.definition: to take the power away from something
being a noun or pronoun of a type that refers to things; not masculine or feminine
to remove part of the sex organs of an animal so that it cannot reproduce
(of an animal) having had part of its sexual organs removed, so that it cannot produce young animals:
examples: Every pit bull must be registered and neutered.
Most of the sheep are neutered males.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         neuter
to remove part of an animal's sexual organs, so that it cannot produce young animals:
examples: Has your dog been neutered?

meanings.definition: to take the power away from something
not saying or doing anything that would encourage or help any of the groups involved in an argument or war:
examples: If there's an argument between my daughter and her mother, it's important that I remain neutral.
The peace conference would have to be held in a neutral country.
I'd rather meet on neutral ground/territory (= somewhere not controlled by or connected to either of us) rather than in his apartment.

meanings.definition: A neutral ground or field is a sports stadium that does not belong to either of the two teams taking part in a competition or game:
examples: The final will, of course, be played at a neutral ground.
The Superbowl always takes place on a neutral field.

meanings.definition: having features or characteristics that are not easily noticed:
examples: Kelly wants dark red walls, but I'd like a more neutral colour like cream.

meanings.definition: A neutral chemical substance is neither an acid nor an alkali:
examples: Pure water is neutral and has a pH of 7.

meanings.definition: A neutral particle has no electrical charge:
examples: Atoms consist of positively-charged protons, negatively-charged electrons and neutral particles called neutrons.

meanings.definition: A neutral wire is a wire in an electric circuit that almost always has zero voltage and is there to complete the circuit:
examples: The currents flowing in the live and neutral wires are the same, because they form part of a series circuit.

meanings.definition: the position of the gears in a vehicle when they are not connected to the engine:
examples: to leave the car in neutral

meanings.definition: a state of no activity or development:
examples: After two years in neutral, the economy is finally moving forward again.

meanings.definition: a neutral person or thing:
examples: Sweden and Switzerland were neutrals during the war.

meanings.definition: not expressing an opinion or taking actions that support either side in a disagreement or war:
examples: Switzerland remained neutral during the war.

meanings.definition: (of colors) not bright, and therefore not likely to attract attention:
examples: He wanted the office painted in neutral colors.

meanings.definition: A neutral substance is neither an acid nor a base.
A neutral wire in an electrical circuit is a wire with no electrical charge.

in American football, the area between the attacking players and the defending players when they line up on the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of a period of action) and where no player can stand before the ball is snapped (= moved to start the action):
examples: No part of any player on the defence can occupy the neutral zone at the beginning of a play.
The defensive tackle committed a neutral zone infraction, which resulted in a penalty of five yards.

meanings.definition: in ice hockey, the area in the centre of the rink (= playing area) between the two blue lines, between the offensive zone and the defensive zone:
examples: He brought the puck through the neutral zone and unloaded a shot on goal.

meanings.definition: an area of land between two areas that are controlled by opposing countries or groups that is not controlled by either group:
examples: This lies in the UN-controlled neutral zone that straddles the border between the two countries.
The invaders remained on enemy territory, but neutral zones were agreed and there was a cessation of hostilities.

meanings.definition: a neutral position, especially in a war:
examples: Sweden isn't likely ever to abandon its traditional neutrality.
The Queen has maintained political neutrality throughout her reign.

meanings.definition: the condition of being neutral in a disagreement or war
the act of making a substance neutral (= not an acid or an alkali):
examples: Slowing digestion may allow more complete mixing of food and neutralization of acid.
the neutralization reaction of an acid and a base

meanings.definition: the act of stopping something from having an effect:
examples: There is also an effort to make women equal by neutralization of sexual symbolism.
In the case of food intolerance, certain foods are avoided, or neutralization therapy provided.

meanings.definition: the act of killing someone, especially by a military force or government:
examples: They decided in favour of a quick and efficient neutralization of the armed groups of extremists.
Strategic political neutralizations can be made to look like accidents.

meanings.definition: in cycling or motor racing, the act of stopping a race from continuing for a time:
examples: The neutralization brought back memories of the 2006 race when the peloton got lost on the stage to Canterbury.

meanings.definition: the production of an effect that removes the effect of something else:
examples: neutralization of the threat of attack

meanings.definition: the reaction between an acid and a base, which produces a salt and water
to make a substance neutral (= not an acid or an alkali):
examples: Acidity in soil can be neutralized by spreading lime on it.
A baking soda bath neutralizes acidic bodily fluids and makes your skin feel silky smooth.

meanings.definition: to stop something or someone from having an effect:
examples: Antibodies neutralize viruses and other infectious agents.
The aerial bombardments have neutralized the threat of artillery attacks on allied ground forces.
Judo focuses on neutralizing opponents by throwing and pinning them to the floor.

meanings.definition: (especially of a military force or government) to kill someone:
examples: Pentagon generals will say U. S. soldiers neutralized opposition forces.
There was no question the state security council had wanted its opponents killed when it used words like "eliminate" and "neutralize".

meanings.definition: in cycling or motor racing, to stop a race from continuing for a time:
examples: The fourth stage of the race was neutralized between mile 46 and mile 67.

meanings.definition: to produce an effect that removes the effect of something else:
examples: Raising the sales tax will neutralize the tax cut.

meanings.definition: to cause a substance to be neither an acid nor a base:
examples: Acid in soil can be neutralized.

meanings.definition: If you have no alternative, you only have one reasonable choice or decision to make. :

meanings.definition: to not be a serious problem; to not be at all surprising or important:

meanings.definition: used to say that something is not a serious problem:

meanings.definition: someone who is not important:

meanings.definition: not anyone; no person:
examples: Nobody was around to answer the phone.
If he can’t fix your computer, nobody can.

meanings.definition: A nobody is also someone who is considered unimportant:
examples: There were celebrities there, but I sat between two nobodies.

meanings.definition: a bad effect on someone's health caused, for example, by them expecting a treatment not to work or to have side effects (= unpleasant effects in addition to the main intended effect):
examples: The nocebo effect could account for up to 25% of side effects.

The nocebo experiment involved volunteers being told that a mild electrical current would pass through their head, and although no electrical current was used, two-thirds of the volunteers complained of a headache afterwards.

meanings.definition: reacting to something that may be harmful by sending pain signals to the brain; relating to or caused by this process:
examples: Nociceptive neurons alert us to potentially damaging stimuli at the skin by detecting extremes in temperature.
Nociceptive pain is relatively resistant to morphine.

meanings.definition: shining at night:
examples: noctilucent cloud

meanings.definition: a condition that makes someone often need to urinate (= pass urine from the body) during the night:
examples: Nocturia can have a negative impact on several aspects of a person's quality of life.
People with an overactive bladder can experience nocturia, which means they need to get up frequently at night to go to the bathroom.

meanings.definition: being active or happening at night rather than during the day:
examples: Most bats are nocturnal.
nocturnal wanderings

meanings.definition: of the night, or relating to the night:
examples: He spends the nocturnal hours in his observatory.
nocturnal light

meanings.definition: of the night, or active during the night:
examples: Most bats and owls are nocturnal.

meanings.definition: the activity of eating a lot of food at night without being aware of or remembering doing it
at night rather than during the day:
examples: Patients with dementia often have nocturnally disrupted sleep.

meanings.definition: a gentle piece of classical music
to move your head down and then up, sometimes several times, especially to show agreement, approval, or greeting, or to show something by doing this:
examples: Many people in the audience nodded in agreement.
When I suggested a walk, Elena nodded enthusiastically.
She looked up and nodded for me to come in.

meanings.definition: a movement up and down with the head:
examples: Chen gave her a nod of recognition across the crowded room.

meanings.definition: a vote or nomination (= the act of officially suggesting that someone or something should be given a prize or position) for someone or something:
examples: Neeson received an Oscar nod for his role in Schindler's List.
At the time, Clinton and Obama were locked in a battle for their party's nod.

meanings.definition: to move the head down and then up again quickly, esp. to show agreement, approval, or greeting:
examples: The teacher nodded (his head) in agreement.

meanings.definition: to let your head fall forward when you are beginning to sleep
a movement of the head down and then up again quickly:
examples: He gave her a nod of recognition.

meanings.definition: to begin sleeping, especially not intentionally:
examples: After our busy day, we both sat and nodded off in front of the TV.

meanings.definition: to begin to sleep, esp. while sitting up:
examples: I nodded off once or twice during the movie.

meanings.definition: consisting of or relating to a place where a leaf and stem join a plant:

meanings.definition: consisting of or relating to a place where things such as lines or systems join:

examples: Cancer cells may spread to lymph nodes near the primarytumour. This is called nodal involvement.

meanings.definition: a very small mass of tissue in the body :

meanings.definition: a lump of tissue:

meanings.definition: having a small raised area or swelling:

meanings.definition: a small raised area or swelling:
examples: There was a soft nodule on my vocal cord.

meanings.definition: a small amount of alcoholic drink, usually a quarter of a pint
the head or mind of a person:

meanings.definition: showing the world as being unpleasant, strange, or cruel, especially in books and films:
examples: Unlike a noir mystery, these books end on a happier note with the bad guys caught and the mystery tidily solved.
She is the noir investigator, trying to fit the pieces together, getting bloodied in the process.
It's all very noir and very depressing.

meanings.definition: a way of showing the world as being unpleasant, strange, or cruel, especially in books and films:
examples: The atmosphere is classic noir: fog, rain, night and streets that lead nowhere.
For years, a touch of noir has been the perfect accessory for all hip crime writers.

meanings.definition: a book or film that shows the world as being unpleasant, strange, or cruel:
examples: Several noirs, including "Raw Deal", have been set here.
Ten years ago he published a noir. Now, with his latest novel, he has written a thriller.

meanings.definition: a type of movie, usually filmed in a city, that shows the world as an unhappy, violent place in which many unpleasant people live, or a film of this type:
examples: The film is a classic noir with an unusual mix of political satire.

meanings.definition: Noirish films or books show the world as being unpleasant, strange, or cruel:
examples: The book is a noirish teen drama.
The film has several plot twists and a dark, noirish look.

meanings.definition: a sound or sounds, especially when it is unwanted, unpleasant, or loud:
examples: The noise out in the street was deafening.
I heard a loud noise and ran to the window.
traffic/background noise
dangerously high noise levels

meanings.definition: any bad change in a signal, especially in a signal produced by an electronic device:
examples: Using a single chip reduces (the) noise on the output signal by 90 percent.

meanings.definition: unexplained or unexpected information in a sample that is not useful and that can be ignored:
examples: There will be a certain amount of statistical noise in the numbers.

meanings.definition: (a) sound, esp. when it is unwanted, unpleasant, or loud:
examples: I heard background noise on the phone line.
If the washing machine gets out of balance, it makes a horrible noise.

meanings.definition: unnecessary information or activity:
examples: The CEO was accused of making unnecessary noise to distract the board from the main issue.

meanings.definition: a change in a signal, especially one produced by electronic equipment:
examples: Using a single chip reduces the noise on the output signal by 90%.

meanings.definition: a legal instruction to reduce or stop loud or unpleasant sounds that are causing a problem for other people:
examples: The council issued a noise abatement order against the club.
