meanings.definition: noise, such as that from traffic, that upsets people where they live or work and is considered to be unhealthy for them:
examples: to tackle/ease/reduce noise pollution

meanings.definition: silent:
examples: Above them an eagle circled in noiseless flight.

meanings.definition: silently:
examples: She walked noiselessly across the carpet to the bathroom.

meanings.definition: a device that can be used to make noise, especially a horn or rattle for use at a party
a small, round piece of meat without much fat, especially lamb:
examples: pan-fried noisettes of lamb with leek risotto
I'm doing lamb noisettes in a port and redcurrant jelly sauce.

meanings.definition: in a noisy way:
examples: A motorbike started up noisily outside.

meanings.definition: the quality of making a lot of noise:
examples: The noisiness of the building work should be over by next week.

meanings.definition: very unpleasant and offensive:
examples: a noisome stench

meanings.definition: making a lot of noise:
examples: a noisy crowd of fans

meanings.definition: having an unwanted change in signal, especially of an electronic device:
examples: a noisy signal

meanings.definition: (of data) containing unexplained or unexpected information that is not useful and that can be ignored:
examples: If the word lists are too noisy, irrelevant terms can be manually removed.

meanings.definition: in a court of law, a situation in which someone does not make an argument or explanation that can be used to prove that they are guilty of something :
examples: A defendant may enter a plea of nolo contendere, in which he does not accept or deny responsibility for the charges.

meanings.definition: used for showing that you like a particular kind of food or that you think something looks or sounds very good to eat:
examples: Carrot cake muffins with a light cream cheese icing. Nom!

meanings.definition: a nomination (= an official suggestion for a prize, position, or job):

meanings.definition: food:
examples: The supermarkets have a good variety of international nom.

meanings.definition: to suggest something or someone officially for a prize, position, or job:
examples: The drama was nommed for an Emmy award.

meanings.definition: to eat something, especially in a way that shows you are enjoying what you are eating:

meanings.definition: a name chosen by someone to use when he or she is involved in a particular activity, especially fighting in a war:
examples: Pol Pot was not his real name, but a nom de guerre adopted in the 1970s.

meanings.definition: very small, or smaller than the usual amount:
examples: The hotel developers will lease the land for a nominal fee .

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is said to be a particular thing, but is not actually that thing:
examples: Although he has retired, the company is still under his nominal control.

examples: Merchandise imports have expanded significantly faster than world trade in both real and nominal dollar values.

not having a strong, pleasant smell:

meanings.definition: someone who is not an artist:

meanings.definition: not involved in or related to the arts (= painting, acting, dancing, music, etc.):

meanings.definition: the feeling of not caring about, or not feeling emotionally involved with, certain things, especially material things (= money and physical objects rather than spiritual things):

meanings.definition: the fact of not going to a place, especially a place you should go to regularly, or an occasion when someone does not go somewhere:

examples: They act together in mutually agreed and non-conflicting ways.

meanings.definition: a non-conforming loan does not meet official standards, especially because it is more than the borrower will be able to pay back:
examples: Non-conforming mortgages will become hard to obtain.

meanings.definition: a way of behaving that avoids upsetting anyone or causing an argument:
examples: The secret of the organization's succcess, he says, is a culture of accommodation and non-confrontation.
The company observes a strict policy of non-confrontation, so the intruders were allowed to leave unchallenged.

meanings.definition: different from something, so that the two things cannot exist together or be easily combined:
examples: Our values and beliefs were jarringly non-congruent.
Idiomatic expressions that are non-congruent with the learner's first language will be most difficult to learn.

meanings.definition: Non-congruent shapes have a different shape and size from each other. :
examples: In Question 4, students are required to identify four non-congruent triangles.
non-congruent shapes/triangles/rectangles

meanings.definition: not chemically conjugated (= formed by combining with another compound):
examples: The trial was the first to show the biological effect of a non-conjugated antibody against a solid tumour.
Current non-conjugated vaccines are not suitable for children under two years of age.

meanings.definition: Non-conscious thoughts or knowledge exist in people's minds without them being aware of them. :
examples: Many of us have the subtle, nonconscious belief that people who speak with a different accent are less trustworthy.
Intuition is typically understood as being the ability to access our non-conscious thoughts.

meanings.definition: Non-consecutive days, events, numbers, etc. do not follow one after another:
examples: Strength training should be done two or three times a week on non-consecutive days.
He became the only president to have been elected to two nonconsecutive terms.

meanings.definition: without the willing agreement of all the people involved:
examples: They proposed reducing the time it takes to obtain a non-consensual divorce from five to two years.
non-consensual sex

meanings.definition: a situation in which the total value of a physical quantity such as energy or mass does not remain the same:
examples: The article examines the non-conservation of energy in the radium experiments of Marie Curie.
We also discussed one other unexplained effect: the non-conservation of mass.

meanings.definition: willing to accept change or consider new ideas:
examples: Applicants will be interviewed to establish whether they have non-conservative views.
His conclusions are based on the opinions of a population of non-conservative, reasonable people.

meanings.definition: opposing conservative political parties (= ones that support business and are against high taxes and government involvement in industry):
examples: Most non-conservative parties support the idea of an active state.
All this disagreement amongst Republicans is great news for the non-conservative candidates.

meanings.definition: involving, relating to or supporting a political party that opposes the British Conservative party:
examples: The policy of private financing was later perpetuated by the non-Conservative government.
The party tends to attract non-Conservative voters.

meanings.definition: A non-conservative system does not conserve energy (= prevent it from being lost):
examples: The force is non-conservative and so has an associated torque.
Examples of non-conservative forces are friction and air resistance.

meanings.definition: not useful or helpful:
examples: It's usually better to make no comment than to risk upsetting people with a non-constructive comment.
The majority of their leisure time is spent in passive or nonconstructive recreation.

meanings.definition: a person or company that is not a consumer (= someone who buys things or services for their own use):
examples: For many years, most nonconsumers of electric hybrid cars were local governments.
The calculation includes the prices of non-consumer goods, such as business equipment.

meanings.definition: not being a consumer of particular goods or services, or of goods and services in general:
examples: Jane describes herself as a non-dependent, non-consuming individual who is not part of the typical family structure.
The proposition assumes that the non-consuming households are at the bottom of the income ladder.

meanings.definition: not eating or drinking a particular thing:
examples: The study compared regular coffee drinkers with a non-consuming group.

meanings.definition: the fact of not consuming (= buying for your own use) goods or services:
examples: With one roll of bin liners, I cancelled out a year's worth of non-consumption of plastic bags.
The non-consumption of unsustainable products is just one way for hotels to protect the environment.

meanings.definition: the fact of not eating or drinking a particular thing:
examples: The non-consumption of the cake represented their puritanism.

meanings.definition: not involving the consumption of things like water or wild animals:
examples: There is little danger from washing clothes or from other non-consumptive uses of the contaminated water.
More people are choosing non-consumptive activities, such as bird watching, over hunting and fishing.

meanings.definition: existing, happening or popular at a time that is not the present time:
examples: The director insisted that they should not use hand-held cameras for non-contemporary stories.
The author's style and interests are decidedly non-contemporary.

meanings.definition: someone who is not a member of the same generation (= a group of people of about the same age within a society or family) as someone else:
examples: Do these considerations apply to intergenerational relations, that is, to relations between non-contemporaries?

meanings.definition: not next to or touching another, usually similar, thing:
examples: The data files are stored on the hard drive in non-contiguous clusters.
In the past, schools in the area were noncontiguous -- they were not always close to each other.

meanings.definition: not depending on or influenced by something else:
examples: In the study, infants who received non-contingent care (care that did not depend on them crying for attention) were found to cry more.
Pay that is based on performance usually enhances productivity compared with noncontingent pay schemes.

meanings.definition: with pauses or interruptions:
examples: This treatment would take place over a non-continuous period of two to four years.
The fencing will be built in noncontinuous sections along the valley.

meanings.definition: not involving or fixed by a contract:
examples: The club is considering taking him on a non-contract basis, which would avoid the need for a work permit.
The state cut 150 noncontract workers -- clerks, office workers, and teaching assistants.

meanings.definition: relating to or involving arrangements that are not fixed by a contract:
examples: The union announced that drivers will ban non-contractual overtime from next month.
State and local governments have to cut noncontractual spending, such as that for schools, fire departments, and law enforcement.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is no contradiction (= the fact that one thing is opposite to or very different from another, so that one of them must be wrong), especially in the principle that a statement and its opposite cannot both be true:
examples: The law of non-contradiction states that we cannot simultaneously affirm and deny the truth of any statement.
When we adopt the principle of non-contradiction, it is impossible for anything to be definitely true, according to some philosophers.

meanings.definition: involving statements or ideas that agree or are similar:
examples: By affirming these non-contradictory ideas, members of different religions can move closer together.
Scientific methods attempt to formulate a non-contradictory theory based on empirical observations.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a financial plan or agreement for an employee that is completely paid for by the employer:
examples: a non-contributory insurance policy

meanings.definition: used to describe a benefit (= something of value offered in addition to a salary) for an employee that is completely paid for by the company, not the employee:
examples: The bank has recently closed its non-contributory pension scheme.

meanings.definition: not easily controlled:
examples: We are still learning how much blame for obesity can be attributed to a non-controllable factor like genetics.
The airline industry is keeping ticket prices down at a time when the non-controllable cost of oil continues to rise.

meanings.definition: without anything having been done to stop a problem from increasing:
examples: The patients' blood pressure ranged from tightly controlled to non-controlled hypertension.
Six people died in a non-controlled fire that started around midnight.

meanings.definition: If a drug is non-controlled, its use or sale is not tightly controlled by law because it is not considered to be dangerous or to cause addiction:
examples: Misrepresenting a noncontrolled substance as a controlled substance is a crime.
Medications can be divided into two categories: controlled and non-controlled.

meanings.definition: not using a control (= an object or system that is not changed so that you can compare it with similar objects or systems that are intentionally changed):
examples: In this non-controlled study, subcutaneous catheters were associated with a low incidence of infection.

meanings.definition: A non-controlling interest (= the fact of owning shares) in a company is not large enough to give control of the company, usually less than 50%:
examples: The net profit attributable to the non-controlling interest over the six-month period was £1 million.
The bank also owns a non-controlling interest in Johnson Mortgage Company.

meanings.definition: different from what is usual or from the way most people do things:
examples: If pain medication does not work, non-conventional treatment with acupuncture or hypnosis can sometimes be helpful.
Oil is still being found, but the really big opportunities are in non-conventional sources, such as shale oil and tar sands.

meanings.definition: involving nuclear, chemical, or biologicalweapons:
examples: The president refuses to rule out nonconventional weapons, such as nuclear missiles.
The commander indicated that the army may use nuclear weapons in response to a non-conventional attack.

meanings.definition: A non-convertible type of money cannot be easily exchanged into other types of money:
examples: a non-convertible currency/bond/security
Trade between the two countries was conducted in non-convertible currency.

meanings.definition: currency that cannot be changed into gold or into the currencies of other countries:
examples: With a non-convertible currency, a rudimentary banking system and no stockmarket, the country was struggling.

meanings.definition: the act of not working together with someone or not doing what they ask you to do:
examples: The country's continuing policy of non-cooperation is increasing the political pressure.
The union recommended non-cooperation by its members.
The pacifist group developed a strategy of noncooperation in order to draw attention to its aims.

meanings.definition: not willing to work with other people or do what they ask you to do:
examples: The organization has published a list of non-cooperative countries in an attempt to persuade them to comply.
The noncooperative behaviour of Members of Parliament makes contemporary politics an unpleasant spectacle.
Despite being called non-cooperative by teachers when he first came to the school, he went on to become a star pupil.

meanings.definition: not on the same plane (= flat surface):
examples: non-coplanar points/beams/lines
Although the computation only requires six non-coplanar points, all the points of the calibration grid are considered to increase the precision.

meanings.definition: relating to or involving a company's business activities that are less important than its main ones:
examples: In 2007, the company sold non-core assets worth 38 billion rubles.
The firm will consider selling noncore businesses in an effort to refocus on its main business.
non-core operations/activities

meanings.definition: a non-core activity, business, etc. is one that a company does not really need or consider the most important:
examples: Volvo sold its non-core businesses to focus on cars and trucks.
non-core assets/investments/holdings
They are still negotiating on which jobs are considered non-core.

meanings.definition: not part of a large company, or not relating to a large company:
examples: I like to support non-corporate coffee shops.
The club announced that all non-corporate tickets for Saturday's match have been sold.

meanings.definition: not relating to a large company that has been legally incorporated (= made a corporation) to have special rights:
examples: There are many small, non-corporate owned nursing homes.
The largest individual, noncorporate or nongovernment gift the museum had received was $25,000.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is no connection or relationship between two or more facts, numbers, etc.:
examples: They found a non-correlation between frequency variables and temperature.
Real estate as an asset provides non-correlation, which means that it does not move in exactly the same way as mainstream markets.

meanings.definition: A non-corrodible material or object cannot easily be damaged by the chemical action of something such as water or acid. :
examples: This non-corrodible brass socket is designed for high-moisture environments, and can be used outdoors.
The container should be made of a non-corrodible metal and kept in the fridge.

meanings.definition: A non-corroding material or object is not easily damaged by the chemical action of something such as water or acid:
examples: Our latest precision design has a long shallow keel and a non-corroding fibreglass centreboard.
The pump is made using non-corroding premium brass and hand removable neoprene caps.

meanings.definition: A non-corrosive substance does not cause damage by chemical action:
examples: a non-corrosive fluid/liquid/gas
The cleaning fluid is non-corrosive, leaves no residue, and is safe to work with.

meanings.definition: A non-corrosive material or object is not easily damaged by the chemical action of something such as water or acid. :
examples: a non-corrosive metal/container/pot/saucepan
Put the chicken wings in a non-corrosive container and cover with plain water.

meanings.definition: relating to or involving music that is not country and western (= popular music based on a type of traditional music from the western and southern US):
examples: We talked to Nash about country music and some of the things even a non-country music lover could appreciate.
She's attracting not just the traditional country fans, but a non-country audience as well.

meanings.definition: a country that is not important enough to be considered as a real country:
examples: Many other nations treat us as a non-country.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving a county (= a political division of the UK or Ireland, or of a US state), or the people who live in a particular county:
examples: The admission charge is £6 for county and £12 for non-county residents.
The RAF will become the first non-county team to compete when they play East Midlands next week.
The councillors for non-county boroughs have a limited range of responsibilities.

meanings.definition: Non-creative jobs or people are technical or practical ones, rather than ones that create new things using original or unusual ideas:
examples: The course aims to train adults in non-creative areas of television.
Traditional job titles often divide people into creative and non-creative roles.

meanings.definition: a situation or state in which there is little or no creativity (= the process of creating new things using original or unusual ideas):
examples: The author proposes that both creativity and non-creativity are learned.
During this long stretch of non-creativity, his unconscious mind was busy working on his next masterpiece.

meanings.definition: not involving or relating to crime:
examples: We have created a simplified report form to be used strictly for noncrime incidents.
When it comes to non-crime literature, Trollope and Austen remain her favourites.

meanings.definition: an action that may be wrong or illegal but is not officially recognized as a crime, or not important enough to be considered a real crime:
examples: He was arrested for the non-crime of being naked in his own home.
In the interview, he blames his victimless noncrime on prescription drugs.

meanings.definition: not relating to, involving, or considered to be a crime:
examples: a non-criminal case/investigation/matter/offence/violation
non-criminal conduct/justice
Thousands of young people are being held for noncriminal offences such as running away from home.

meanings.definition: a situation that is not bad enough to be considered a crisis (= a very serious event that causes great difficulty, danger, or suffering):
examples: In non-crisis circumstances, a moderate slowdown would even have been welcome in some countries.
Every environmental event, whether a crisis or a non-crisis, creates the opportunity for change.

meanings.definition: A non-critical illness or injury is not extremely serious or dangerous:
examples: Five passengers suffered serious but non-critical injuries.
People are unhappy about waiting months or years for medical treatments for noncritical conditions.

meanings.definition: not criticizing someone or what they have done:
examples: If parents are positive and have a non-critical attitude, it will help motivate the child.
You need to take the lead in a noncritical way, explaining how you feel about your relationship.

meanings.definition: less important or serious than other similar, issues, situations or activities:
examples: If too much electricity is being used, they can shut down air conditioning to some noncritical areas.
The proposal includes cutting 70 non-critical desk jobs.

meanings.definition: A non-crystalline object or substance is not a crystal (= a solid consisting of atoms or molecules that are arranged in a regular structure) or made of up crystals:
examples: In a non-crystalline material, the atoms are arranged in a random, haphazard way.
They had been unable to reach sufficiently low temperatures for the ice to remian non-crystalline.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving food or cooking:
examples: Lemon is used for non-culinary purposes throughout the world.
The market is known for its spices, both culinary and non-culinary, as well as a huge collection of teas.

meanings.definition: Non-cultivated land does not have crops growing on it. :
examples: The researchers looked at three different habitats: forests, non-cultivated land such as bush, and agricultural sites.
non-cultivated pastures/soil

meanings.definition: Non-cultivated plants or crops grow naturally, rather than being planted, for example by a farmer:
examples: These aphids are frequently found on crops as well as on non-cultivated plants.
non-cultivated crops/grasses/species

meanings.definition: a state or situation in which plants are not cultivated (= planted and grown, for example by a farmer):
examples: Non-cultivation, even when rent was paid, often led to removal of land ownership rights.
The anti-drug programme includes incentives for non-cultivation of fields for cannabis.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving the way of life, especially the general customs and beliefs, of a particular group of people at a particular time:
examples: Terms for such non-cultural concepts must have been familiar to these tribes for centuries.

meanings.definition: Non-cumulative arrangements do not allow people to receive money that was not paid in previous periods:
examples: The preference shares will receive a 9% non-cumulative dividend.
Non-cumulative shares give the right to a fixed percentage dividend of profit each year.

meanings.definition: Non-current payments have not been paid or do not have to be paid within a certain amount of time. :
examples: A shocking 22% of all mortgages in the state are noncurrent, according to a new report.
If collection of payment is expected within one year or less, the assets are classified as current assets. If not, they are presented as non-current assets.

meanings.definition: not happening or being used or made at the present time:
examples: I allow a couple of days to go by (so the date of the files is non-current) and then I delete them.
The service provides quality parts for all our current and noncurrent product lines.

meanings.definition: a debt or other payment that does not have to be paid within 12 months
(of a punishment) that does not involve a person being sent to prison:
examples: As an alternative to prison the judge may choose to give a non-custodial sentence.

meanings.definition: not having custody of a child (= the legal right to care for him or her):
examples: A non-custodial parent often has very limited access to his or her children.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving a customer or customers of a particular organization:
examples: Owners must maintain and operate all non-customer parking areas.
The big banks charge an average of $1.35 for noncustomer transactions.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a customer of a particular organization:
examples: If you are a non-customer, please take the form to the branch that is most convenient for you.
The banks are imposing a surcharge on any noncustomer who uses their cashpoints .

meanings.definition: not affected by patterns of economic change:
examples: non-cyclical businesses/companies/goods/markets/sectors

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving a woman's menstrual cycle (= the series of changes that take place in a woman's body every month):
examples: Mastalgia can be divided into cyclical and non-cyclical breast pain.
Chronic pelvic pain is defined as noncyclical long-term pelvic pain that requires medical care.

meanings.definition: containing nothing that is made from animal milk:
examples: non-dairy drinks made from soya milk
non-dairy recipes
They offer plenty of vegan and nondairy options.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving dance or dancing:
examples: Gaining visibility in the dance world and doing non-dance tasks such as administration has been challenging for him.
To help a non-dance audience, we used a narrator to signpost the story.
The director added in dances to passages that Tchaikovsky intended as nondance music.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a dancer, or who is not dancing:
examples: "I love using natural movements that a non-dancer would use," said Frank.
Unusually, the show featured a nondancer in the starring role.
A non-dancer would usually look after the children behind the scenes in the theatre.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving Darwinian theories (= the theories of Charles Darwin, which described how animals and plants change and develop over millions of years, with those that are best suited to their environment being the most successful and others that are less well suited not continuing to exist):
examples: There is a feeling that evolution must consist of something more orderly, and in this respect, the old tradition of non-Darwinian thinking is still alive.
Conservative thinkers chose to accept a non-Darwinian version of evolution.

meanings.definition: telling people the truth and not trying to make them believe something that is not true :
examples: non-deceptive fieldwork/methods/practices/research/studies
By law, advertisements must be truthful and non-deceptive, and businesses must have evidence to back up their claims.
This type of study should proceed only when nondeceptive methods appear inferior.

meanings.definition: failure to make a decision on a subject:
examples: A non-decision is the worst possible outcome: each year a project is delayed costs a further 500 million euros.
They said that government inaction, or nondecision, becomes a policy when it is pursued consistently over a long period of time.

meanings.definition: A non-deductible amount cannot be taken away from a total, especially so that less tax can be paid:
examples: The cost of travel from home to the workplace is usually non-deductible if it is considered to be ordinary commuting.
The new tax will be nondeductible for corporation tax purposes.
Non-deductible expenses include, for example, legal and professional fees, bad debts, and penalties and fines.

meanings.definition: considering the known facts and making judgments about probable causes and results:
examples: It is not possible to dismiss these non-deductive techniques as simply "subjective".
Much evaluative reasoning is nondeductive because there is not enough information to enable us to draw firm conclusions.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving defence, in particular weapons and other systems that protect a country against attack:
examples: The promised increase in social security payments has led to painful cuts to non-defence spending.
Orders for non-defence capital goods, which reflect business spending for new equipment, fell by 1.5 percent.
He promised to freeze nondefence spending.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving defense, in particular weapons and other systems that protect a country against attack:
examples: Government spending is likely to shift towards non-defense programs, such as medical research
Orders for non-defense capital goods, which reflect business spending for new equipment, fell by 1.5 percent.
Orders and shipments for nondefense capital goods have generally decreased in recent months.

meanings.definition: not able to be delayed until a later time:
examples: Non-deferrable expenses could include costs such as rent, property taxes, utilities, and insurance.
Tasks such as milking and feeding are categorized as "nondeferrable" because they take place at specified times each day and cannot be put off.

meanings.definition: (of a clause) giving extra information about someone or something and not necessary in order to understand who or what is being referred to, or (of a pronoun) used in a clause like this:
examples: In the sentence "My younger sister, who lives in Boston, is a nurse", "who lives in Boston" is a non-defining relative clause.
If the clause is non-defining and the antecedent non-human, you usually use which and put a comma before it, as in "He screwed the paper into a ball, which he threw in the bin."
In the first sentence "which" functions as a non-defining pronoun.

meanings.definition: not explaining or describing the meaning and exact limits of something:
examples: There are many women who find other women attractive in a non-defining way (= they may or may not be lesbian).

meanings.definition: A non-degradable substance will not degrade (= change into a more simple chemical structure over time):
examples: One of the dangers of lead is the fact that it is non-degradable, which means that it remains in the atmosphere forever.
Nondegradable plastic floats in the sea, where it chokes and kills fish and other wildlife.

meanings.definition: not leading to or working towards a degree (= a qualification given to a student after they have completed a course of study at a college or university):
examples: a non-degree student/course/programme
If you've been out of the education system for some time, try taking one or two courses as a non-degree student.
The government provides financial aid for adults seeking short-term career training in nondegree classes.

meanings.definition: not intentional or planned:
examples: The police are investigating whether the malfunction came about as a result of a deliberate or a nondeliberate occurrence.
A large part of the primary socialization process is unplanned and non-deliberate.

meanings.definition: a situation in which goods, letters, parcels, etc. that have been ordered or sent are not delivered (= taken to people's houses or places of work):
examples: In the case of non-delivery, the time limit for making a claim is 42 days.
If a customer repeatedly claims nondelivery, delete their name from your mailing list.
The right of the buyer to recover any payments he has already made clearly applies in the case of a non-delivery.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something that has been promised is not achieved or produced:
examples: The contract has been canceled as a result of a non-delivery by the Department of Health on their contractual obligations.
Businesses can sometimes be critical of IT departments over non-delivery, but sometimes delays are unavoidable.

meanings.definition: the fact that goods bought by someone have not been received by them:
examples: The buyer will be entitled to damages assessed as for non-delivery of goods.

meanings.definition: not needing a lot of time, attention, or energy:
examples: These passive music consumers' tastes have less to do with musical interest and more to do with familiar, non-demanding easy listening.
This is a fairly non-demanding course that you could do in your spare time while still working.

meanings.definition: not asking other people for something in a forceful way:
examples: You need to ask for more support, but in a nondemanding way.

meanings.definition: relating to a system of government or a country in which the leaders are not elected by the people, or not elected in a way that is considered to be fair:
examples: a non-democratic country/government/regime/state
The government is facing criticism about its record of nondemocratic elections.

meanings.definition: not based on the principles of democracy (= the belief in freedom and equality between people) :
examples: She claimed that the whole debate around political correctness was non-democratic, arguing that it keeps people from saying what they think.
Low wages and occupational risk are related to the nondemocratic nature of farm labour.

meanings.definition: not connected with a particular religious denomination
in the UK, relating to an organization that is involved in government but is not part of a government department:
examples: A new non-departmental energy agency will take over responsibility for nuclear power stations.
The government sees a continuing role for non-departmental public bodies, particularly when faced with politically hostile local authorities.
The IPCC is a nondepartmental public body.

meanings.definition: not needing someone's support to provide money, food, etc.:
examples: In the 1980s, only 11% of households contained a non-dependent child.
Back in the 1970s, the media portrayed her as a non-dependent modern woman.

meanings.definition: taking drugs or a drug, but able to stop if necessary; relating to taking drugs in this way:
examples: The research was based on a small study of 15 recreational nondependent drug users.
The coroner recorded a verdict of death by non-dependent drug use.

meanings.definition: Non-depletable forms of energy and technology are still available when people have used them, or can be produced as quickly as they are used:
examples: They recommend that non-depletable resources (such as software and online tools) should be provided to users without charge.
Only SBSP (space-based solar power) fulfils all the essential criteria: it is low-cost, nondepletable, environmentally clean, and available to everyone.

meanings.definition: the fact of rock or soil not being deposited (= laid down, especially by wind or water):
examples: Creeks are thought to be areas of non-deposition rather than areas of erosion.
The nodular limestones were formed during extensive periods of nondeposition.

meanings.definition: A non-derivative asset is one whose value does not depend on the value of another asset such as a currency:
examples: Non-derivative financial instruments consist of trade and other receivables, cash and cash equivalents, and long-term debt.
Item 305 requires information about non-derivative non-trading instruments.

meanings.definition: containing ideas that are new and not copied or developed from something else :
examples: He hoped his choreography would reveal some non-derivative qualities.
The film is interesting enough to hold one's attention without providing any fresh or nonderivative developments.

meanings.definition: not clearly describing or explaining something, or telling you what it is:
examples: The menu was non-descriptive: there was a list of options, but no information on the items.
The work that I'm doing now is abstract, non-descriptive, and highly symbolic.
If an older person comes in with nondescriptive pain that's not getting better, I'll order a series of tests.

meanings.definition: (of an area of land) not covered with desert:
examples: Ancestors of modern humans populated all the non-glaciated and non-desert parts of Eurasia and Africa.
Our survey revealed 37 wild mammal species with the disease in non-desert ecoregions of Mexico.
The speed of water loss from a cactus plant may be up to one thousand times slower than that of a plant living in nondesert conditions.

meanings.definition: not causing damage:
examples: They use non-destructive testing to determine the quality of the components without having to take the machine apart.
The beauty of this method is that it is non-destructive, so it saves a lot of time and money.
Nondestructive examination of the nuclear reactor will begin later this year.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not cause damage:
examples: The car parts are now tested non-destructively, which has numerous advantages in terms of cost and time.
The plant samples were measured quickly, simply, and nondestructively.
This technique is used to non-destructively measure concentrations of chemical elements within a small area of the sample.

meanings.definition: (of an object) designed in such a way that it cannot be removed:
examples: The organizers made them wear non-detachable orange wristbands and let them stay in only the most basic rooms.
One associates these hotel chains with mindless standardization, rooms without a view, and non-detachable coat hangers.
They designed a container for fruit with a nondetachable lid.

meanings.definition: producing a different result each time the same piece of data is entered:
examples: The calculus is non-deterministic because the substitution mechanism does not follow any strategy for fetching resources from arguments.
In the theory of computation, a nondeterministic finite state machine is one where there may be several possible next states.

meanings.definition: likely to have a different result every time, so that it is not possible to guess what will happen:
examples: We can adopt a non-deterministic position that sees social structure as a complex system that is unstable and dynamic.
Any voting method which is completely strategy-free must be nondeterministic, that is, it might not select the same outcome every time it is applied.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something does not develop, or is not developed:
examples: Non-development of trust comes about when the consultant is unreliable, breaks promises, and is late for appointments.
Medical experts at the time claimed that the condition was a state of non-development caused by defective organs.
They list a number of developments - and non-developments - that are likely to go on being important for many years to come.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving development, for example of an industry, area, or country :
examples: These "grassroots" organizations tend to be small, founded by non-development specialists, run by volunteers, and funded by individuals.
Parliament was increasingly demanding a more active role for government in non-development issues such as electoral and industrial reform.

meanings.definition: not relating to or affected by diabetes (= a disease in which the body cannot control the level of sugar in the blood):
examples: Dietary advice for a person with diabetes is different from that for a non-diabetic person.
It is possible that diabetic patients were suspected of having the condition at an earlier stage of illness than non-diabetic individuals.

meanings.definition: not able to be removed by dialysis (= a process of separating substances from liquid by putting them through a thin piece of skin-like material):
examples: These data imply that the additional components are non-dialyzable and thus of considerable molecular weight.
Human lymphocytes need the nondialyzable macromolecular constituents of serum in order to synthesize DNA.

meanings.definition: not intended to teach people, or to tell them what to do or think :
examples: Therapists try to provide caregivers with developmental guidance while also maintaining a nondidactic approach.
The films were non-didactic, aesthetic rather than informative, and appealed to emotion rather than to reason.

meanings.definition: Non-diegetic music in a film or TV programme is played over the action for the people watching to hear, rather than being part of the action and heard by the characters.
not able to be diffused (= spread through or into a surrounding substance ):
examples: The role of hyperemia in the results is eliminated by a comparative study using non-diffusible vascular tracers.
The values were computed using a nondiffusible tracer model.

meanings.definition: not expressed in or representing measurements of any particular unit, for example of length, or time:
examples: In complex value measurement systems, native performance scales are collapsed onto a non-dimensional value scale, which is normalized between zero and one.
Multiplying a selection gradient by the corresponding phenotypic standard deviation gives the selection intensity, a non-dimensional quantity that is widely used by breeders.

meanings.definition: not having or appearing not to have height, length, depth, or width:
examples: In the end, circumference and centre are reduced to a nearly non-dimensional point.
The two worst enemies of dark hair are flat, non-dimensional colour and lack of condition.

meanings.definition: not involving diplomats (= officials whose job is to represent one country in another, and who usually work in an embassy):
examples: Those forced to leave include non-diplomatic support staff at the foreign embassies, migrant workers, freelance writers, artists, and students.
Foreign governments can engage in nondiplomatic activity on American soil, but cannot do so via their embassy.

meanings.definition: acting in a way that might cause people to be upset, hurt, or annoyed :
examples: His colleagues see him as arrogant, non-diplomatic, and pretentious.
If you speak about others in a non-diplomatic way, people will avoid you because they may be the next one to be talked about.

meanings.definition: not involving rules or instructions about what to say or do:
examples: I used a simple set of questions to obtain a significant sample of these vowels in nondirected speech.
The primary goal of this type of therapy is non-directed relaxation.

meanings.definition: Non-directional investments aim to earn the same amount of profit whether the economy is strong or not:
examples: Non-directional funds try to stay independent of market movements.
The appeal of non-directional strategies is greater in periods when there is more uncertainty in the markets.
We are aware of the risk of hedge funds so we have focused on nondirectional investments.

meanings.definition: Non-directional sound or light waves are equally strong in every direction:
examples: The 3D speaker system leaves the largely non-directional deep bass sounds to a single sub-woofer unit.
The inner ear is located in such a way that it does not touch most other bones in the skull, thus diminishing the nondirectional sound waves.

meanings.definition: Non-directive counselling (= the process of listening to someone's problems so that you can help them) or education is counselling or education in which you do not tell someone what to do and instead let them make their own decisions:
examples: The key skill of non-directive counselling is ensuring that you avoid dictating solutions.
A good classroom facilitator will take a nondirective approach, guiding the discussion as appropriate.
The kind of counselling that we practise here is nondirective and patient-centred.

meanings.definition: having the physical or mental abilities that most people have:
examples: Such awareness programmes have put non-disabled employees in wheelchairs to see how well they can get around the office.
Disabled and nondisabled youths play side by side so they can learn to accept each others' differences.

meanings.definition: a situation in which information is not made known to others:
examples: In some cases, the safety of witnesses required the non-disclosure of their identity.
An order of non-disclosure could be obtained, and criminal history information would no longer be public information.
All the employees were bound to silence by nondisclosure agreements.
In fact, only the most serious non-disclosures will result in the non-payment of a claim.

meanings.definition: the fact of not making something known:
examples: The court had to balance the interest to be served by non-disclosure against the interest served by disclosure.
The appeal will focus on the non-disclosure of evidence.

meanings.definition: a legal document stating that someone will not tell anyone certain private information, especially about the company they work for:
examples: He has new employees sign a non-disclosure agreement limiting what they can say about his company.
He declined to name the investor, citing a non-disclosure agreement.

meanings.definition: an agreement not to make something known, often required before a business negotiation can start:
examples: In some cases, clients require these temporary professionals to sign non-disclosure agreements.

meanings.definition: not selling at or involving reduced prices:
examples: Are you more likely to avoid delays and cancellations if you go with a non-discount airline?
Feedback from non-discount supermarkets suggests that even their customers are increasingly buying from their cheaper lines.

meanings.definition: relating to something that you pay for that is considered necessary, such as food and rent:
examples: The price of non-discretionary items such as fuel and food has been rising sharply.
The non-discretionary nature of the healthcare chain's products helped it survive the economic downturn.

meanings.definition: A non-discretionary fund (= an amount of money saved or invested for someone) does not allow the person who manages the fund to make decisions about how the money in it is managed and used, without asking the person who the money belongs to:
examples: With a non-discretionary account, you make all the trading decisions, and the broker may not execute any transactions without your approval.
Trusts may be either discretionary or non-discretionary.

meanings.definition: not having the right to decide for someone how their money should be invested, when it should be paid to them, etc.:
examples: My wife and I recently made a non-discretionary trust settlement on our grandchildren.

meanings.definition: the practice of treating people, companies, countries, etc. in the same way as others in order to be fair:
examples: a non-discrimination law/policy/provision/rule
She voiced concerns about the lack of a non-discrimination clause that would ensure the policy is enforced fairly.
The organization's current policy on homosexuality does not meet the criteria of the nondiscrimination clause.

meanings.definition: the practice of treating people, companies, countries, etc. in the same way as others in order to be fair:
examples: The principle of non-discrimination in trade relations would restrain destructive economic nationalism, and help prevent the resurgence of protectionist policies.
Is there a written employee nondiscrimination policy?

meanings.definition: treating everyone in the same way, whatever their race, gender, sexuality, etc.:
examples: One of the key principles of the directive is that there will be non-discriminatory access to all public transportation facilities.
A pregnant employee must be treated in a nondiscriminatory fashion, receiving the same level of benefits as other employees.

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation in which everyone is treated in the same way:
examples: They're opening the market to foreign suppliers by giving them non-discriminatory access to the local network.

meanings.definition: not involving language or words:
examples: We rely on non-discursive forms of communication, which by their nature defy translation into words.
His theories stress the interactions of individuals expressed through both discursive and non-discursive practices.

meanings.definition: not involving or causing dispersion (= the separation of light into different colours):
examples: Such a medium is called a non-dispersive medium, and waves travelling through it will maintain a constant shape.
In this paper, I describe the general techniques used to perform nondispersive X-ray diagnostics of these short-lived plasmas.

meanings.definition: not causing trouble or problems, and therefore not stopping something from continuing as usual:
examples: Students have the right to express their views at school but they must do it in a non-disruptive way.
Comparisons between disruptive and nondisruptive Year 1 children confirmed their hypothesis.

meanings.definition: Something that is non-distinctive does not makes things different from other things:
examples: The male flowers have a faint but non-distinctive scent.
It was proposed that vowel length is nondistinctive before analysis of the utterances of 25 native speakers confirmed this.

meanings.definition: not able to be distributed (= given out) to shareholders (= people who own shares in a company and therefore get part of the company's profits):
examples: Non-distributable reserves are created for a specific purpose and cannot be distributed among shareholders.
Any profits are non distributable and are retained for the benefit of the Scheme.

meanings.definition: profit made by a company that is not available to pay as dividends to shareholders:
examples: Included in the Profit and Loss Account of the company are non-distributable reserves.

meanings.definition: someone who is not a doctor:
examples: Do you think part of this diagnosis could be done by a non-doctor?
As a non-doctor, I couldn't understand his explanation.
The workshop looks at the changing role of the practice nurse and includes sessions on non-doctor prescribing.

meanings.definition: emphasizing practical solutions rather than following fixed beliefs and ideas:
examples: He published an intellectual, non-doctrinaire journal of opinions, politics and arts.
It's a very easygoing, non-doctrinaire organization, full of kind people who do their best to see both sides of every issue.
These students are articulate, techno-savvy, impressively well-informed, and nondoctrinaire.

meanings.definition: not having the features of a documentary (= a film or television or radio programme that gives facts and information about a subject):
examples: He is the first non-documentary filmmaker to have secured rights to the singer's life and music.
He released four full-length nondocumentary movies before his death.

meanings.definition: not involving or contained in documents:
examples: An event may be proved by nondocumentary evidence, even though a written record of it was made.
They can use other nondocumentary methods of identification.

meanings.definition: open to new and different ideas, and not claiming that you are always right, especially in connection with religious beliefs :
examples: He was a flexible politician, who always looked for an imaginative and non-dogmatic solution to problems.
The aim of the project is to help pupils approach the diversity of religious beliefs in an open and non-dogmatic way.

meanings.definition: not involving or relating to the dollar, usually the US dollar:
examples: About 35 percent of the country's reserves are in non-dollar assets.
Any weakness of the US dollar makes dollar-denominated assets more attractive to non-dollar investors.
Tickets sold in nondollar currencies usually bring in more profit.

meanings.definition: someone who is living in a country in which they are not domiciled (= it is not their legal home), especially when this means that they pay less tax:
examples: My precise tax status is that of a non-dom.
What is the best way for non doms to hold UK property?

meanings.definition: (of a person) living in a country in which they are not domiciled (= it is not their legal home), especially when this means that they pay less tax:
examples: All the political parties now rely on non-dom donors.
More non dom clients are being encouraged to reconsider their tax status.

meanings.definition: relating to people living in a country in which they are not domiciled (= it is not their legal home), especially when this means that they pay less tax:
examples: Non-dom status allows the wealthy to legally escape paying tax on earnings abroad.
Uncertainty has hung over non-dom taxation for many years.
The representatives of wealthy foreigners claimed that the £30,000 non dom levy would drive the wealthy out of London.

meanings.definition: abbrevation for non-domiciled: relating to the position of a person who lives in a country but does not have to pay tax there on money they have earned outside the country:
examples: The Treasury says there are about 116,000 residents with non-dom status.
He called for a non-dom levy of £25,000 a year on those who live in this country but do not pay full taxes.

meanings.definition: a person who lives in a country but does not have to pay tax there on money they have earned outside the country:
examples: For these non-doms, the UK is a tax haven.

meanings.definition: not relating to, or taking place in, the home, house, or family:
examples: The law distinguishes between childcare provision in domestic premises and non-domestic premises such as playgroups.
The new legislation will raise the minimum age for buying a non-domestic knife from 16 to 18.

meanings.definition: not existing, taking place, or operating in a particular country:
examples: The term "offshoring" is often used to refer to outsourcing to a non-domestic provider.
On Tuesday afternoon, about ten to twelve nondomestic flights were allowed to land.

meanings.definition: (of a person) living in a country in which they are not domiciled (= it is not their legal home), especially when this means that they pay less tax:
examples: London has the largest community of non-domiciled tycoons in the world.
As he is a non-domiciled taxpayer, the houses would avoid the normal inheritance tax of 40%, or £1.6 million.

meanings.definition: relating to people living in a country in which they are not domiciled (= it is not their legal home), especially when this means that they pay less tax:
examples: His new non-domiciled status allows him to spend 90 nights in the UK every year.
He accused the minister of being ignorant on the subject of non-domiciled taxation.

meanings.definition: Non-drip paint is specially made so that it does not produce unwanted drops when it is being used.
goods that do not last for a long time and that people buy often:
examples: Job prospects look best in non-durable goods manufacturing and wholesale and retail trade.
There was stronger demand for both durable products like airplanes and for nondurables such as food and paper products.

meanings.definition: not relating to trade, industry, or money:
examples: The money was meant to compensate them for suffering non-economic damages such as pain, mental distress, and family strain.
You rarely hear the word used in a noneconomic context.
It was obvious that the reasons why voters voted the way they did were mostly non-economic.

meanings.definition: money that is paid to someone because they have been physically harmed rather than because they have been caused financial loss:
examples: There are financial limits on the amount of money someone can receive in a lawsuit for non-economic damages.

meanings.definition: a person who has not studied or does not have a special knowledge of economics:
examples: Most non-economists did not expect a recession.
It was a big surprise when a noneconomist was appointed as the country's Finance Minister.

meanings.definition: not intended for eating or not safe to eat:
examples: Make sure that you remove the non-edible decorations from the cake before serving it.
All of the plants in the garden are non-edible.

meanings.definition: relating to people who are not editors (= people who write or change text, for example in a newspaper or magazine) or to work that is not editing (= writing or changing text):
examples: The newspaper wrote to all non-editorial staff.
The journalist also does non-editorial work when required.

meanings.definition: not relating to education:
examples: They employed some non-education graduates in order to boost the teaching staff.
The charity also funded non-education projects which are consistent with their aims.

meanings.definition: not providing or relating to education:
examples: The school building is also used for noneducational purposes in the evenings and at weekends.
The word is rarely found with this meaning in non-educational contexts.

meanings.definition: not successful or not achieving the results that you want:
examples: It became clear that the approach was non-effective.
The government was criticized for its non-effective programme of legislation.

meanings.definition: (used about a treatment or drug) not working well:
examples: The pain relief proved to be non-effective.
a non-effective dose

meanings.definition: not able to stretch and return to its original shape or size, or relating to this ability:
examples: The substance is similar to rubber, but it is non-elastic.
The two scientists published a paper on the non-elastic properties of various materials.

meanings.definition: not containing elastic (= a type of rubber that is able to stretch and return to its original shape or size):
examples: He insists on wearing non-elastic socks.
Older students may prefer to wear a non-elastic tie .

meanings.definition: not having been voted into a particular important job or position:
examples: The committee consists of at least three non-elected representatives in addition to the five MPs.
The president's wife is, essentially, a non-elected adviser.

meanings.definition: an election that does not take place:
examples: It turned out to be a non-election because of the Prime Minister's change of mind.
Commentators criticized the government after the nonelection.

meanings.definition: A non-election year is one in which there is no election:
examples: There is less campaigning in a non-election year.

meanings.definition: not voted for in an election:
examples: The central government organ was non-responsible and non-elective.
The highest nonelective positions in the US are those of the president's cabinet.

meanings.definition: (of a medical treatment) ugently needed and not chosen by a patient, or relating to such a treatment :
examples: non-elective surgery
The baby was delivered by nonelective caesarean section because of foetal distress.
A high number of patients were operated on under non-elective conditions.

meanings.definition: If something is non-elective, you have to do it or it has to happen. :
examples: There should be non-elective lectures in nutrition for all trainee doctors.
Employers are required to make a nonelective contribution to the plan.

meanings.definition: not using electricity for power:
examples: Many people prefer to use non-electric household and cooking appliances such as can openers and whisks.
Both electric and non-electric bikes are available for hire.

meanings.definition: not using or relating to electricity:
examples: They manufacture both electrical and nonelectrical machinery and parts for a wide range of different industries.
The process and equipment can be repurposed for non-electrical applications.

meanings.definition: not using a system of operation that involves the control of electric current by various devices:
examples: The shop specializes in traditional, wooden, and non-electronic toys.
He prefers to use non-electronic welding methods.

meanings.definition: not using or related to computers:
examples: Financial transactions are completed using both electronic and non-electronic means of payment.
A number of nonelectronic games are still popular with children.

meanings.definition: not belonging to the elite (= the richest, most powerful, best-educated, or best-trained group in a society):
examples: The same principles of organization are found at both elite and non-elite levels of society.
They ran as part of the group of non-elite athletes.

meanings.definition: something, such as an accident, that is not dangerous or serious and does not need fast action in order to avoid harmful results:
examples: Many of these visits were for non-emergencies, such as toothaches and colds.
All non-emergency surgery has been cancelled.

meanings.definition: not having and expressing strong feelings:
examples: It was hard to have a non-emotional reaction to the pictures.
He was strangely non-emotional at the funeral.

meanings.definition: not relating to the emotions:
examples: The child had experienced a number of emotional and non-emotional problems.
Scientists tested the response to nonemotional stimuli.

meanings.definition: A non-emphatic word or sound is one that is not stressed (= given more force or importance than others):
examples: The distinction between emphatic and nonemphatic indefinite pronouns is marked only by the stress.
One can describe intonation in terms of pairs of opposed features: "non-emphatic" and "emphatic", and "suspensive" and "final".

meanings.definition: used for referring to a particular type of consonant in languages such as Arabic, Aramaic, and Hebrew:
examples: Arabic distinguishes between emphatic and non-emphatic consonants.

meanings.definition: based on theory rather than on what is experienced or seen:
examples: She believed that sociology was a non-empirical field which must study social action using purely subjective means.
Their methodology was criticized as being non-empirical.

meanings.definition: someone who is not an employee of a person or company:
examples: Non-employees must sign in at reception every time that they visit the building.
What rules does the company have for working with independent contractors and other types of nonemployees?

meanings.definition: the fact of not having paid work:
examples: Rates of non-employment are extremely high in these groups.
The duration of the nonemployment period was found to be significant.

meanings.definition: A non-empty set is one which contains at least one member:
examples: Let X be any non-empty set of variables.
When can a non-empty set M of real numbers be said to be unbounded?

meanings.definition: the last part of a story where the story ends suddenly:
examples: The non-ending of the story was intriguing as it left so many questions unanswered.
The series' nonending infuriated fans.

meanings.definition: used for describing activities or events, especially unpleasant ones, when they seem to continue for ever:
examples: It was no surprise that this war was non-ending.
The computer was running a non-ending program in the background.

meanings.definition: not relating to energy (= power from something such as electricity or oil):
examples: Non-energy commodities were down more than 20 percent from their peak.
The country has used the oil revenue to invest in the expansion of its non-energy private sector.

meanings.definition: the fact of allowing people to not obey a law or rule:
examples: She campaigned for the non-enforcement of the law.
The harshness of the country's laws is softened by their non-enforcement.

meanings.definition: not involved in or relating to making certain that people obey a law or rule:
examples: There is a need to monitor the broad range of nonenforcement activities performed by the police.
Grupo Beta is the humanitarian, nonenforcement arm of Mexico's immigration patrol.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being involved with something:
examples: Our culture of public cynicism and non-engagement encourages such behaviour.
Non-engagement with mental health treatment is a familiar problem for health services.

meanings.definition: the fact of choosing not to begin fighting someone:
examples: Non-engagement with the enemy is not an option.
The government favoured a policy of non-engagement with the rebels.

meanings.definition: not studying, working in, or relating to engineering (= the design and building of machines, engines, or electrical equipment):
examples: They are increasingly hiring non-engineering graduates to test software applications.
Coming from a non-engineering background, I do sometimes feel a little unappreciated or threatened.

meanings.definition: not relating to entertainment (= shows, films, television, or other performances or activities that entertain people):
examples: Downloads of nonentertainment apps have grown.
The channel specializes in non-entertainment programming, offering a range of educational and documentary programmes.

meanings.definition: not caused by the action of, or not consisting of, an enzyme (= a chemical substance produced by a living cell and causing a particular chemical reaction to happen while not being changed itself):
examples: Glycosylation is a non-enzymatic reaction that reflects the concentration of excess glucose.
They investigated the changes in non-enzymic antioxidants during desiccation.

meanings.definition: not involving sexual desire and pleasure:
examples: The story is about non-erotic love between an older woman and a teenage boy.
The painting is one of a series of non-erotic scenes that she painted in her later life.

meanings.definition: not yet accepted or respected because of being fairly new:
examples: A number of patients agreed to submit to a non-established therapy.
Non-established ways of working have been introduced.

meanings.definition: used for describing someone who is not known for doing a job well because they have not been doing it for a long time:
examples: He was flattered because he was the only non-established player from Brazil to be included in the team.
Nonestablished actors can struggle to get auditions.

meanings.definition: used for describing a church or religion that is not the official one of a country:
examples: The archbishop is much loved by the priests and laity of the non-established Church of Wales.
Nonestablished religious groups are under-represented.

meanings.definition: not part of the establishment (= the important and powerful people who control a country or an organization, especially those who support the existing situation):
examples: The non-establishment candidates for the leadership are top of the polls.
A balance must be struck so that nonestablishment science ideas are given a public outing.

meanings.definition: not yet changed into an ester (= a chemical compound produced by a reaction between an acid and an alcohol, in which the hydrogen of the acid has been replaced by an alkyl group of atoms):
examples: Non-esterified fatty acids are transported in the blood.

meanings.definition: not invested in or relating to companies that are known for being socially and environmentally responsible :
examples: The report revealed that ethical funds perform equally as well as non-ethical funds.
Customers expect good, if not better, service than they would get from a non-ethical alternative, especially if they are charged more.

meanings.definition: not morally right, or not relating to beliefs about what is morally right and wrong:
examples: We would not be so keen on freedom of information if the information were used in a non-ethical way.
There are many non-ethical reasons for preserving nature.

meanings.definition: relating to the study of geometry (= the study of angles and shapes formed by the relationships between lines) that disagrees with or adds to the theories of Euclid
not belonging to or relating to Europe or its people:
examples: Only three non-European cities were on the list of the top ten best cities in which to live.
The French company is expanding into non-European countries.

meanings.definition: a person who is not from Europe:
examples: She was the first non-European to win the competition.
Two of the competitors who beat him were non-Europeans.

meanings.definition: not involving judging or calculating the quality, importance, amount, or value of something:
examples: The writer of the report took particular care to choose non-evaluative adjectives where possible.
She gave the results of the survey in a purely factual, non-evaluative manner in order to remain as objective as possible.

meanings.definition: a disappointing occasion that was not interesting, especially one that was expected to be exciting and important:
examples: The party turned out to be a non-event - barely anybody showed up.

meanings.definition: the lack of one or more reasons for believing that something is or is not true:
examples: The politician claimed that the article was inaccurate and based on non-evidence.
The skill of the detective is to distinguish between evidence and non-evidence.

meanings.definition: not limited to only one person or group of people, or to only one thing:
examples: The technology is licensed on a non-exclusive basis for use in a wide range of contexts.
The rights granted to the publisher for use of the image are non-exclusive.

meanings.definition: not limited to only one person or organization, or to one group of people or organizations:
examples: They have entered into a non-exclusive distribution agreement.
The licence grants them the non-exclusive right to use the technology in their products.

meanings.definition: relating to someone who gives advice to a company but does not make decisions:
examples: She resigned when she turned 60 and started a new career as a non-executive director of various companies.
He remained on the board in a non-executive, advisory capacity.

meanings.definition: someone, often in a high position, who gives advice to a company but does not make decisions:
examples: She agreed with her follow nonexecutives.
He will join the company next month as a non-executive.

meanings.definition: a member of a company's board of directors who is not one of the company's managers:
examples: Many non-executives believe they should have the last word on a company's mergers.
The days of the non-exec coming in for a monthly meeting, with a good lunch and a game of golf, are long gone.

meanings.definition: relating to a non-executive:
examples: Baker is to be non-executive chairman at Medeva.
a non-executive role/board seat/post

meanings.definition: one of a company's board of directors who is not one of the company's managers:
examples: She joins the Lloyds board on March 1 as a non-executive director.

meanings.definition: without special permission not to do or pay something, especially tax:
examples: In the event of bankruptcy, your non-exempt assets are liquidated to mitigate your debts.
Non-exempt competitors must successfully complete a qualifying round in order to take part in the finals.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that has to be done, paid, etc. because it is not one of the situations where a particular rule or law does not have to be obeyed:
examples: People going bankrupt sometimes try to prevent non-exempt assets being taken from them.

meanings.definition: Something that is non-existent does not exist or is not present in a particular place:
examples: Insurance payment for alternative healthcare is virtually non-existent.

meanings.definition: not exotic (= unusual or exciting because of coming, or seeming to come, from far away, especially a tropical country):
examples: He comes from a very non-exotic part of the city.
They have a large collection of non-exotic birds and animals.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is non-expendable, people cannot do something or deal with a situation without them:
examples: non-expendable property such as equipment and furniture
Some of the military personnel were classified as non-expendable.

meanings.definition: not relating to tests, especially scientific ones:
examples: The majority of studies were nonexperimental or observational in nature.
It would have been difficult to establish the cause using non-experimental methodologies.

meanings.definition: a person who does not have a high level of knowledge or skill relating to a particular subject or activity:
examples: The book was written with the non-expert in mind.
A work of art is viewed in one way by an expert and differently by a non-expert.

meanings.definition: not having or showing a lot of knowledge or skill:
examples: In my non-expert opinion, this change will be a good thing.
Even non-expert users can find the software very productive.

meanings.definition: not giving an explanation about something:
examples: They objected that they found such concepts unhelpful and non-explanatory.
Explanatory feedback has been proven to have a positive effect on learning outcomes compared with non-explanatory feedback.

meanings.definition: not using someone unfairly for your own advantage:
examples: The group promotes local food which has been produced in a sustainable and non-exploitative way.
How do we ­provide the world’s ­population with viable, nonexploitive sources of finance?
non-exploitive social and commercial organizations

meanings.definition: not exploding or able to explode easily:
examples: Although toxic, the chemicals are non-explosive.
The Navy were using non-explosive, hollow practice rounds during the training exercise.

meanings.definition: very old and no longer existing:
examples: There are a number of non-extant plays that we know were written by the playwright.
Reference is made to a non-extant letter from the 15th century.

meanings.definition: something that is said to be a fact but for which no proof exists or about which there is no information:
examples: The claims were shown to be based on a number of non-facts.
It has become difficult to distinguish fact from non-fact.

meanings.definition: a fact, situation, or person that does not influence the result of something:
examples: Are there deadlines for the completion of this project or is time a non-factor?
The storm was a non-factor in the poor service.

meanings.definition: not using or consisting of facts:
examples: He made a series of non-factual statements and produced no evidence to back up his claim.
The author said that she was giving up fiction because she didn't have time left for non-factual entertainment.

meanings.definition: Non-faculty employees work, but do not teach, at a school, college, or university:
examples: It takes the typical university about six non-faculty professionals to service each 100 students.
The school has cut 30 nonfaculty jobs in the most recent restructure.

meanings.definition: Non-faculty employees work, but do not teach, in a college or university faculty (= a group of departments that specialize in a particular subject or group of subjects).
not affecting several members of the same family:
examples: The syndrome is a non-familial congenital disorder.
The results may not be generalizable to milder forms of the illness or non-familial samples.

meanings.definition: not part of a particular family:
examples: Non-family members could not attend the funeral.
The company added its first nonfamily non-executive director to the board.

meanings.definition: not owned by, relating to, or consisting of a family or families:
examples: There are a growing number of non-family farming businesses.
Many visitors to the ancestry centre now come for non-family reasons.
the trend towards non-family, smaller households

meanings.definition: someone who does not admire and support a person, sport, sports team, etc. or who does not like something:
examples: His sister knows every song they have done but he's a non-fan.
She's a confirmed non-fan of raisins as she was once sick after eating them.

meanings.definition: not relating to farms or farming:
examples: Non-farm unemployment in the county was at an all-time high.
