meanings.definition: not related to or involved in farming:
examples: In May, non-farm employment in the state stood at 6 million.

meanings.definition: someone who does not own or take care of a farm:
examples: Both farmers and non-farmers have been buying land in the region.
The seed company also sells its products to non-farmers, although at a higher price.

meanings.definition: Non-fat food contains no fat:
examples: non-fat milk/yogurt

meanings.definition: A non-fatal illness, injury, or accident does not cause death:
examples: The infection is usually non-fatal if the patient gets treatment right away.
a non-fatal shooting/stabbing/heart attack

meanings.definition: Non-fattening food does not contain much fat, sugar, etc. that would quickly make you fatter if you ate a lot of it:
examples: It's a delicious, non-fattening alternative to butter.
There are nearly always nonfattening versions of normally high-calorie foods.

meanings.definition: not containing a lot of fat:
examples: Non-fatty foods can be dry if overcooked since all moisture either drips out or evaporates.
non-fatty tissue such as skin or muscle

meanings.definition: not relating to the central government of some countries such as the US:
examples: Non-federal public employees must apply to the state for assistance.
Virginia has 22.5 million acres of nonfederal land and 2.65 million acres in federal ownership.

meanings.definition: containing little or no iron:
examples: non-ferrous metals

meanings.definition: writing that is about real events and facts, rather than stories that have been invented

A non-figurative painting, drawing, etc. represents something in an abstract way (= using shapes, lines, and colour in a way that does not try to represent the appearance of people or things), rather than as it really looks:
examples: There has been a big increase in the popularity of non-figurative art.
These works are non-figurative, with shapes whose meaning is unknown, allowing the viewer to construct their own interpretation.
I need to know what I'm looking at in a painting, so anything nonfigurative just leaves me confused.

meanings.definition: not last, or not at the end of something:
examples: In this language, the verb is rarely in a non-final position.
This was an earlier, non-final version of the speech.
The study investigated the length of both nonfinal and final syllables.

meanings.definition: not relating to money or how money is managed:
examples: Non-financial incentives have proven much less effective than financial ones.
Couples also consider non-financial factors when deciding on when to retire.

meanings.definition: used to describe a company that is not a financial institution:
examples: The latest banking scandal has not affected industrial and other non-financial companies.

meanings.definition: a physical asset such as property or a machine, rather than money, shares, bonds, etc.:
examples: Through a program of cost cutting and the sale of non-financial assets, the bank has recovered from near-collapse.

meanings.definition: A non-finite verb is in the infinitive form or is a participle and does not show the tense and subject of the verb.
Something that is non-flammable cannot burn or is very difficult to burn.
Something that is non-flammable does not burn easily:
examples: Fortunately, the tanker that crashed was transporting non-flammable liquids.
The gas is non-flammable and widely used in manufacturing to reduce the likelihood of fire.
Following the tragic fire, new legislation was introduced to ensure the use of nonflammable building materials.

meanings.definition: A non-fluorescent light is not a very bright, tube-shaped electric light that is often used in offices:
examples: They don't use any non-fluorescent lamps in the building.
Non-fluorescent lighting is generally considered to provide a more natural form of light at consistent light levels.

meanings.definition: A non-fluorescent colour is not a fluorescent colour (= a very bright colour that can be seen in the dark):
examples: The T-shirts can be printed in a range of non-fluorescent colours.

meanings.definition: producing non-fluorescent colour:
examples: Any dye can be used with this material as long as it is nonfluorescent.

meanings.definition: A non-flying bird, insect, or animal is not able to fly:
examples: The flightless cormorant is the only example of a non-flying cormorant in the world.
Certain species of moth are wingless and hence non-flying.

meanings.definition: not travelling by or controlling an aircraft:
examples: Non-flying tourists are forced to take a 12-hour journey by ferry
Pilots have requested that they are paid for non-flying hours.

meanings.definition: not for eating, or relating to things that are not for eating:
examples: The biggest price increases came in non-food products and especially electrical goods
The supermarket has seen growth in the non-food area in particular.

meanings.definition: not food or not related to food:
examples: The supermarket chain has recently expanded to offer non-food items like books, clothing, and furniture.

meanings.definition: Non-formal language, clothes, and behaviour are suitable for occasions that are not serious or official:
examples: It's a shirt that can be worn on both formal and non-formal occasions.
The word is rarely found in non-formal usage.

meanings.definition: Non-formal education or training is not received in a school or college:
examples: There is a growing non-formal pre-school market.
This kind of education is non-formal and does not lead to a qualification.

meanings.definition: based on fact or good reasons, and having a chance of succeeding in law:
examples: The court ruled that the allegations were non-frivolous and hence a hearing would be held.
Any nonfrivolous appeal must be referred to a moderator for a final ruling.

meanings.definition: not turned to ice or preserved by freezing:
examples: They tried to find a non-frozen part of the lake in which to fish.
Some parents insist on only giving their children non-frozen, healthy food.

meanings.definition: not consisting of, used as, or relating to fuels (= substances that are used to provide heat or power, usually by being burned):
examples: The country is one of the world's biggest exporters of non-fuel minerals.
The airline's non-fuel running costs have almost doubled.

meanings.definition: a lack of pleasure and satisfaction because you are not happy with your life:
examples: After a lifetime of non-fulfilment, it was not surprising that he experienced bouts of rage.
The sense of non-fulfilment in her personal life contrasted with her very successful business career.

meanings.definition: the failure to do something that someone wanted you to do or that you promised to do:
examples: The group was protesting against the nonfulfilment of their demands.
They were fined for non-fulfilment of their contractual obligations.

meanings.definition: (of a machine, system etc.) not working, or not working in the correct or usual way:
examples: Any non-functional components should be returned to the supplier.
After prolonged and heavy use, the keyboard had become nonfunctional.

meanings.definition: not having a particular purpose:
examples: She is best known for her striking non-functional wall hangings.
A distinction can be made between functional requirements and nonfunctional requirements.

meanings.definition: (of a machine, system etc.) not working, or not working in the correct or usual way:
examples: Non-functioning traffic lights at the junction had caused the crash.
Following the break-in, the company was criticized for not maintaining the non-functioning security system.

meanings.definition: a unique unit of data (= the only one existing of its type) that links to a particular piece of digital art, music, video, etc. and that can be bought and sold :
examples: Non-fungible tokens are usually built using the same kind of programming as cryptocurrencies.
Nonfungible tokens are changing the way we own things digitally.

meanings.definition: (of wild animals) not hunted for food and sport, or relating to such animals:
examples: She studied non-game birds and especially birds of prey.
Conservation of both game and nongame species is extremely important.

meanings.definition: not relating to a particular competition, match, or occasion when people play a game:
examples: The stadium is available for hire on non-game days.
The club receives income from all food and drink sales at nongame events.

meanings.definition: not caused by or relating to genes (= parts of the DNA in cells) received by each animal or plant from its parents:
examples: Genetic and non-genetic factors have been identified to have roles in the incidence of dementia.
The cause is believed to be non-genetic in the majority of cases.

meanings.definition: not involving or affecting the outer sexual organs, especially the penis or vulva:
examples: It is not commonly known that a number of sexually transmitted diseases are non-genital.
The virus can cause genital and non-genital warts, amongst other symptoms.

meanings.definition: not glamorous (= especially attractive and exciting):
examples: She has deliberately chosen to take on non-glamorous roles.
Working as a carpark attendant may be a non-glamorous occupation, but he feels good about earning a salary.

meanings.definition: designed to prevent unpleasantly bright or strong light shining off something:
examples: Non-glare lighting was installed throughout the warehouse following complaints from staff.
The non-glare display and generous keyboard of the laptop make it really comfortable to use.

meanings.definition: a person who does not play golf as a hobby:
examples: Her husband was a confirmed non-golfer so she played with someone she met at the resort.
Even non-golfers have found this year's Open competition fascinating.

meanings.definition: not part of or controlled by the government:
examples: Non-government agencies are needed if we are to really help these people.
We work with non-government organizations that have similar objectives to our own.

meanings.definition: not part of or controlled by the government:
examples: a nongovernmental health agencies

meanings.definition: not related to or controlled by a government:
examples: At the moment, we recommend investment in non-governmental securities.
The campaign includes nongovernmental groups like Oxfam.

meanings.definition: an organization that tries to achieve social or political aims but is not controlled by a government
A non-gradable adjective or adverb is one that cannot be used in the comparative or superlative, or that cannot be qualified by words such as 'very' or 'quite'.
(of a piece of work or test) not given a score:
examples: They believe that it is important that assessments should be non-graded as it encourages inclusiveness.

meanings.definition: (of a school class) not divided into different groups by age or ability:
examples: The local government believed strongly in the benefits of nongraded schools.
In a non-graded school, children of all ages and abilities are taught in the same classroom.

meanings.definition: a person who does not have a degree from a university or college, or, in the US, a diploma from a high school :
examples: Whilst a degree is no guarantee of a job, there is no doubt that if you have one, it gives you an enormous advantage over a non-graduate.
Even graduates with first-class degrees are having to take non-graduate jobs.

meanings.definition: not relating to grammar (= the rules about how words change their form and combine with other words to make sentences) or not obeying the rules of grammar:
examples: Some grammatical aspects of a language are learnt at the same rate as non-grammatical elements.
The system has been trained to detect non-grammatical constructions and suggest corrections.

meanings.definition: not made of, consisting of, or seeming like granules (= small pieces like grains):
examples: The substance was used in a non-granular form in the experiment.
The paste had a pleasant non-granular texture.

meanings.definition: not relating to gravity (= the force that makes things fall to the ground) or gravitation (= the force that attracts objects towards one another):
examples: non-gravitational fields of study, such as electromagnetism

meanings.definition: not covered with or full of fat or oil:
examples: The body lotion is a non-greasy cream that is easily absorbed and leaves the skin soft and silky.
The product claims to be the natural way to nongreasy hair.

meanings.definition: not increasing in size or quantity:
examples: This type of tumour is a slow growing, sometimes non-growing, one.

meanings.definition: lack of any increase in size or quantity:
examples: The period of non-growth in the economy has now lasted for 10 years.

meanings.definition: used to describe a financial product that a company sells without promising a particular level of profit:
examples: Income payments on a non-guaranteed annuity depend on the insurance company's investment expertise.

meanings.definition: not relating to the destruction of blood cells:
examples: Acute non-haemolytic febrile reactions were common in patients who had multiple transfusions.

meanings.definition: the fact of something not happening, or an occasion when something does not happen:
examples: The probability of the non-happening of the event was estimated as low.
The company cannot be held responsible for any events, non-happenings, omissions, or incidents beyond their reasonable control.

meanings.definition: Non-hardy plants cannot live through the winter without protection from the weather:
examples: You will need to bring any non-hardy plants into a greenhouse on very frosty nights if they are to survive.
Non-hardy perennials such as marigolds, delphiniums, and petunias can be successfully grown if a few simple precautions are taken.

meanings.definition: not relating to harmony (= a pleasant musical sound made by different notes being played or sung at the same time):
examples: The non-harmonic sound on his new album has disappointed many of his long-term fans.

meanings.definition: not consisting of a special note that sounds when a musical note is played that is different from the main note:
examples: Non-harmonic tones, also called embellishing tones, are notes that do not fit with the chord in question.

meanings.definition: not dangerous:
examples: Non-hazardous industrial waste can often be recycled and used as a raw material.
Water levels in the flooded area have now fallen to a non-hazardous level.

US spelling of
        
         non-haemolytic
not hierarchical (= arranged according to the level of importance of people or things, or relating to such a system):
examples: The company has chosen to adopt a non-hierarchical structure in order to encourage innovation.

meanings.definition: not from or connected with Spanish-speaking countries, especially those in Latin America, or not having parents or grandparents from these countries:
examples: Non-Hispanic white people make up 80% of the population.

meanings.definition: a person who is not from, or whose parents and grandparents are not from, a Spanish-speaking country, especially one in Latin America:

meanings.definition: not connected with studying or representing things from the past:

meanings.definition: cancer that starts in one or more lymph nodes or the spleen and spreads to any part of the body, often the liver and bone marrow
not used as or in a home, or not happening in or relating to a home:

These kinds of textiles are specialist ones for non-home use only.

meanings.definition: not relating to hormones (= any of various chemicals made by living cells that influence the development, growth, sex, etc. of an animal and are carried around the body in the blood):
examples: Some women may want to consider non-hormonal remedies to treat the symptoms of menopause-related conditions.
You are advised to use a non-hormonal method of contraception.

meanings.definition: not relating to or happening in a hospital:
examples: More nurses are choosing to go into non-hospital work.

meanings.definition: not unfriendly:
examples: Her non-hostile reaction to the criticism was widely praised.

meanings.definition: not difficult, or suitable for living and growing:
examples: These plants will flourish if grown in a non-hostile environment.

meanings.definition: not connected with the enemy in a war:
examples: Almost a quarter of fatalities happened in non-hostile circumstances.

meanings.definition: relating to situations in which one company wants to buy another company whose owners are willing to sell it:
examples: The bank said that they would support the company in their purchase as long as the approach was non-hostile.

meanings.definition: not relating to buildings for people to live in:
examples: The authority's non-housing budget has increased by 7%.

meanings.definition: a person or animal that does not hunt animals for food or sport:
examples: The council issued a warning to non-hunters that the hunting season was about to begin.

meanings.definition: not involved in or relating to hunting (= chasing and killing animals for food, sport, or profit):
examples: The organization has been working closely with non-hunting groups to improve animal welfare.
They built a number of refuges in the forest during the non-hunting season.

meanings.definition: not hysterical (= unable to control your feelings or behaviour because you are extremely frightened, angry, excited, etc.):
examples: The book was a sober, non-hysterical review of the sensitive subject.

meanings.definition: not perfect or the best possible:
examples: The team performed poorly in non-ideal conditions of a slippery pitch with many bare patches.
They have persevered with the nonideal method and had some success.

meanings.definition: not exactly the same as someone or something else:
examples: Legally, a draft or non-identical copy is a separate document.
It would look better if the houses had non-identical porches but the developer uses a builder that mass-produces only a certain number of styles.

meanings.definition: (of children born to the same mother on the same occasion) not looking exactly the same because they developed from separate eggs:
examples: It was the first successful ovarian tissue transplant between two non-identical sisters.
Doctors believe she is expecting triplets and a non-identical brother.

meanings.definition: a twin (= either of two children born to the same mother on the same occasion) who do not look exactly the same because they developed from two separate eggs:
examples: She had a family history of non-identical twins.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being the same:
examples: The non-identity between the two products was established after lengthy analysis.
Non-identity exists between the two terms at a semantic level.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being, or not feeling that you are, a particular type of person, organization, etc.:
examples: She talked about women's social identity, or rather non-identity.
The non-identity is the hardest part of being the first restaurant of a fast-food chain.

meanings.definition: not ideological (= based on or relating to a particular set of ideas or beliefs):
examples: She is determined that the story is covered in a non-ideological way.

meanings.definition: not relating to or containing an image (= picture):
examples: Non-image files must be stored separately from image files.

meanings.definition: not copying someone or something:
examples: Despite all the time that she spent with the other artists, she used colour in a unique, non-imitative way.
At this point in history, music was largely non-imitative.

meanings.definition: not protected against a particular disease by particular substances in the blood:
examples: Once diagnosed, malaria must be treated quickly,as non-immune individuals can die within 48 hours.
It is a notoriously infectious disease and will spread rapidly among those who are non-immune.

meanings.definition: not involving the force of one object hitting another:
examples: She was recommended to take up non-impact sports such as swimming or cycling following her accident.

meanings.definition: the fact of not including someone or something as part of a group, list, etc.:
examples: The outstanding issue is the inclusion or non-inclusion of the smaller piece of land in the agreement.

meanings.definition: not becoming larger in amount or size:
examples: Throughout the article, the author has preferred the words increasing to non-decreasing and decreasing to non-increasing.
The sequence is non-negative and non-increasing.

meanings.definition: not officially having the named position now, or at a particular time that is being referred to:
examples: A non-incumbent presidential candidate is often at a disadvantage.
Compared to non-incumbent teams, incumbent campaign teams are better at predicting vote share and the final outcome.

meanings.definition: someone who does not have a particular official position now, or at a particular time that is being referred to:
examples: Non-incumbents have traditionally been more successful than incumbents in the election.
She was the first woman elected to the post as a non-incumbent.

meanings.definition: not born in, living in, or coming from India:
examples: They stayed at a hotel in Delhi that caters to non-Indian tourists.
The non-Indian players in the cricket team now outnumber the Indians.

meanings.definition: not belonging to one of the groups of people who were living in North and South America before Europeans arrived :

In the period 1806 to 1807, the entire non-Indian population of Texas was around 7,000.

meanings.definition: someone who was not born in India or does not live there or come from there:
examples: While Sikhism started in India, many non-Indians have converted to Sikhism.
He became one of the first nonIndians to head a leading company on the subcontinent.

meanings.definition: someone who is not a member of one of the groups of people who were living in North and South America before Europeans arrived:
examples: Some Native American spiritual leaders have spoken against excluding non-Indians from sacred, traditional ceremonies.
When the nation police arrest a nonIndian on tribal land, they have to turn him over to a sheriff's deputy.

meanings.definition: used to refer to, or relating to, people who have moved to a place from somewhere else, rather than the people who originally lived there:
examples: Indigenous and non-indigenous people joined together to celebrate the historic event.
Although the tunes are ancient, the music is now often played with non-indigenous instruments.

meanings.definition: used to refer to plants and animals that have been brought to a place from somewhere else, rather than those that grow or live there naturally:
examples: This variety of snake is non-indigenous to the region.
The importing of non-indigenous wildlife poses numerous threats to the park's ecosystem.

meanings.definition: foreign or from outside an area:
examples: Joint ventures with non-indigenous corporations are now encouraged.
They think that non-indigenous competitors should be excluded from the market in order to promote local businesses.

meanings.definition: not relating to a single, separate person or thing:
examples: According to the privacy policy, non-personal data is collected on a non-individual basis.
The contract makes provision for what happens if there is a non-individual beneficiary.

meanings.definition: not one of the group of European and Asian languages that are spoken in most of Europe and in parts of Asia and that include English, French, Greek, Russian, and Hindi, or not speaking one of these languages:
examples: The most widely spoken non-Indo-European language in Europe is Hungarian.
It is known that an ancient, non-Indo-European people were living in the region at this time.

meanings.definition: not relating to industry, or not having a lot of industry and factories:
examples: Non-industrial societies are more vulnerable to severe weather events.
Non-industrial areas in the south of the country have seen a boom in tourism.

meanings.definition: not having developed a lot of industry:
examples: Recent investment has begun to transform this previously non-industrialized country.
Child mortality rates, historically very high, have begun to fall in non-industrialized nations in the region.

meanings.definition: not relating to one particular type of business:
examples: The committee had a balance of industry and non-industry members.
Non-industry outsiders can often add a valuable new perspective.

meanings.definition: not relating to the production of goods for sale, especially in factories:
examples: Many activities carried out by non-industry sectors of the economy contribute to industrial output.

meanings.definition: not having a particular disease caused by a virus, bacteria, or parasite (= an insect that feeds on a person):
examples: The non-infected population is still much larger than those who have been infected.
Patients were classified as non-infected or infected according to a set of detailed criteria.

meanings.definition: not containing or affected by bacteria that can cause disease:
examples: There has been an increase in cases of non-infected glue ear.
The majority of noninfected foot ulcers do not require surgery.

meanings.definition: (of a disease) not able to be passed from one person, animal, or plant to another:
examples: The public awareness campaign focused on chronic, non-infectious diseases such as cancer and heart disease.
A fever may be present in both infectious and non-infectious conditions.

meanings.definition: not able to pass on a disease:
examples: All such patients must be placed in isolation until they are confirmed to be non-infectious.
Non-infectious cases were treated in a separate part of the hospital.

separate rather than combined with something else:
examples: Running two parallel, non-integrated accounting systems caused numerous problems.
The hundreds of websites, all non-integrated, mean that maintaining a uniform marketing message is hard.

meanings.definition: separate from the society of a place :
examples: There was a large non-integrated community of migrant workers in the region.

meanings.definition: Non-integrated schools, areas, etc. keep people of different races, or people with different religious beliefs, apart. :
examples: The non-integrated school system has been a source of embarrassment for the government.

meanings.definition: not related to or not paying interest (= money that is paid to a person or organization that lends money):
examples: The company's non-interest income for the year increased by 50 percent over last year.
The money was kept in a non-interest checking account.

meanings.definition: the feeling of not being interested in something:
examples: I fear they might have taken my lack of response to their idea for non-interest.
She made clear her non-interest in continuing guitar lessons.

meanings.definition: not related to the interest that a company, bank, etc. makes on money they have lent:
examples: The bank is increasing its non-interest income through brokerage and other services.

meanings.definition: a policy of not trying to stop something or not involving yourself in something that another person, country, etc. is trying to do:
examples: The Pact included an agreement of mutual non-interference among its member states.
The country pledged non-interference in the domestic affairs of its neighbour.
The school administrators opted for non-interference in the classroom and allowed teachers to choose their own lesson plans.

meanings.definition: not meeting or crossing one another:
examples: Fill in the non-intersecting sections of these circles.
non-intersecting lines
two nonintersecting planes

meanings.definition: not including any of the same members:
examples: the non-intersecting subsets of all even numbers and all odd numbers

The staff work in three non-intersecting departments: marketing, manufacturing, and financial.

meanings.definition: the practice of refusing to get involved in a situation, especially in a disagreement between countries or within a country:
examples: a policy of non-intervention

meanings.definition: not making you feel nervous or afraid to try something:
examples: The gym owners tried to provide a friendly, non-intimidating environment for its members.
So far I've found the software user-friendly and nonintimidating.

meanings.definition: a substance, drink, etc. that does not contain a drug such as alcohol:
examples: The cool box contains soda, juice, and other non-intoxicants for people who do not wish to drink alcohol.
The shop was granted a licence to sell food and non-intoxicants.

meanings.definition: not able to make you drunk or make you feel the influence of a drug:
examples: Only non-intoxicating beverages were allowed inside the park.
CBD is a non-intoxicating compound that is found in cannabis.
The campers warmed themselves with hot cocoa and non-intoxicating cider.

meanings.definition: not causing someone to feel uncomfortable by getting too close to them, asking them for information they do not want to reveal, etc.:
examples: The police detective asked a few non-intrusive questions to each member of the victim's family.

meanings.definition: not easy to use or learn, especially without any special training or practice:
examples: For first-time users, the software can seem unfriendly and nonintuitive.
The puzzles were too non-intuitive to be done within the short time limit.

meanings.definition: not what you would expect based on beliefs or feelings, although maybe true in fact:
examples: For some, these conclusions may seem so nonintuitive that they must be wrong.
The loss of animal species can have some dramatic and non-intuitive consequences for human communities.

meanings.definition: relating to any medical test or treatment that does not cut the skin or enter any of the body spaces:
examples: a non-invasive test
a non-invasive procedure

meanings.definition: in a way that that does not cut the skin or enter any of the body spaces in a medical test or treatment:
examples: Thanks to MRI technology, doctors are able to examine the brain non-invasively.
This new technical solution allows hospitals to measure patients' haemoglobin levels non-invasively.
The settings can be modified noninvasively, with no need for a further operation.

meanings.definition: not related to investing:
examples: The government promised to cut non-investment spending by 4.75%.

meanings.definition: used to describe bonds, etc. with a high risk of not being paid back:
examples: Don't buy non-investment grade or 'junk' bonds unless you're willing to risk losing your money.

meanings.definition: not causing an ion to be formed:
examples: radio waves and other forms of non-ionizing radiation
a non-ionizing electromagnetic field
Radiation is non-ionizing when no electrons are removed from the atom to create an ion.

meanings.definition: not treated with light or other types of radiation:
examples: Do you notice any difference in flavour between irradiated and non-irradiated herbs and spices?
non-irradiated bone marrow
The patient was given non-irradiated blood plasma following the kidney transplant.

meanings.definition: not supplied with water taken from another place, for example by pipes or hoses, for growing crops and plants:
examples: The drought caused serious damage to many non-irrigated cornfields.
Most of the farmland in that part of the state is non-irrigated.
Sorghum grows well even in dry, non-irrigated soil.

meanings.definition: not causing pain or soreness:
examples: The soap contains natural ingredients that are non-toxic and non-irritant.
Unlike other brands, this lotion contains only one type of nonirritant sunscreen.

meanings.definition: not causing pain or soreness:
examples: The bicycle shorts were made of a non-irritating fabric that allowed for movement.
The hair removal cream is supposed to be non-irritating.
The company makes a non-irritating razor with a strip of aloe along the blade for sensitive skin.

meanings.definition: someone who does not wish to become a member of an organization or who does not like to get involved in activities with groups of people:
examples: A nonjoiner by habit, Annette turned down an invitation to go on a walk with the other students.
A lot of introverted people tend to be non-joiners.

meanings.definition: If a person or thing is non-judgmental, they do not judge or criticize:
examples: a non-judgmental book/counsellor
The organization provides a 24 hour, non-judgmental listening service for people who are considering suicide.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not judgmental (= too quick to criticize people):
examples: Her advice was to treat all the bad behaviour you experience as non-judgmentally as possible.
Parents are encouraged to listen non-judgmentally to what their children have to say.
However hard I try, I just can't think of them nonjudgmentally.

meanings.definition: not capable of being decided by law or a court:
examples: cases deemed nonjusticiable by the Supreme Court
The District Court held that his claim was non-justiciable.
The court ruled that the case presented a nonjusticiable political question.

meanings.definition: (of food, places where food is sold, or methods of preparing food) not allowed by Jewish law or not following the rules of Jewish law:
examples: The delicatessen claims that it doesn't sell any nonkosher foods.
The butcher's keeps its kosher and non-kosher meats in separate freezers.

meanings.definition: (of a person, family, etc.) not following the rules of Jewish law about which types of food can be eaten, and about how to prepare and store food:
examples: There are plenty of options on the menu for nonkosher diners.
Our daughter's friend was visiting for dinner, and we wanted to make sure he was comfortable eating in our non-kosher home.

meanings.definition: not related to people who work at a job, for an organization, etc., or to the money that is paid for this work:
examples: Given other non-labor costs, the city cannot rebalance its expenditures without restructuring labor costs.
The company is looking for nonlabor savings.

meanings.definition: someone who does not own any land:
examples: It is hard to do research on non-landowners from the past since they are often not listed on city property records.
A servant of the squire in 1542, he lived in modest circumstances, as a non-landowner with only £7 in goods.

meanings.definition: not relating to speaking or learning a language:
examples: Many of our students choose to study one language and one non-language subject.
tests of language and non-language ability

meanings.definition: not using words to communicate something:
examples: Winking, grinning, and other non-language forms of expression can communicate a lot of information to another person.

meanings.definition: sounds, movements, or other forms of communication that do not include words, or do not have meaning:
examples: The actors improvise using prepared nonlanguage.
He dismissed most politicians' utterances as "non-language".

meanings.definition: a person who is not a lawyer:
examples: She was the only non-lawyer on the eight-member panel.
As a nonlawyer, he will rely on expert legal advice.
Non-lawyer police officers often find themselves up against experienced defence counsel.

meanings.definition: not containing lead or coated with lead:
examples: The newer houses in the neighbourhood have exteriors coated in non-leaded paint.
non-leaded crystal champagne glasses

meanings.definition: (of a team, etc.) not belonging to one of a country's main professional leagues (= groups of sports teams who compete against each other):
examples: For a non-league team to beat Chelsea was an amazing result.
He has visited many small non-league football grounds.

meanings.definition: not taking place within or belonging to the same league (= a group of teams who compete against each other) :
examples: They have a nonleague game scheduled for next week against a team visiting from upstate.

meanings.definition: not working or trained in the law:
examples: The workshop is aimed at both a legal and non-legal audience.
Barristers and solicitors have strict ethical standards which do not apply to non-legal staff.

meanings.definition: without using the law or having a court case:
examples: A non-legal, technological solution may be best way to tackle software piracy.

meanings.definition: not according to the law:
examples: Pension benefits could not be transferred to non-legal spouses.

meanings.definition: a plant that is not a legume (= a plant such as a bean or pea, that has its seeds in a pod):
examples: Rotating legumes and non-legumes will help to sustain the nutrients in the soil and keep it fertile.
Quinoa is a broadleaf non-legume that is grown for grain.

meanings.definition: related to a plant that is not a legume and does not have its seeds in a pod:
examples: non-leguminous crops such as cereals
Nitrogen is usually the main limiting factor for yield in nonleguminous grains.

meanings.definition: not able or likely to cause death:
examples: The department armed its officers with nonlethal weapons.
He was struck by a round of non-lethal ammunition.

meanings.definition: not relating to words and their meanings, especially as included in a dictionary:
examples: The editors added thousands of non-lexical items to the dictionary, including biographical and geographical entries.
For ease of reading, repetitions, pauses, and non-lexical utterances (ums, uh huhs) have been excluded.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a librarian (= a person who works in a library and helps people find books, information, etc.):
examples: The university has positions open for both librarians and non-librarians.
Even the nonlibrarians on the staff are well versed in the Dewey Decimal System.

meanings.definition: not related to or belonging to a library:
examples: This computer is set aside for non-library use, but the others will allow you to access the catalog.
Any nonlibrary sources that are consulted as part of your research must be approved by the teacher in advance.

meanings.definition: not related to life insurance:
examples: The insurance company said non-life business accounted for 62% of its overall income.

meanings.definition: not relating to the members of a person's family who are directly related to them; not relating to a person's children, their parents, or their parents' parents:
examples: Single people are more vulnerable in old age as few people are willing to take care of non-lineal relatives.

meanings.definition: used to describe a process, series of events, etc. in which one thing does not clearly or directly follow from another:
examples: a non-linear career path/system/narrative
Researchers say that nonlinear thinking may be an increasingly important attribute for tomorrow's workers.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving words or language:
examples: Non-linguistic elements in conversation include sounds, gestures and facial expressions.
She has remarkable non-linguistic communicative skills.
Any adequate theory of meaning must address both linguistic and non-linguistic behaviourbehavior.

meanings.definition: not consisting of money or something that can be bought or sold for money easily:
examples: They offer flat-fee services to clients whose wealth is tied up in non-liquid assets, such as a business or real estate.

meanings.definition: not in the form of a liquid (= a substance, such as water, that is not a solid or a gas and can be poured easily):
examples: Most world cuisines use metric weights for non-liquid ingredients and metric volumes for liquids.

meanings.definition: not understanding or intending a word or phrase in its original, basic meaning:
examples: The imagery suggests narratives in an abstract, nonliteral way.
He is a liberal Christian who takes a non-literal, modern approach to the Bible.

meanings.definition: not connected with or typical of written artistic works, especially those that are considered to have a high and lasting artistic value:
examples: The author originally had a nonliterary career in mind: she wanted to be a ballerina.
The way in which a work is constructed may define it as literary or non-literary.

meanings.definition: not alive or having life:
examples: In tree bark, older tissue is pushed outward, forming a thick coat of non-living cells.
Plants obviously do not have minds; nor do nonliving things like tables and rocks.

meanings.definition: not found within, coming from, or relating to a small area, especially of a country:
examples: Non-local attendees to the arts festival spend significantly more than local attendees, according to the report.
A large number of items made of nonlocal materials were found at the archaeological site.

meanings.definition: not using reason:
examples: He claims that intuitive, non-logical thinking is a function of the right hemisphere of the brain.
These emotions are powerful and non-logical, but they are the result of social experience.

meanings.definition: not relating to logic (= a formal scientific method of examining or thinking about ideas):
examples: These symbols are often called nonlogical constants.
logical and non-logical symbols

meanings.definition: not producing or reflecting bright light:
examples: A planet is a nonluminous body gravitationally bound to the Sun or a star.
If we place a wire-gauze cap over the gas jet, it burns with a non-luminous flame.

meanings.definition: (of a metal object or material) not able to attract objects or materials containing iron or steel:
examples: In the experiment, half the participants had strong magnets, while the rest had non-magnetic metal bars.

meanings.definition: not able to be attracted by a magnet (= an object that is able to attract iron and steel objects):
examples: The metal detector is able to detect firearms in magnetic and non-magnetic metals and mixed alloys.
A copper rod is used because it is a nonmagnetic material.

meanings.definition: not having, using, or following the ideas, beliefs, etc. that are accepted by most people or being among the things that are liked or preferred by most people:
examples: The arts centre screens non-mainstream and non-English-language films.
People here are not very tolerant of nonmainstream views.

meanings.definition: not among the biggest, most important, or most serious of its type:
examples: What is the risk level of nonmajor surgery in healthy people aged over 60?
non-major banks/airlines

meanings.definition: A non-major student is one who is not taking a particular subject as their main subject of study:
examples: Non-major students take English modules as a compulsory requirement.

meanings.definition: a student who takes a class in a subject that is not their main area of study:
examples: I teach non-majors a class in Environmental Biology.
a physics textbook for nonmajors

meanings.definition: a sports competition, especially in golf or tennis, that is not among those considered the most important or at the highest level :
examples: He won three nonmajors but fell short of qualifying for the US Open.

meanings.definition: not likely to be harmful and especially not related to cancer:
examples: The usual cause of the disease is a nonmalignant tumour on the pituitary gland at the base of the brain.
The consultant had told him that the growth was non-malignant.

meanings.definition: not able to be easily changed into a new shape or made to do something different from what is usual:
examples: Cast iron is non-malleable at room temperature, while wrought iron can be shaped at room temperature for different purposes.
Personality traits are generally considered to be stable and non-malleable.

meanings.definition: not relating to, belonging to, or being a mammal:
examples: Non-mammalian vertebrates include fish, birds, amphibians, and reptiles.
Soya beans are an important source of non-mammalian protein.

meanings.definition: not relating to, being, or belonging to the people who are in charge of a business, organization, etc.:
examples: The measure made it easier for non-management employees to be fired for poor performance.
After taking into account inflation, the average weekly earnings for workers in nonmanagement jobs actually fell.

meanings.definition: not relating to a manager or management:
examples: During that time, the average income for non-managerial workers rose about 7 percent.
The union representative organized a meeting with the company's nonmanagerial staff.
She is retiring at the end of October but will still hold a non-managerial role with the company.

meanings.definition: not working with the hands or relating to work done with the hands:
examples: Manual workers are shown to have higher rates of absenteeism than non-manual employees.
The risk of heart disease is greater among men employed in non-manual jobs than those who do manual labour.

meanings.definition: not related to manufacturing (= the business of producing goods in large numbers):
examples: Over 200,000 jobs were created over the past year, most of them in non-manufacturing industries.
The company revealed plans to cut up to 10 per cent of nonmanufacturing jobs.
a non-manufacturing company/business

meanings.definition: used to describe an activity that does not involve making products:
examples: Profits in the non-manufacturing sector, particularly at banks and other service-related industries, are still headed downward.

meanings.definition: not relating to marriage; taking place between people who are not married:
examples: As more people put off getting married, studies show an increase in non-marital cohabitation.
They were in a nonmarital romantic relationship for six years.
The decade saw an increase in non-marital births.

meanings.definition: not relating to or influenced by the demand of people to buy certain things or the supply of things to be bought:
examples: The cartel uses fixed, non-market pricing to keep the consumption of energy resources stable.
Universities are non-market institutions that help us develop and exchange ideas.
He is convinced that non-market solutions are needed to battle climate change.

meanings.definition: not able to be traded after being sold:
examples: non-marketable securities

meanings.definition: not relating to or expressing belief in Marxism (= a social, political, and economic theory that is based on the writings of Karl Marx):
examples: Non-Marxist writers say they want to be apolitical, while Marxists claim that “neutral” statements are equally political.
Non-Marxist feminists do not believe that women would necessarily be free in a different economic system.
His writings offer a non-Marxist approach to explaining the crisis.

meanings.definition: a person who does not express belief in Marxism (= a social, political, and economic theory that is based on the writings of Karl Marx):
examples: The Left is often affected by fierce divisions between Marxists and non-Marxists.
His writings have been the subject of frequent criticism from Marxists and non-Marxists alike.
She cites the work of eminent non-Marxists such as Tolstoy and Ruskin.

meanings.definition: not relating to physical objects or money:
examples: Influence is to do with non-material power.
A service is the non-material equivalent of a good.

meanings.definition: not existing in a physical form:
examples: ghostly non-material beings
Personhood isn’t actually vested in something material, but resides in something non-material such as a soul.

meanings.definition: relating to the emotions:
examples: People also need to have their non-material needs met.

meanings.definition: not consisting of or connected with money or physical objects:
examples: He is now at a stage of life where non-material, spiritual satisfaction becomes more important.

meanings.definition: not believing that having money and possessions is the most important thing in life:
examples: The religious man lived a simple and nonmaterialistic life.
He criticized the actor for preaching a non-materialistic philosophy while enjoying all of the comfortable amenities of life.

meanings.definition: not relating to mathematics:
examples: People tend to believe that there are mathematical minds and nonmathematical minds, but he questions this.
Readers with nonmathematical backgrounds will appreciate that the book mostly avoids technical explanations.
The process of assessing penalties in court is mostly nonmathematical and unscientific.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a mathematician (= someone who studies, teaches, or is an expert in mathematics):
examples: Fermat’s Last Theorem is a conjecture of number theory known even to some non-mathematicians.
The report uses a complicated statistical analysis that is too difficult to explain to any nonmathematician.

meanings.definition: not formally admitted to study at a university or college:
examples: He spent a semester at the University of Iowa as a non-matriculated student.
She attended the college on a non-matriculated basis.
You can take non-matriculated classes at the city university.

meanings.definition: not having or intended to show a meaning or purpose:
examples: If you don't know the words to the song you can just sing non-meaningful syllables in their place.
They studied mothers' responses to their young children's non-meaningful utterances.

meanings.definition: not able to be measured:
examples: The last snowfall left only trace, non-measurable amounts and no accumulation.
If the switch to higher-octane petrol had any effect on the car's performance, it was so small as to be nonmeasurable.

meanings.definition: containing no meat or nothing made from meat:
examples: It was the best non-meat burger I've ever eaten.
She has been on a nonmeat diet for the past six months.
Do you have any alternative dishes for non-meat eaters?

meanings.definition: not involving a machine or made to work like a machine:
examples: The most common non-mechanical causes for ambulance crashes are collisions with obstacles such as lampposts and other cars.
Only nonmechanical garden tools were available for loan.

meanings.definition: not relating to doctors, medicine, or treatment for a disease or condition:
examples: Doctors recommend against taking the drug for non-medical reasons.
Some in-home care assistants also perform non-medical services such as house cleaning and meal preparation.

meanings.definition: a person or thing that is not a member of an organization or group:
examples: Admission to the park is £10 for members and £20 for non-members.
This was the first time that the country had held a state funeral for a non-member of the royal family.
The event is open to non-members.
You can save more than 40% off the nonmember price.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that has not officially joined a particular group:
examples: The club's function room can be hired by non-members for €100.

meanings.definition: the state of not being a member of an organization or group:
examples: In the UK, it is illegal to discriminate against employees on the basis of their membership or non-membership of a trade union.
The writer was required to prove his non-membership of the Communist Party.
Non-membership in a religious or community group could raise mortality risk in older people, the study found.

meanings.definition: (of an organization) not open only to members:
examples: The charity is a nonmembership organisation whose services are made available to anyone who needs them.

meanings.definition: not relating to the mind:
examples: Poor mental health is also associated with higher rates of non-mental health related illness.
When we think about our neural processes, we consider our brains as non-mental things.

meanings.definition: not relating to or containing mercury (= a silver metal that is liquid at room temperature):
examples: The patient was prescribed a non-mercurial diuretic.
The paper concerned the mercurial and non-mercurial treatment of the disease syphilis.

meanings.definition: a chemical element that is not a metal
not containing or expressed using a metaphor (= language or an image that describes a person or object by referring to something that is similar to that person or object):
examples: We faced a nonmetaphorical uphill climb to reach our destination.
Financial bubbles are just as prone to bursting as non-metaphorical bubbles.

meanings.definition: not using a system of measurement that uses metres, centimetres, litres, etc.:
examples: The use of both metric and non-metric units in the same article was confusing.
In recording distances, we add non-metric equivalents for the convenience of our readers.

meanings.definition: not written in metre (= the regular arrangement of syllables in poetry according to the number and type of beats in a line):
examples: She made her debut with a twenty-line poem written in non-metrical verse.
Walt Whitman is considered one of the first American masters of nonmetrical poetry.

meanings.definition: not located in or near a large city, or related to people who do not live in or near a large city:
examples: Agriculture in the form of corn, soya beans, and cattle raising is the chief industry for most of the state's nonmetro counties.
It has been estimated that 150,000 people move from metro areas to non-metro areas annually.

meanings.definition: not located in or near a large city, or related to people who do not live in or near a large city:
examples: Most of the voters who support the proposal live in non-metropolitan communities.
It seemed that many urban elites were out of touch with how non-metropolitan people lived.

meanings.definition: a county (= area with its own local government) of England that does not include a large city:
examples: Suffolk is a non-metropolitan county of historic origin in East Anglia, England.

meanings.definition: not made up of or caused by microbes (= very small living things, especially ones that cause disease):
examples: She spent a summer at an oceanographic institute studying non-microbial life forms.
The test came back negative, leading the doctor to believe that her infection had a nonmicrobial cause.

meanings.definition: a person that is not a migrant (= someone who travels to a different country or place, often in order to find work):
examples: Although the children were non-migrants, they were born to parents who had immigrated from Slovenia 30 years ago.
Migrant workers are eligible for membership in the union with the same rights as non-migrant workers.
nonmigrant religious groups

meanings.definition: an animal that does not migrate (= travel regularly to a different place, usually when the season changes):
examples: The birds they studied were non-migrants that were able to remain throughout the colder winter season.
The Galapagos fur seal is classified as a non-migrant species, even though there have been reported sightings on the mainland of Central America.

meanings.definition: A non-migratory bird or animal is one that does not migrate (= travel to a different place, usually when the season changes):
examples: Non-migratory monarch butterflies tend to live for only a few weeks.
This particular hawk is a non-migratory species that is found only in certain parts of the western United States.
Because they are nonmigratory, some birds and mammals must collect and store a cache of food in order to survive a long and harsh winter.

meanings.definition: not preferring to use violence or force to achieve something:
examples: As an ardent feminist, she was nonmilitant in her principles, preferring to defend women's rights with words and ideas.
His cousin was a non-militant activist who employed peaceful methods of protest as a way to draw attention to the injustices of the world.

meanings.definition: not part of an army or other group that is fighting a war:
examples: The fighting was done in a desert far from the city, and as a result there were few non-militant casualties.
The region's nonmilitant population consisted mostly of farmers, peasants, and clerics.

meanings.definition: not involving the military or being a member of the military:
examples: Non-military contractors were evacuated from the war zone.
The only cuts were made to non-military spending.
The legislature voted to send £5 billion in nonmilitary aid to the struggling country.
The air attacks led to the destruction of several non-military targets.

meanings.definition: not representing something, especially in art, by copying it exactly as it appears:
examples: His paintings have nonmimetic elements that make no allusion to works from the past.
The stage sets featured non-mimetic rooms that were still hyper-realistic.

meanings.definition: A non-mimetic organism is one that does not look or act like something else in nature, especially as a way to hide or disguise itself :
examples: Insects whose genes produce non-mimetic patterns on their wings are more likely to be spotted and detected by predators.
The male swallowtail butterfly has a non-mimetic wing pattern, in contrast to the female, which imitates that of toxic species to ward off predators.

meanings.definition: a person who does not belong to a minority (= any small group in society that is different from the rest because of their race, religion, or political beliefs):
examples: Over 80 percent of the respondents identified as non-minorities.
They strive to provide equal opportunities for minorities and non-minorities.

meanings.definition: not belonging to a minority (= any small group in society that is different from the rest because of their race, religion, or political beliefs):
examples: The professor felt that non-minority students tended to dominate the conversation in the classroom.

meanings.definition: not moving; not able to move or be moved from one place to another:
examples: A non-mobile structure housed the temporary classroom while the main school building was being renovated.
Nurses and medical staff use special devices to transport nonmobile patients.
The toddler learned to walk around the nursery and figured out how to snatch toys from the non-mobile babies.

meanings.definition: not relating to or using a mobile phone:
examples: The report presented an analysis of mobile versus non-mobile web traffic.
The app can be used on both mobile and non-mobile platforms.
People with smartphones are more active on social media than non-mobile users.

meanings.definition: not relating to or made up of molecules (= the simplest units of a chemical substance):
examples: Sand is made of silica, which is a non-molecular compound of silicon and oxygen.
Quartz and diamond are two examples of a nonmolecular crystal solid.

meanings.definition: not relating to money or consisting of money:
examples: Aside from the good pay, the job brings with it a lot of non-monetary benefits.
Some of the non-monetary assets, such as stocks, might need to be liquidated or sold before they can be transferred.
We made a non-monetary donation to the charity.

meanings.definition: not relating to money or consisting of money:
examples: Use this form to report any non-money income you received during the fiscal year.
So much of the economy is driven by nonmoney factors such as supply of goods and the happiness of the workforce.
Some people might choose to convert their non-money savings into cash.

meanings.definition: used to describe assets that are not in the form of money:
examples: People in developing countries sometimes store their savings in non-money ways.

meanings.definition: having or relating to the practice of having sexual or romantic relationships with two or more people at the same time:
examples: He is in a non-monogamous relationship.
She and her husband were nonmonogamous the first year they were dating.

meanings.definition: (especially of plants, organisms, and very small forms of life) not able to move by itself:
examples: As most plants are non-motile, they rely on pollination by insects or the wind to reproduce.
Nonmotile forms of the microbe lack a flagellum to propel them through water.

meanings.definition: not using an engine or motor to move:
examples: She gets around in a non-motorised wheelchair.
The lake is open to all forms of non-motorized recreation.
The area was opened to the public for cycling, jogging, horse riding and other nonmotorised sports.

meanings.definition: not moving or not able to move:
examples: We were sitting in non-moving traffic for twenty minutes.
The camera lens seemed to work better when shooting a nonmoving subject.

meanings.definition: relating to a vehicle that is parked or not being driven:
examples: He was fined for a nonmoving violation because his car had improper seat belts.

meanings.definition: relating to the side of a court case that did not ask for the case to be brought:
examples: Cases of doubt or ambiguity are viewed by the court in the way most favorable to the non-moving party.

meanings.definition: not owned or managed by the local government of a town or city:
examples: The country club is the only non-municipal golf course in the area.
Elections for mayor and town council are held in odd-numbered years while nonmunicipal elections are held in even-numbered years.

meanings.definition: not consisting of or relating to music:
examples: The streaming service also offers non-music content, such as podcasts.
Many nonmusic students still enjoy singing in the campus choir or performing in the varsity band.

meanings.definition: not relating to or using music:
examples: Many of the orchestra's members have non-musical day jobs.
The variety show included a good number of nonmusical acts, such as jugglers and stand-up comics.

meanings.definition: not sounding pleasant, like music:
examples: We heard the nonmusical clatter of dishes being washed in the kitchen.
I rang the bell, which gave a dull, non-musical sound.

meanings.definition: not interested or skilled in music:
examples: He grew up in a non-musical family and didn't start playing the guitar until he was in college.
Although she had been considered a nonmusical person all her life, she was drawn to the drums.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a musician:
examples: He writes about the technical aspects of classical music in a way that makes an enjoyable read for non-musicians.
The popular video game gives a nonmusician a chance to imagine what it's like to be a rock star.

meanings.definition: not caused by or showing the effects of a mutation (= a permanent change in an organism):
examples: Some versions of the flower included an extra ring of petals that nonmutant versions of the flower lacked.
The 12 control subjects had the non-mutant version of the gene.
The non-mutant gene does not cause the cultured cells to become cancerous.

meanings.definition: not in the form of a narrative (= a story or a description of a series of events):
examples: The non-narrative film was made of a series of short vignettes that explored the theme of separation.
The book consists of paragraphs of nonnarrative writing linked together, forming a cohesive whole.
She choreographs dances that are nonnarrative but evocative.

meanings.definition: not belonging to or relating to a nation:
examples: Despite having "American" in its name, the doctors' association is a non-national organization.
The group is avowedly nonnational, with no expressed loyalty or ties to any particular government.
The data showed an increase in visits to non-national museums across the United Kingdom.

meanings.definition: A non-native plant or animal is one that lives or grows in a place where it did not originally live or grow:
examples: The river was stocked with a nonnative species of trout that is now preying on other fish.
The beetle is a non-native insect responsible for destroying entire groves of ash trees.

meanings.definition: A non-native person is one who was not born in the place where they currently live or who did not learn the language that is spoken there as their first language:
examples: The census results showed an increase in the number of non-native residents in the state.
The author provided a glossary that translated some of the local lingo for non-native readers.

meanings.definition: not belonging or relating to an indigenous group of people (= the people who originally lived in a place, usually before Europeans came), especially a Native North American or South American people:
examples: She said it was offensive for non-Native people to wear Native American headdresses as a costume.
Navajo artists began weaving baskets and blankets that featured wry depictions of daily life, Native, and non-Native people.

meanings.definition: someone who has learned a particular language as a child or adult rather than as a baby :
examples: dictionaries for non-native speakers of English

meanings.definition: not relating to or caused by things that occur in nature:
examples: Accidents and suicide are among the leading non-natural causes of death.
She wore special contact lenses that turned her eyes a nonnatural shade of green.

meanings.definition: the state of not being needed:
examples: At the end of her letter, she indicated the non-necessity of sending a reply.

meanings.definition: something that is not needed:
examples: Please pack light and avoid filling your bags with non-necessities.

meanings.definition: not caused by or guilty of negligence (= the fact of not giving enough care or attention to people or things that are your responsibility):
examples: The driver who struck and killed the pedestrian was charged with nonnegligent manslaughter.
The court concluded that a non-negligent subcontractor had no duty to indemnify for damages or pay costs.

meanings.definition: Something that is non-negotiable cannot be changed by discussion:
examples: The terms of this agreement are non-negotiable.

meanings.definition: A non-negotiable cheque cannot be exchanged for money and must be paid into a bank account.
A non-negotiable financial product cannot be bought and sold:
examples: Time deposits are non-negotiable deposits that are maintained in a bank for a specified period of time.

meanings.definition: used to describe a financial product that cannot be traded:
examples: Time deposits are non-negotiable deposits that are maintained in a bank for a specified period of time.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that someone refuses to discuss or change:
examples: Talks failed because there were too many non-negotiable issues on both sides.
The buyout offers are nonnegotiable.

meanings.definition: not connected to or part of a network:
examples: You will need a portable drive if you wish to transfer the file to a non-network computer.
He controls 60 non-network broadcast television stations across the country.

meanings.definition: A non-network doctor or hospital is not automatically included as part of someone's health insurance, so they have to pay for some or all of it themselves:
examples: Once stabilized at a non-network hospital, the patient may be transferred to a network hospital.
My dermatologist is non-network, so appointments cost a lot.

meanings.definition: not relating to the system of nerves in the body:
examples: The tests revealed abnormalities in the motor neurons as well as in the non-neural cells that surrounded them.
The embryo develops a temporary non-neural outer layer called the ectoderm.

meanings.definition: something that is not news or not worth being reported as news:
examples: The celebrities' 72-hour marriage was non-news, the wedding a joke performed merely as a public relations stunt.
The front page was full of non-news and no useful information.

meanings.definition: consisting of or concerned with things that are not news:
examples: The radio station plays jazz and classical music and airs other non-news programming on the weekends.
She won a Top Photographer award in the category of non-news photography.

meanings.definition: not containing the element nitrogen:
examples: There were noticeable differences in the health and fruitfulness of the plants that grew in nitrogenous soil versus those that grew in non-nitrogenous soil.
Renal failure can result in the retention of nitrogenous and non-nitrogenous waste products that are normally excreted by the kidneys.

meanings.definition: not relating to what is considered the usual or normal way for people to look, act, or behave:
examples: The study discusses the connections between the creation of norms and the legal punishment of non-normative behaviour.
The clothes are sold in a broad range of sizes and cuts to accommodate people with nonnormative body types.

meanings.definition: not new or different:
examples: The critic felt the film to be a stale and nonnovel artistic work that didn't say anything new.
The game had a non-novel concept with many similar elements to games that have been seen before.

meanings.definition: (of a cell) not having a nucleus (= a central part that controls its growth):
examples: A prokaryote is a non-nucleated single-celled organism of which bacteria are the most common type.
The genetic material of non-nucleated microbes is usually contained within the cytoplasm.

meanings.definition: non-operating income does not come from a business's main activities, but from other activities such as selling assets:
examples: We have asked them for details of their non-operating income such as investments in other companies.
Net income includes a non-operating after tax gain of approximately $93,000.

meanings.definition: shares in a company that pay a fixed rate of interest rather than a share of the company's profit:
examples: With non-participating shares you do not have the right to a share in surplus profits.

meanings.definition: not a member of or connected with a group or political party:
examples: a non-partisan organization/voter/watchdog group

meanings.definition: not involving or related to a political party:
examples: The government intends to hold non-party elections to the new bodies.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who is not directly involved in a legal agreement or disagreement:
examples: Disinterested, non-party trustees will be very important in resolving this matter.

meanings.definition: A non-paying person does not pay for something:
examples: The piano teacher accepted her as a non-paying pupil.
The play was first performed to a few non-paying special guests.

meanings.definition: a failure to pay money that is owed:
examples: non-payment of taxes

meanings.definition: the fact of not paying or being paid a sum of money that is owed:
examples: The law banned water companies from disconnecting customers for non-payment of bills.
Consider taking out insurance against non-payment.

meanings.definition: a failure to do a piece of work or an activity:
examples: They were sued for non-performance of services.
There is a valid excuse for the nonperformance of the work.

meanings.definition: a person who does not perform as an actor, singer, dancer, or musician:
examples: He was voted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a non-performer.
The award is open to musicians and also nonperformers who have had an influence on American music.

meanings.definition: someone or something that does not perform well:
examples: We try to sort out the good workers from the non-performers.
She thinks that I am a nonperformer who is only good at making excuses.

meanings.definition: used to describe a loan that is not being paid back in the way that was agreed:
examples: Banks do not have to declare loans as non-performing for a year after non-payment of interest.

meanings.definition: used to describe a business activity, asset, etc. that is not making a profit:
examples: They are restructuring and selling off non-performing assets.

meanings.definition: not allowing or encouraging a particular thing to happen:
examples: The cells will stop growing when the non-permissive temperature is reached.
The microbes were still able to survive under non-permissive growth conditions.

meanings.definition: not relating or belonging to a single or particular person:
examples: Non-personal communications had little effect on the behaviour of patients.
You will need to ask for permission if you want to make copies for non-personal use.

meanings.definition: not consisting of or involving petroleum (= a dark, thick oil obtained from under the ground):
examples: In the future, most cars will run on non-petroleum fuel.
The government is encouraging firms to develop non-petroleum fuel products.

meanings.definition: a person who does not study philosophy (= the use of reason in understanding such things as the nature of the real world and existence, the use and limits of knowledge, and the principles of moral judgment):
examples: I discussed what I had been learning with a friend who is a non-philosopher.
This book will probably not be interesting to a nonphilosopher.

meanings.definition: not relating to the study or writing of philosophy (= the use of reason in understanding such things as the nature of the real world and existence, the use and limits of knowledge, and the principles of moral judgment):
examples: He is one of the few modern philosophers who are also famous in non-philosophical circles.
Philosophers should be able to express their ideas in such a way that a reasonably intelligent non-philosophical person can understand them.

meanings.definition: A spelling system can be described as non-phonetic if you cannot always understand how words are pronounced simply by looking at their spelling:
examples: The non-phonetic nature of English can made it a hard language to learn.
He was struggling to master the difficulties of the non-phonetic spelling system.

meanings.definition: not containing any phosphates (= chemicals that contain the element phosphorus):
examples: Supermarkets are now stocking non-phosphate detergents.
We have a large research team that is working to develop a non-phosphate formula.

meanings.definition: not relating to, used for, or produced by photography:
examples: Some countries now use non-photographic forms of identification.
She is more famous for her photography than for her non-photographic work.

meanings.definition: not relating to or using the body:
examples: Most of the students had experienced some form of nonphysical harassment.
Because of my back trouble I can only do non-physical work.

meanings.definition: relating to things that you cannot see or touch:
examples: The goodwill of our customers is a non-physical asset.
I am more impressed by non-physical qualities such as kindness and courage.

meanings.definition: relating to mammals such as marsupials whose babies, which are not fully developed at birth, continue to develop outside the mother's uterus
having a surface that is not flat or level in all directions:
examples: The vehicle was driven over a slightly non-planar terrain.
This technology can be used to form nonplanar images.

meanings.definition: not made of plastic:
examples: We will deliver the paper to your home in a non-plastic covering.
After stirring, transfer the mixture to a non-plastic serving dish.

meanings.definition: not taking part in a game or sport:
examples: He travelled to Hungary as a non-playing member of the team.
She was later appointed non-playing captain of the American ladies' team.

meanings.definition: not relating to poetry or poets:
examples: The book uses material from a wide variety of poetic and non-poetic sources.
She published eight books of verse as well as some non-poetic fiction.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a substance whose molecules do not have opposite positive and negative poles
not a member of the police:
examples: Some of these jobs could be done by non-police staff.
The court heard statements that victims had given at the scene to doctors and other non-police officers.

meanings.definition: not having or expressing an opinion about politics:
examples: I am non-political and do not support either of the candidates.
We tried very hard to make sure that the event was nonpolitical.

meanings.definition: not relating to politics:
examples: Recently, historians have paid more attention to the non-political aspects of the conflict.
There are several reasons for this regulatory activity, some political and some non-political.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not relate to politics:
examples: The boundary between the two regions must be established transparently and non-politically.
The songs that they performed were non-politically patriotic.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a member of a government or law-making organization:
examples: Many of guests who appear on the show are non-politicians.
Even non-politicians usually have strong views about education.

meanings.definition: not causing pollution:
examples: We must develop new non-polluting sources of energy.
The speaker urged us all to use non-polluting methods of transport.

meanings.definition: Non-poor people have enough money and possessions that they are not considered to be poor, although they may not be rich:
examples: We are now targeting nonpoor customers.
Only a quarter of households in the area are non-poor.

meanings.definition: the fact that you do not have or own something:
examples: They were prosecuted for non-possession of a driving licence.
In this country you can be sent to jail for nonpossession of a valid identity document.

meanings.definition: relating to ideas or imagination rather than experience, real situations, or actions:
examples: Traditional education involved learning a lot of non-practical stuff.
I don't usually read non-practical books.

meanings.definition: involving writing or talking rather than doing things:
examples: The class sizes for non-practical subjects have steadily increased.
I got a high score on the non-practical part of the test.

meanings.definition: not actively involved in a religion:
examples: He and his wife are both non-practising Muslims.
There are many nonpractising Christians living in the community.

meanings.definition: trained to do a type of work but not doing it at the present time:
examples: Some of the hospital administrators are non-practising doctors.
We want to encourage non-practising teachers to come back to work.

meanings.definition: relating to the practice of lending money, especially to buy a house, to people who may not be able to pay it back:
examples: Typically, non-prime loans are made to people with a low credit score and cost the borrower more.
About 25% of mortgage holders in Louisiana are considered nonprime.

meanings.definition: a bill of exchange (= document ordering someone to pay a particular amount for goods or services) that is thought to be at risk of not being paid and is therefore sold for a lower price
a number that is not a prime number (= a number that cannot be divided by any other number except itself and the number 1):
examples: Non-prime numbers are divisible by more than two numbers.
Any non prime number can be written as a product of prime numbers.
Euclid called nonprime numbers "composites."

meanings.definition: Non-print newspapers, books, magazines, and documents are read using a computer rather than on paper:
