examples: Her new book is only available as a non-print publication.
I encourage my students to make use of both print and nonprint sources.

meanings.definition: a situation, person, or thing that does not need attention, although some people might think that it does:
examples: The best way to deal with a non-problem is to do nothing.
Why are we wasting all this time and money on a non-problem?

meanings.definition: A non-problem child, family, etc. is not considered to have problems with their behaviour, mental or physical health, etc.:
examples: We studied the differences between children with emotional problems and non-problem children.
Non-problem gamblers are able to stop before they lose too much money.

meanings.definition: not making or creating a particular thing:
examples: The owners earn nothing from a nonproducing oil well.
Some growers do not supply any water to non-producing trees.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who does something not as their job but because they are interested in it:
examples: There are certain indicators that signal an upturn that may not be obvious to non-professional investors.

meanings.definition: used to describe a job that does not need a high level of training or education:
examples: The company gave special bonuses to its nonprofessional staff.

meanings.definition: not intended to make a profit, but to make money for a social or political purpose or to provide a service that people need:
examples: We are a non-profit organization dedicated to the conservation of ocean mammals.

meanings.definition: an organization whose aim is to make money for a social or political purpose or to provide a service that people need, rather than to make a profit

→ 
        
         non-profit
not a member or part of an official programme (= an officially organized plan or system):
examples: The incomes in villages that joined the scheme were higher than incomes in non-programme villages.
Eighty percent of programme group members graduated, compared with fifty percent of the nonprogramme group.

meanings.definition: a person who is not able to write computer programs:
examples: The system is quite easy for a non-programmer to use.
Even a non-programmer would find this talk entertaining.

meanings.definition: (of a medical condition) not continuing to develop; not becoming worse or more serious:
examples: It is a non-progressive disorder, so the damage will not get any worse.
Some diseases can remain nonprogressive for years.

meanings.definition: not supporting or encouraging change in society or in the way that things are done:
examples: The non-progressive parties have done well in the recent elections.
I would not want to live in such a non-progressive society.

meanings.definition: A non-progressive form of a verb is one that shows that the action is no longer continuing:
examples: In English, stative verbs (= verbs that describe a state rather than an action) are non-progressive.
English grammar has a progressive aspect and a non-progressive aspect.

meanings.definition: the controlling of the spread and/or amount of something, especially nuclear or chemical weapons:
examples: a non-proliferation treaty

meanings.definition: Nonproprietary goods do not have the name of a particular company on them:
examples: The drug is better known by its non-proprietary name.
We should only use widely available, nonproprietary systems.

meanings.definition: not relating to the study or treatment of mental illness:
examples: She works in a general, non-psychiatric hospital.
Nonpsychiatric doctors sometimes make the mistake of seeing this as evidence of psychiatric illness.

meanings.definition: a person, especially a doctor, who is not trained in psychiatry (= the study of mental illness):
examples: She is being treated by a non-psychiatrist.
Many of the patients in the unit were initially diagnosed by a non-psychiatrist.

meanings.definition: not relating to the human mind and feelings:
examples: Some apparently psychological states such as panic or anxiety can be triggered by non-psychological factors, such as ingested toxins.
The author has tried to analyse human identity in nonpsychological terms.

meanings.definition: not suffering from psychosis (= a severe mental condition that makes someone believe things that are not real):
examples: Even small amounts of the drug are dangerous to non-psychotic people.

meanings.definition: limited to a particular person or group of people rather than being available to everyone:
examples: We have put strong measures in place to safeguard your nonpublic information.
We shall store this information in a non-public area.

meanings.definition: not provided by the government from taxes to be available to everyone:
examples: Their children are enrolled in a nonpublic school.
The rules do not apply to non-public building projects.

meanings.definition: not involving punishment, or not intended as a punishment:
examples: There is a voluntary, non-punitive system for reporting near-misses.
They prefer to use non-punitive measures for preventing crime.

meanings.definition: not done with the aim of achieving a particular thing:
examples: She regards the state as a non-purposive, rule-based institution.
He believes that evolution occurs through a variety of nonpurposive mechanisms.

meanings.definition: not able to be measured:
examples: The new technology can also bring nonquantifiable benefits for both patients and staff.
The lecture also discusses the more general and non-quantifiable ways in which social policy can affect economic growth.

meanings.definition: not relating to numbers or amounts:
examples: Computers are not good at handling non-quantitative information.
The method is non-quantitative and so cannot be used to create a ranking order.

meanings.definition: not influenced by a person's race:
examples: We're a non-sexist and non-racist employer.

meanings.definition: not relating to railways:
examples: The museum has plans to loan the locomotive to a non-railway organization.
He had a new non-railway job at a power company.

meanings.definition: A non-rated investment does not have a rating (= a score) that tells people, companies, or countries how safe it is:
examples: Most of the portfolio is invested in low-grade and non-rated bonds.
Investing in non-rated securities means that you are more at risk of losing your money.

meanings.definition: not involving clear thought and reason:
examples: A rational person can make a fortune by exploiting the non-rational choices of others.
People have become increasingly attracted by superstition and other forms of non-rational thinking.

meanings.definition: not like something that really exists or happens, especially when this is an intentional feature of the style of something such as a film or story:
examples: She likes to include narrative elements of a non-realistic, fairytale nature.
They established a new theatre company to experiment with nonrealistic styles of drama.

meanings.definition: the fact of not receiving money or goods:
examples: Unfortunately, we cannot accept liability for non-receipt of goods ordered.
Most of the complaints we receive concern either slow delivery or nonreceipt of the product.

meanings.definition: A non-reciprocal action or arrangement involves two people or groups of people who do not behave in the same way to each other:
examples: The nonreciprocal system of tariffs is designed to benefit developing countries.
The actors in the play are in a non-reciprocal relationship with the audience.

meanings.definition: the fact of not agreeing that something is true or legal:
examples: Indigenous people were protesting against the non-recognition of their laws and culture.
The government tried to remain in power despite almost universal non-recognition of its legitimacy.

meanings.definition: the fact of not knowing that you have seen, heard, or experienced someone or something before:
examples: People would just walk past, exhibiting complete non-recognition.
The students we surveyed reported total nonrecognition of both words.

meanings.definition: used to describe a loan in which the lender has the right to take only the asset bought with the loan if it is not paid back, and does not have the right to take any other assets:
examples: They financed the $1.2 million purchase with a non-recourse loan.

meanings.definition: used to describe a payment, debt, etc. that cannot be got back:
examples: a non-recoverable down-payment

meanings.definition: used to describe charges that do not happen regularly:
examples: Profit was $482 million after accounting for non-recurring charges of $305 million.
Officials discussed the issue of non-recurring imports, such as the 10 airplanes Malaysia Airlines took delivery on this year.

meanings.definition: If a product is non-recyclable, you cannot use it again after it has been used because you cannot treat it in order to produce useful materials:
examples: The council has discussed a plan to charge for the collection of non-recyclable rubbish.
We must stop buying goods that come in nonrecyclable packaging.

meanings.definition: not adding one or more electrons to another substance:
examples: Non-reducing sugars are less harmful to cells and tissues than other sugars.
We tested for the presence of the acid under non-reducing conditions.

meanings.definition: A container that is non-refillable cannot be filled again when the liquid inside has been used:
examples: There is an additional customs duty on non-refillable cigarette lighters.
You can sell milk in cardboard cartons even if they are non-refillable.

meanings.definition: A non-reflecting surface does not send back light that shines on it:
examples: The room contained a huge cabinet with trophies and newspaper clippings locked behind nonreflecting glass.
Her new computer is housed in a non-reflecting black case.

meanings.definition: the practice of not sending refugees or asylum seekers (= people trying to escape war, danger, threats, etc. in their own country) back to their country or to another country where they are likely to suffer bad treatment:
examples: The principle of non-refoulement is that a refugee must not be repatriated when there is likely danger of persecution.
The article argues that non-refoulement forms a part of customary international law.

meanings.definition: used to describe money that you pay that you cannot get back:
examples: At this point, the purchaser will have to pay a 10% non-refundable cash deposit to the auctioneer.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that you cannot return after you have bought it:
examples: The check-in desks close 40 minutes prior to departure, so if you're late, you're stuck with a nonrefundable ticket.

meanings.definition: A non-regulated type of business or activity is not controlled by rules or laws:
examples: We are operating in a non-regulated business environment.
The government has promised to review the activities of nonregulated lenders.

meanings.definition: used to describe businesses, services, agreements, etc. that do not have to obey official rules:
examples: Non-regulated products and services: please note that the Financial Services Authority does not regulate all of the products featured on the website.

meanings.definition: a lack of official rules for controlling something:
examples: He supports the non-regulation of the financial sector.
For years the government has been following a policy of non-regulation.

meanings.definition: not following the rules or the usual way of doing things:
examples: She was disqualified for using non-regulation equipment.
He led his force into battle wearing a non-regulation cap.

meanings.definition: not connected with what is happening or being discussed:
examples: I would like to block all non-relevant emails from my inbox.
Some non-relevant information has been removed from the example.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving religion:
examples: I prefer to send non-religious cards at Christmas.
They decided to have a non-religious marriage ceremony.

meanings.definition: not having a belief in a god or gods:
examples: She grew up in a non-religious family.
Almost all the people who post on this forum are non-religious.

meanings.definition: existing in limited quantities that cannot be replaced after they have all been used:
examples: Oil, natural gas, and coal are non-renewable fuels.

meanings.definition: If an official document or agreement is non-renewable, its use cannot be continued for an extra period of time after it has ended:
examples: Foreign workers bringing dependents could obtain only one non-renewable two-year visa.

meanings.definition: relating to materials, etc. that are not able to be replaced:
examples: Green power is displacing power that would have come from a non-renewable source.

meanings.definition: if an agreement or an official document is non-renewable, its use cannot be continued for an extra period of time:
examples: This contract is valid for a period of two years, and is non-renewable.

meanings.definition: types of energy that cannot be replaced after they have been used:
examples: Fossil fuels are nonrenewable energy sources.

meanings.definition: the fact of not making an official document, agreement, or rule continue for an extra period of time after it has finished:
examples: Some of the savings will come from non-renewal of contracts.
Non-renewals have increased following the change in regulations.

meanings.definition: If an amount of money is non-repayable, you do not have to pay it back:
examples: The loan is interest-free and effectively non-repayable.
Students on low incomes qualify for a non-repayable bursary.

meanings.definition: (of a style of art) not showing things as they are usually seen:
examples: His first non-representational work was Madrigal, in which he conveyed emotion through coloured rectangles, triangles and diamonds.
I am in no way opposed to non-representational and conceptual artworks.

meanings.definition: not typical of, or the same as, others in a larger group of people or things:
examples: Using volunteers is almost certain to produce a non-representative sample.
This piece is monotonous and non-representative of her music.

meanings.definition: A non-representative system of government is one in which people do not vote for politicians to represent them:
examples: These unelected officials have become a permanent non-representative government.
We are living in a non-representative dictatorship.

meanings.definition: not staying or living at a place:
examples: His claim for nonresidency in the country, in an attempt to avoid tax, was rejected.
There was a feeling of resentment among some voters about the candidate's non-residency in the area.

meanings.definition: a person who is not staying or living in or at a place:
examples: The hotel bar is open to non-residents.
Non-residents pay higher tuition fees.

meanings.definition: not staying or living in or at a place:
examples: During the summer the town has a large non-resident population of holidaymakers.
One of the women has a non-resident boyfriend.

meanings.definition: a person who does not live permanently in a particular country and who is in a special position in relation to the payment of tax:
examples: The UK income tax liability of a non-resident is subject to an upper limit.

meanings.definition: a person who is not staying at or living in a place, for example a hotel:
examples: The hotel wellness centre is open to non-residents.

meanings.definition: not living permanently in a country, and in a special position in relation to the payment of tax:
examples: You must be non-resident for five tax years to escape UK capital gains tax.

meanings.definition: not staying at or living in a place:
examples: There are over 20 million non-resident Indians living in different regions of the world.
non-resident owners of vacation properties

meanings.definition: A non-residential building is one that people do not live in:
examples: The architect is best known for designing non-residential buildings.
Spending on non-residential property fell in the first part of the year.

meanings.definition: A non-residential road, area, etc. has only offices, factories, shops, etc., not private houses:
examples: The factory is situated in a non-residential area.
Nightclubs are only allowed to operate in non-residential neighbourhoods.

meanings.definition: A non-residential job, position, course, etc. is one for which you do not live at the same place where you work or study:
examples: We are looking for people to do non-residential work in the wildlife park.
This year's summer school will be non-residential.

meanings.definition: used to describe a building, etc. that is not used for people to live in:
examples: Construction of non-residential property such as new office buildings is increasing.

meanings.definition: a non-residential course or job is one that you do not live at but which you travel to every day:
examples: This is a five-day residential or non-residential course offered at our training centre in London.

meanings.definition: a person who does not answer a request for information:
examples: All of the non-respondents were sent a second request one week later.
The people who responded to the survey had a higher average income than the non-respondents.

meanings.definition: a person who does not answer a request for information:
examples: Sixty of the people we surveyed were non-responders.
We sent out a reminder to all the non-responders.

meanings.definition: an ill person who does not begin to get better when they are given treatment:
examples: She is a nonresponder to aspirin.
If the patient is a non-responder, the therapy should be stopped.

meanings.definition: a failure to give an answer or reaction:
examples: I think your non-response to my question is extremely rude.
The information from the survey is flawed because of the high rates of non-response.

meanings.definition: not working or reacting to changes, instructions, etc.:
examples: An attacker could cause an affected system to become non-responsive.
No selling company will survive with an inferior product, unjustifiably high prices, or a non-responsive supply chain.

meanings.definition: not answering a question:
examples: He was non-responsive when court staff inquired as to his purpose for being there.
I got what I consider to be offensive, non-responsive answers.

meanings.definition: not able to be cured or helped by a treatment:
examples: An acute, non-responsive leukemia claimed his life.
Her pain was described as excruciating, and was non-responsive to most traditional analgesic drugs.

meanings.definition: not reacting in any way when spoken to, shaken, etc. because of being unconscious or very ill:
examples: A cardiac arrest is an unexpected collapse in an individual who is non-responsive.
The 1-month-old elephant calf became non-responsive, and staff members were unable to revive him.

meanings.definition: not limited by official rules, laws, etc.:
examples: I have non-restricted access to the site.
You can get a nonrestricted licence at the age of sixteen.

meanings.definition: A non-restricted area is one that you do not need official permission to enter:
examples: Security at nonrestricted airports is much less strict.
The café is situated in the non-restricted area between the check-in counters and the departure hall.

meanings.definition: not limiting the freedom of someone, or the size or meaning of something:
examples: The advice about wearing a face covering was very broad and non-restrictive.
A non-restrictive clause in English should never start with "that".
The church takes a commendably nonrestrictive view about who can attend its events, which has helped to build a strong sense of community.

meanings.definition: Something that is non-returnable cannot be returned:
examples: a non-returnable deposit
These bottles are non-returnable.

meanings.definition: If something is non-reversible, it cannot be changed back to what it was before:
examples: The child has a non-reversible form of deafness.
Evolution is a non-reversible process.

meanings.definition: not involved in or relating to a revolution (= a complete change in the way a country is governed, often involving violence or war):
examples: The group is committed to non-revolutionary action to achieve social equality.
Some bosses wanted to encourage moderate and nonrevolutionary trade unionism.

meanings.definition: able to be bent or moved; not stiff or fixed:
examples: These airships have non-rigid frames.
Most of the manufacturers sell their products in nonrigid bags.

meanings.definition: not turning in a circle around a fixed point:
examples: The main part of the machine consists of a large, non-rotating cylinder.
It must be in a nonrotating state before you can change from one mode to another.

meanings.definition: not part of a system that changes things according to a regular pattern:
examples: Two of the restaurant's non-rotating dishes are vegan.
The team was selected on a non-rotating basis.

meanings.definition: special or unusual, rather than part of what usually happens:
examples: She still needs help with many non-routine tasks.
The insurer will pay for all your nonroutine expenses.

meanings.definition: not belonging or connected to a king or queen or a member of their family:
examples: He was the first non-royal president of the organization.
This house is probably the finest non-royal building in the city.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a member of the family of a king or queen:
examples: She was the first non-royal to appear on her country's postage stamps.
He was the only non-royal who was present at the meeting.

meanings.definition: not being in control of a country, society, etc.; not making the decisions about how a country, society, etc. is run:
examples: These women were part of a non-ruling elite.
The majority of the population belongs to the non-ruling class.

meanings.definition: an animal that is not a ruminant (= one such as a cow, that brings up food from its stomach and crushes it again with its teeth):
examples: Pigs and elephants are non-ruminants.
Most non-ruminants digest less than half of what they eat.

meanings.definition: A non-ruminant animal is not an animal such as a cow, that brings up food from its stomach and crushes it again with its teeth:
examples: These seeds can be poisonous to nonruminant animals.
The disease is less common in non-ruminant species such as horses and zebras.

meanings.definition: not belonging to or relating to Russia, its people, or its language:
examples: Half of the team's players hold non-Russian passports.
The book is very challenging for non-Russian readers.

meanings.definition: a person who is not from Russia:
examples: There were only two non-Russians in the cast.
Most Russian art is bought by non-Russians.

meanings.definition: not containing salt:
examples: These plants thrive in well-drained, non-saline soil.
There is increasing competition among the farmers in the region for supplies of non-saline water.

meanings.definition: not suffering from or relating to schizophrenia (= a serious mental illness):
examples: The group contained five schizophrenic patients and five non-schizophrenic patients.
Some of the people she treated had initially been diagnosed with non-schizophrenic disorders.

meanings.definition: not belonging or connected to a school:
examples: Many of the kids go to non-school clubs.
There are lots of non-school activities that children can get involved in.

meanings.definition: referring to the time when children do not go to school:
examples: She is only available during non-school hours.
You are allowed to work for up to seven hours on a non-school day.

meanings.definition: a person who does not study or work in one of the sciences:
examples: She sets out her argument clearly so that even a nonscientist can follow it.
It is not easy for a non-scientist to understand this discussion.

meanings.definition: relating to or happening during the whole of the year rather than in a particular part of it:
examples: She is affected by non-seasonal depression.
Another 500 nonseasonal jobs were created last month.

meanings.definition: not connected with any specific religion:
examples: About 1,500 students attend 23 non-sectarian private schools.

meanings.definition: not kept separate or treated differently according to race, sex, religion, etc.:
examples: They had plans to set up a non-segregated school.
She enjoys working in a relaxed, nonsegregated environment.

meanings.definition: not kept separate from something else:
examples: You should segregate your waste properly because non-segregated waste may not be possible to recycle.
The depot provides non-segregated storage.

meanings.definition: the policy of not keeping one group of people apart from another because of race, sex, or religion:
examples: The laws of the state require the non-segregation of schools.
I am in favour of the non-segregation of our young people.

meanings.definition: A non-selected person or thing has not been chosen to take part in an activity or to be used:
examples: The non-selected players always wish the team good luck for the game.
The nonselected areas are coloured red so that the selected area is easy to view.

meanings.definition: A non-selective school is one which any child can go to, without having to pass an examination first:
examples: All children in the Netherlands go to non-selective primary schools.
We believe that education should be free and non-selective.

meanings.definition: affecting everything rather than only particular things:
examples: The soil was sprayed with a nonselective weedkiller.
Insecticide sprays are nonselective, killing almost all insects, both adults and larvae.

meanings.definition: A country or an area that is non-self-governing is not controlled by the people living there:
examples: Local people are dissatisfied with the colony’s non-self-governing status.
Tokelau is a non-self-governing territory that is under the administration of New Zealand.

meanings.definition: not trying to be shocking or exciting:
examples: The filmmakers were looking for ways to treat the topic in non-sensational manner.
Most of the newpapers gave non-sensational reports of the trial.

meanings.definition: A non-sensitive subject, situation, etc. does not need to be dealt with carefully or kept private, because it is not likely to upset people or cause embarrassment:
examples: This part of the network is used to store non-sensitive files.
All consumers should be able to review their nonsensitive data.

meanings.definition: a group of words that does not form a complete sentence:
examples: The first chapter of the novel begins with a pretentious non-sentence.
Nearly all the comments are written in non-sentence format.

meanings.definition: not following a particular order, or not following one after the other in order:
examples: The material can be accessed in a non-sequential way, enabling students to find their own ways to engage with the content.
The banknotes had non-sequential numbers.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not follow a particular order:
examples: The software allows you to move non-sequentially through related topics.
The book is a collection of essays that can be read independently and nonsequentially.

meanings.definition: not severe in effect:
examples: A few passengers suffered non-serious injuries as a result of the crash.
One child developed a non-serious rash.

meanings.definition: joking or intended to be funny:
examples: She smiled to signal the nonserious nature of her comment.
Let me offer a non-serious answer to that question.

meanings.definition: not needing or deserving your complete attention:
examples: She sees rock music as a non-serious art form.
They use the local dialect for casual, non-serious communication.

meanings.definition: not suggesting or believing that the members of one sex are less able, intelligent, important, etc. than the members of another sex:
examples: They published some guidelines for nonsexist use of language.
The new government aimed to establish a non-racial, non-sexist democracy.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involved in the activity of sex:
examples: He had several previous convictions for non-sexual offences.
The hero's mother is a presented as a non-sexual, selfless carer.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that does not sign a particular document (= write their name on it to show that they agree with its contents):
examples: The United States was among the non-signers of the treaty.
Even though I signed the agreement, I think that the rights of non-signers ought to be protected.

meanings.definition: a person who does not use sign language (= a language that uses hand and body movements, used by people who cannot hear or talk):
examples: The course is aimed at nonsigners who are interested in learning about sign language.
The majority of the students are nonsigners who are moderately deaf.

meanings.definition: not happening or being done at exactly the same time:
examples: We did a non-simultaneous house swap with a family in Sweden.
The rules require us to hold nonsimultaneous presidential and parliamentary elections.

meanings.definition: not relating to the skeleton (= frame of bones) of a person or animal:
examples: Nonskeletal symptoms are important for early diagnosis.
Vitamin D deficiency can have a harmful effect on various non-skeletal tissues.

meanings.definition: Non-skeletal creatures do not possess a skeleton:
examples: The area contains large numbers of non-skeletal life forms.
Non-skeletal organisms play a role in the production of biomass.

meanings.definition: a person who does not ski or has not learned how to ski:
examples: This is an excellent place for non-skiers to visit.
There are plenty of activities here to keep a non-skier occupied.

meanings.definition: designed to prevent sliding, especially by being made of sticky material or having a surface with a special texture:
examples: a non-slip surface/grip

meanings.definition: a person who does not smoke
A non-smoking person does not smoke:
examples: non-smoking passengers

meanings.definition: A non-smoking place is one where people are not allowed to smoke:
examples: Let's get a table in the no-smoking area.
a non-smoking flight

meanings.definition: used to describe a place where people are not allowed to smoke:
examples: It's physically impossible to prevent cigarette smoke from drifting from the smoking area over to the non-smoking areas.
All our offices have been non-smoking for several years now.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who does not smoke:
examples: Non-smoking colleagues often resent the fact that smokers are allowed to take time for a cigarette break outside.

meanings.definition: not believing in or supporting socialism (= a set of beliefs or political system based on the idea that all people are equal and should share equally in a country's money):
examples: She defeated two nonsocialist candidates in the election.
He became the country's first non-Socialist president.

meanings.definition: someone who does not believe in or support socialism:
examples: Most non-socialists believe that there is no sensible alternative to the free market.
The non-Socialists in the assembly rejected the Socialists' proposal.

meanings.definition: not of or from the sun:
examples: We may need to introduce new non-solar sources of energy.
Non-solar light tends to disrupt your body's natural rhythms and interfere with your sleep.

meanings.definition: not using the energy from the sun to produce electric power:
examples: The standard version of the phone contains a non-solar battery.

meanings.definition: the fact of not taking a company's customers or employees with you when you stop working for it as an employee yourself:
examples: All employees of the company must sign a non-solicitation agreement.
The non-solicitation period in the employment agreement is 24 months.

meanings.definition: a statement in an employee's contract saying that if they leave the company they will not do business with its customers and will not try to get other employees to leave it to work for someone else:
examples: Everyone had to sign a non-solicitation agreement when they started to work here.

meanings.definition: a course of action that does not solve or end a problem or difficulty:
examples: Setting up another inquiry was really a non-solution to the problem.
The proposed tax is a nonsolution that could create further shortages in the future.

meanings.definition: not relating to the position, area, and size of things:
examples: The nonspatial attributes of an object include colour, temperature, and weight.
The software uses both spatial and non-spatial reference data.

meanings.definition: someone who does not speak a particular language:
examples: Subtitles are provided for non-speakers of German.
She rarely used Gaelic, except very occasionally to keep a secret from her son or some other nonspeaker.

meanings.definition: a person who does not speak or is not able to speak:
examples: We want to improve the communication skills of non-speakers.
Some help is available for severely impaired nonspeakers.

meanings.definition: not saying anything:
examples: Glasses of wine and orange juice were passed around by non-speaking waiters.
The performance was intended to be interactive; it was not for a nonspeaking audience.

meanings.definition: not able to speak:
examples: Non-speaking people often use electronic devices to help them to communicate.
This approach provides an alternative to signing for nonspeaking clients.

meanings.definition: If an actor has a non-speaking part, they appear in a film, play, etc. but do not say anything:
examples: She had a non-speaking part in "The Merchant of Venice".
He made his debut in a non-speaking role in a long-running soap opera.

meanings.definition: A non-specific disease or condition does not result from any one particular cause:
examples: Chest pain is a non-specific symptom that can have cardiac or no cardiac causes.

meanings.definition: not very exciting to look at or experience:
examples: This sort of non-spectacular story does not offer much to excite the news media.
I want to create music that is serene and non-spectacular.

meanings.definition: based on information rather than on a guess:
examples: The statement was unambiguous and non-speculative.
I have tried to explain how these forces work by using purely mathematical and nonspeculative terms.

meanings.definition: not involving speculation (= buying and selling because you hope that the value of what you buy will increase and it can be sold at a profit):
examples: This type of asset is best suited for people making long-term, non-speculative investments.
They made the transactions for non-speculative purposes.

meanings.definition: not involving or consisting of speech:
examples: Her research examines the non-speech elements of language.
You can cause the device to start working by using a variety of non-speech sounds.

meanings.definition: not having a perfectly round shape, like a ball:
examples: A non-spherical projectile is likely to veer off course and miss the target.
Most of the eggs that we looked at were obviously non-spherical.

meanings.definition: not normal or usual:
examples: The keyboard was fitted with a non-standard plug.

meanings.definition: A non-standard word or phrase is not considered correct by educated speakers of the language.
not of the normal type or size:
examples: The keyboard was fitted with a non-standard plug.
a non-standard size of paper

meanings.definition: relating to paid work that is not permanent or not done for all the hours of the week that people normally work:
examples: Growing numbers have non-standard working arrangements.

meanings.definition: an idea, plan, or person with no chance of success:
examples: The proposal was a non-starter from the beginning because there was no possibility of funding.

meanings.definition: an idea, plan, or person that has no chance of success:
examples: The proposal was a non-starter from the beginning.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that does not belong to or is not controlled by a government:
examples: China's non-state sector is expanding rapidly.
In the UK, gas and electricity are competitive, non-state industries.

meanings.definition: not relating to statistics (= information based on counting the number of something, or the science of using information based on numbers):
examples: The data were generated by a wide range of non-statistical techniques.
As there are no figures available, we have to take a non-statistical approach.

meanings.definition: A non-stick cooking pan or tool has a special surface that prevents food from sticking to it:
examples: a non-stick frying pan

meanings.definition: without stopping or without interruptions:
examples: a non-stop flight
It felt like we travelled non-stop for the entire week.

meanings.definition: without stopping or without interruptions:
examples: a non-stop flight
It felt like we had travelled non-stop for the entire week.
He has worked nonstop to build up his business.

meanings.definition: information that someone tries to pass on that is of no importance or of no interest to anyone:
examples: It all turned out to be a bit of a non-story.
Why are they spending so much time spinning a non-story to the media?

meanings.definition: not helping to achieve a plan, for example in business or politics:
examples: The senior management team agreed to offload non-strategic businesses as part of a reorganization.
The group has deemed these parts of the country to be non-strategic and hence scaled down its operations there.

meanings.definition: not used to provide military forces with an advantage:
examples: There was widespread criticism of the bombing of the city, a non-strategic, non-military target.
The general was happy to allow non-strategic guerrilla troops to continue to disrupt the enemy's activities in remote regions.

meanings.definition: not related to the most important activities of a business:
examples: They have already sold off non-strategic activities in order to concentrate on growing the volume of the main brands.
non-strategic assets

meanings.definition: in cricket, the one of the pair of batters (= the players who try to hit the ball) to whom the ball is not being bowled (= thrown), who stands at the same end of the wicket (= the length of ground between the two sets of sticks) as the bowler:
examples: She smashed the ball back and almost hit the non-striker.
The non-striker should always begin to move down the pitch as the bowler bowls.

meanings.definition: not relating to the structure of a building or similar object:
examples: One wall was bulging and cracked but most of the damage was non-structural.
As well as building new dykes, the government approved a number of nonstructural solutions to the flooding problem.

meanings.definition: not organized according to a system or pattern:
examples: Non-structured creative activities can be just as important for children's education as formal classroom tasks.
We had a mass of non-structured data from the research project but needed to filter out what was important.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a student:
examples: There were just as many non-students among the crowd as there were students.
Some non-students joined the protests, even though they were not directly affected by the new law.

meanings.definition: a thing that is not discussed or studied, or considered not to be deserving of discussion or study:
examples: Her dad dismissively called media studies a non-subject.
Whether he did or not did not use a particular word is a non-subject; what matters is what he actually did.

meanings.definition: not a grammatical subject (= the person or thing that performs the action of a verb, or is joined to a description by a verb), or not relating to one:
examples: The first parts of the following sentences in this language are non-subjects.
These kinds of words rarely appear in the non-subject position.

meanings.definition: not subjective (= influenced by or based on personal beliefs or feelings, rather than facts):
examples: Appraisal of employees' performance must be based on non-subjective criteria.
The human resources team ensures that all applications are reviewed using non-subjective data.

meanings.definition: with no part of the cost of something paid:
examples: She argued that people living in non-subsidized apartments should be entitled to other benefits.
Countries in which there is non-subsidised agriculture have challenged the tariffs.

meanings.definition: failure to achieve the results wanted or hoped for:
examples: Not recruiting and training younger team members is a recipe for non-success in this market.
The success or non-success of our work depends on the patients’ willingness to cooperate.

meanings.definition: something that does not achieve positive results:
examples: Each trial was categorized as either a "success" or a "non-success".
We celebrate our successes and mourn our non-successes.

meanings.definition: not relating to or containing sugar:
examples: They make a point of only buying non-sugar cereals.
There has been a huge expansion of the non-sugar manufacturing sector in the country.

meanings.definition: not having or involving the job of supervising a person or activity (= watching them to make certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.):
examples: The company has committed to increasing the salary and benefits of non-supervisory employees.
She was beginning to find her non-supervisory role unrewarding and had applied for a management post.

meanings.definition: used to describe a medical treatment that does not involve cutting open the body:
examples: She had a non-surgical facelift.
a non-surgical procedure/treatment/method

meanings.definition: a person who is not able to swim:
examples: Despite being a non-swimmer, his mother jumped in to try to save him.
As a non-swimmer myself, I am always on my guard when my toddler goes near a swimming pool.

meanings.definition: not involving or using symbols:
examples: The artist is known for taking everyday, non-symbolic objects and finding meaning in them.
Non-symbolic language typically refers to real-world actions and objects and not intentions and other cognitive features.

meanings.definition: having two parts that do not match exactly, either when one half is not like an image of the other half in a mirror, or when one part cannot take the place of another if it is turned 90° or 180°:
examples: He has a non-symmetrical face with one ear higher than the other.
Although the pattern on the carpet appears symmetrical, if you look carefully you can see that it's actually non-symmetrical.

meanings.definition: involving actions or parts that are not similar or balanced:
examples: The principle of non-symmetrical disarmament has been proposed, where the country with the most weapons cuts the most.
The non-symmetrical distribution means that the results must be treated with caution.

meanings.definition: not happening at the same time or speed:
examples: The use of non-synchronous sound played a major part in the early days of film-making.
You can have two windows open on your screen and choose either synchronous or non-synchronous scrolling.

meanings.definition: not done or happening according to an agreed set of methods or an organized plan:
examples: The policy has been a failure because of the non-systematic implementation of its key principles.
The review into existing practices was non-systematic but did highlight some serious issues.

meanings.definition: A non-systemic drug, disease, or poison does not reach or have an effect on the whole of a body or a plant:
examples: The drug exerts a non-systemic action.
This is a non-systemic infection manifesting as fungal growth on the underside of leaves.

meanings.definition: A non-systemic problem or change is one that is experienced by particular parts of an organization or a country and not the whole of it:
examples: The review concluded that the issue was a rare and non-systemic one and that no further action was required.
There are almost certainly a number of non-systemic reasons for this problem that are harder to address.

meanings.definition: not involving a tariff (= a charge or list of charges either for services or on goods entering a country):
examples: The principle of non-tariff barriers is a core part of the European Union.
The government has proposed to introduce non-tariff measures for trade in agricultural products.

meanings.definition: a method of limiting imports without charging a tariff (= a tax on goods coming into a country):
examples: NTBs such as health and safety requirements or technical barriers can be important obstacles to international trade.

meanings.definition: If something is non-taxable, you do not have to pay tax on it:
examples: This portion of your income is non-taxable.
The government introduced a new, non-taxable investment account to encourage people to save more.
The same item may be viewed as taxable or nontaxable depending on where it was purchased.

meanings.definition: used to describe income, an asset, etc. on which you do not have to pay tax:
examples: Profits from exports are non-taxable for up to six years.
non-taxable income

meanings.definition: not doing, involving, or relating to the work of a teacher:
examples: Non-teaching staff in the college are treated in exactly the same way as teachers.
After many years in the classroom, he decided to make a change and take up a non-teaching role at the school.

meanings.definition: (of a person, job) not having or needing special knowledge about the machines, methods, etc. used in science and industry:
examples: She runs a course on computing for non-technical people.
Employers are also looking for graduates for non-technical roles such as consultancy, sales and marketing, and HR.

meanings.definition: (of language, information, etc.) not needing special knowledge relating to a particular subject or job to understand:
examples: She had tried as hard as possible to use non-technical language in her report so that it could be widely understood.
Although it has a non-technical title, the book deals with some advanced economic concepts.

meanings.definition: not involving or relating to the special knowledge, machines, methods, etc. used in science and industry:
examples: The reasons for the crash were deemed to be mostly non-technical.
It's possible that some non-technical aspects of cancer treatment, such as community support, make a big difference.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving practical skills and methods that are used in a particular activity:
examples: He found the more non-technical parts of the game a bit dull.
Once you have mastered the basic skills of the sport, you need to concentrate on the equally important non-technical side.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a teacher in a college or university who does not have tenure (= the right to remain permanently in a job):
examples: Approximately 20% of the staff are non-tenured.
Many non-tenured teachers had their contracts terminated.

meanings.definition: (of a disease or illness) not likely to lead to death soon:
examples: The whole family were hugely relieved to be told that the illness was non-terminal.
The diagnosis was that she had treatable, non-terminal bowel cancer.

meanings.definition: A non-terminal patient is one who is not likely to die soon:
examples: The hospital had to decide to deprioritize non-terminal patients.
Even if they are nonterminal, people with chronic illnesses require a great deal of care.

meanings.definition: not belonging or relating to the theatre, or to the performance or writing of plays, opera, etc.:
examples: She was best known for her non-theatrical roles but was keen to return to the stage.
It's his first non-theatrical work since the novel that made his name.

meanings.definition: not in a cinema:
examples: Most nontheatrical distribution of a movie is to airlines.
She specialized in non-theatrical film-making for the business and education sectors.

meanings.definition: not relating to theology (= the study of religion and religious belief):
examples: Although he speaks on the subject from a non-theological point of view, he shows a deep understanding of the theological issues.
In the absence of any non-theological basis for this position, as an atheist I have to disagree.

meanings.definition: based on the practical uses of a subject, rather than on a theory or theories:
examples: Archaeology used to be viewed as purely a non-theoretical discipline, but that is no longer true.
Their approach is non-theoretical in that it is not based on any specific economic model.

meanings.definition: not helping to treat an illness:
examples: Use of these drugs in non-therapeutic situations is coming under ever greater scrutiny.
Although very interesting, this kind of research is non-therapeutic and will bring no obvious benefit to patients.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not thinking carefully or seriously about what you do or believe:
examples: Litter and broken bottles had been left all over the park by non-thinking festival goers.
She claims that the purpose of education is to produce non-thinking citizens.

meanings.definition: (of an action or belief) not based on serious thought or an examination of the facts:
examples: There are signs that the party members' continued non-thinking support for their leader is beginning to waver.
I did not want to rush into giving an easy, non-thinking response.

meanings.definition: not affected by the tide (= the rise and fall of the sea that happens twice every day):
examples: New lock gates have made the harbour non-tidal.
Nontidal wetlands have a crucial role to play in guarding against flooding.
a non-tidal part of the River Thames

meanings.definition: not containing or relating to tobacco (= a substance smoked in cigarettes, pipes, etc. that is prepared from the dried leaves of a particular plant):
examples: The company is looking to grow its non-tobacco sales as the number of smokers is decreasing.
Local farmers are being offered incentives to grow more non-tobacco crops.

meanings.definition: Non-tonal music is written in a way that is not based on any particular musical key:
examples: There are some non-tonal passages in the piece that are tricky for the singers.
The composer would only work with classical pieces and eschewed anything non-tonal.

meanings.definition: A non-tonal language is one that does not use tones (= changes in how high or low the voice is that can change the meaning of a word):
examples: Although some of the dialects are tonal, most are non-tonal.
If you are a native speaker of a non-tonal language like English, Chinese is particularly hard to learn.

meanings.definition: not poisonous or not containing poisonous substances:
examples: non-toxic paint

meanings.definition: used to describe a business that is not involved in buying or selling, or one that is not operating:
examples: The high-street stores group is planning to raise £400 million through the sale of non-trading properties.

meanings.definition: used to describe a time when no buying or selling takes place:
examples: non-trading public holidays

meanings.definition: different from what was considered usual or typical in the past:
examples: non-traditional families/medicine/methods

meanings.definition: different from what was usual in the past:
examples: Women are increasingly joining non-traditional industries such as construction.

meanings.definition: not able to be used or legally owned by anyone other than a particular person:
examples: Tickets are non-transferable.
All prizes are non-transferable and have no cash value.

meanings.definition: not able to be used by another person:
examples: It is industry practice that tickets are non-transferable in order to prevent a secondary market in air tickets.
The prizes are non-transferable and are not redeemable for cash or other prizes.

meanings.definition: the lack of the use of medical treatment such as drugs or exercises to help a person with an illness or injury:
examples: The health authority have a recommended policy of non-treatment in such cases.
Randomized control trials comparing the results of different types of treatment, and non-treatment, should be run.

meanings.definition: having value or importance:
examples: The police are trying to concentrate their efforts on non-trivial crimes.
The decision about funding is a non-trivial one which could have a long-lasting effect.

meanings.definition: A non-trivial problem is not easy to solve:
examples: I soon realized that this was a non-trivial problem that was going to require a lot of time and thought.
It's one of those challenges that looks easy at first, but once you try to solve it, you find it's non-trivial.

meanings.definition: not in, coming from, or relating to the tropics (= the hottest area of the earth, between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn):
examples: Chile contains some of the only non-tropical areas in South America and can experience harsh winters.
The recent flooding was caused by non-tropical storms.

meanings.definition: Non-turbulent air or water does not move very strongly or suddenly:
examples: The valve outlet is sufficiently wide to allow the liquid to flow out in a non-turbulent fashion.
A flight feels smooth to passengers when the plane is flying through non-turbulent air.

meanings.definition: not having all the characteristics that you would usually expect from a particular group of things or people:
examples: This is a non-typical problem that requires a novel approach to resolve it.
Their family set-up was non-typical and so attracted some negative comments from less tolerant neighbours.

meanings.definition: Behaviour or ways of speaking that are non-U would not be considered acceptable by people of high social class.
indigestion that is not caused by a duodenal ulcer

If a group of people are non-unanimous, they do not all agree about something or vote the same way, and if a decision or judgment is non-unanimous, it is not formed or supported by everyone in a group:
examples: The sentencing options for a judge differ if there is a non-unanimous jury.
We had a vote on where to go next and, even though the decision was non-unanimous, everyone agreed in the end that it was a good choice.

meanings.definition: not the same in all parts or areas:
examples: The material was inspected and found to be of non-uniform thickness.
The temperature distribution within the container is non-uniform.
Unfortunately ID was requested and checked in a nonuniform fashion at the doors.

meanings.definition: not part of a uniform (= a particular set of clothes that have to be worn by members of the same organization or group of people):
examples: She was given detention for wearing a non-uniform skirt.

meanings.definition: A non-uniform day is one when you do not need to wear your uniform (= a particular set of clothes that have to be worn by members of the same organization or group of people):
examples: Fridays are non-uniform days so we can wear whatever we like to school.

meanings.definition: clothes that are not the same as those that usually have to be worn by members of the same organization or group of people:
examples: The soldiers were disciplined for wearing non-uniform.
The debate about uniform or non-uniform has diverted attention from the bigger issues.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is not the same in all places and situations:
examples: Businesses complained about non-uniform regulations across the European Union.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of not being the same in all parts or areas:
examples: The non-uniformity of the pattern actually made it more attractive.
It was felt that the law had been a failure because of the non-uniformity of its implementation.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a company or organization that does not employ workers who belong to a union, or a person who does not belong to a union:
examples: non-union employers/employees

meanings.definition: not belonging to a trade union:
examples: Among blue-collar jobs, union workers averaged $18.62 while non-union workers received $14.23.
Council withdrew a proposal to open the project to nonunion labour.

meanings.definition: not employing workers who are in a trade union, or not in favour of trade unions:
examples: The Big Three automakers contend that labor costs make it hard for them to compete with non-union companies.

meanings.definition: not made or worked on by members of a trade union:
examples: She refuses to buy non-union produce.
We work on union and non-union jobs throughout the country.

meanings.definition: not being a member of a trade union (= an organization that represents the people who work in a particular industry, protects their rights, and discusses their pay and working conditions with employers):
examples: The company is planning to reduce its non-unionized workforce by 10%.
Whether they are unionized or non-unionized, all workers are subject to the same terms.

         non-union  :
examples: The work force was non-unionized, thanks in no small part to the company's staunch resistance.

meanings.definition: not the only existing one of its type:
examples: This field in the database will always have non-unique values.
Any non-unique passwords will be rejected by the system.

meanings.definition: not existing everywhere or involving everyone:
examples: A change to a non-universal health care system would be fiercely resisted by the public.
The appeal of her work has always been non-universal, with both strong supporters and fierce critics.

meanings.definition: not relating to, going to, or having a university:
examples: Some of my non-university friends were a bit cold with me when I came back home.
The university is one of the biggest employers in the town, and non-university jobs are hard to find.

meanings.definition: not in, relating to, or typical of a city or town:
examples: The temperatures in non-urban areas tend to be a couple of degrees lower than in the big cities.
Voters like the nonurban values and lifestyle she represents.

meanings.definition: not needing to be done or dealt with immediately; not needing immediate attention:
examples: The hospital was overwhelmed and had to turn away all non-urgent cases.
If your trip is non-urgent, you are advised to stay at home.

meanings.definition: decorative and not designed to be useful:
examples: This architect specializes in taking a nonutilitarian approach to the most functional of buildings.
The number of non-utilitarian objects found in the ruins indicated that it had been the house of a wealthy family.

meanings.definition: not relating to a service used by the public, such as an electricity or gas supply:
examples: Non-utility companies are permitted to build power generators that do not use fossil fuels.
Industrial businesses that feed excess power into the grid are an example of a non-utility generator.

meanings.definition: not relating to or aiming for utopia (= a perfect society or system in which everything works well and everyone is happy):
examples: The campaign group made some very practical, non-utopian claims.
He takes a very sober, non-utopian view of human nature.

meanings.definition: not based on truth or reason:
examples: The results of the experiment were said to be non-valid because of the inconsistent methodology employed.
They persisted in employing the same arguments even after they had been shown to be non-valid.

meanings.definition: A document or computer file is non-valid if it does not meet a set of conditions, often official ones:
examples: This is a non-valid sequence of tags.
She was fined for travelling on a train with a non-valid ticket.

meanings.definition: not having legal force:
examples: The contract was deemed to be non-valid.
The lawyer claimed that the agreement had not been drafted properly and hence was non-valid.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a meal that contains meat, or a person who eats meat
A non-venomous snake, insect, etc. does not produce venom (= a poisonous liquid that can be put into another animal's body by biting or stinging):
examples: Most of the snakes native to the region are non-venomous, but care still needs to be taken.
She received a nasty snake bite, but fortunately the snake was identified as being a non-venomous variety.

meanings.definition: not using words, or not relating to the use of words:
examples: Body language is a potent form of non-verbal communication.
There are tests in verbal and non-verbal reasoning.

meanings.definition: not able to talk or use words:
examples: He has cerebral palsy and is non-verbal.
These tools are great for non-verbal children.

meanings.definition: not using words or speech:
examples: Sara Bates, a business trainer in non-verbal communication, says women need to work particularly hard at using eye contact.
Non-verbal signals tell other people as much about you as what you actually say to them.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not use words:
examples: So much of what we think about something is communicated non-verbally.
They agreed, nonverbally through glances and nods, to meet outside at lunchtime.

meanings.definition: someone who has not been in the armed forces:
examples: The study compared suicide rates between veterans and non-veterans.
As a non-veteran, the candidate had to work hard to persuade veterans and serving soldiers to vote for him.

meanings.definition: not able to work as intended or not able to succeed:
examples: It's an interesting proposal but it's simply economically non-viable.
They fiercely contested the assertion that independence was a non-viable option.

meanings.definition: not able to continue to exist as or develop into a living thing:
examples: Non-viable embryos can be used for research purposes under strict conditions.
Seeds below a certain weight are considered non-viable.

meanings.definition: a person who does not watch something on television or a video:
examples: Non-viewers of the reality programme will be mystified by some of the words that it has popularized.
As a non-viewer, I can honestly say that I don't get the appeal of this show.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone avoids fighting or using physical force, especially when trying to make political change:
examples: The Dalai Lama has always counselled non-violence.

meanings.definition: (of political protest or crime) not involving fighting or the use of physical force:
examples: Gandhi was an exponent of non-violent protest.
She called on volunteers to join the non-violent resistance.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not involve fighting or the use of physical force:
examples: The activists were committed to protesting non-violently.
The campaigners were non-violently attempting to raise awareness of the climate crisis by blocking traffic.
Martin Luther King campaigned nonviolently for an end to racial segregation.

meanings.definition: someone who has had sex:
examples: He felt stigmatized as all his friends claimed to be non-virgins.
Women who are non-virgins can be subjected to hostility in some communities.

meanings.definition: A non-viscous liquid is not thick and flows easily:
examples: Water is a good example of a non-viscous liquid.
For optimal efficiency, this machine requires a working fluid which is as non-viscous as possible.

meanings.definition: not relating to seeing:
examples: An audio tour is available for blind and partially sighted people which describes the exhibits using non-visual language.
I find it hard to remember information if it is presented in a non-visual way.

meanings.definition: not relating to or produced by the voice, either in singing or speaking:
examples: The non-vocal tracks on her new album have been less well received.
It is interesting to observe the non-vocal signals used by the chimpanzees to communicate.

meanings.definition: (of a course, a qualification, etc.) not intended to provide the skills and education needed for a particular job:
examples: Non-vocational courses are better for people who are not committed to a particular career.
Fewer students are now taking non-vocational degrees as the job market becomes more competitive.

meanings.definition: not relating to or made by a volcano (= a mountain with a hole at the top through which hot liquid rock is or has been forced out):
examples: Non-volcanic tremors off the east coast were detected recently but are thought to pose no threat.
The point of land jutting out into the sea consists of non-volcanic rock.

meanings.definition: forced or paid to do, make, or give something:
examples: She argued that the regulations should be made non-voluntary to ensure that people really change their behaviour.
The company announced a number of non-voluntary redundancies.

meanings.definition: a person who does not vote or who does not have a legal right to vote, especially in an election:
examples: When questioned, non-voters gave a number of different reasons for not casting a vote.
Low turnout can have a significant impact on the result because of demographic differences between voters and nonvoters.

meanings.definition: not having or giving the legal right to vote, or not choosing to vote:
examples: The board includes four non-voting members representing different groups.
There was an opportunity to trade voting and nonvoting shares.

meanings.definition: used to describe company shares that do not allow their owners the right to vote at shareholder meetings:
examples: We own 500 shares of Class A non-voting stock in the company.
The IRS agreed that the stock had a value of $37 per voting share and $35 per non-voting share.

meanings.definition: used to describe a member of a company's board of directors who does not have the right to vote:
examples: The airline's pilots agreed to a 2% pay cut in return for a non-voting board seat.

meanings.definition: not relating to a wage (= a particular amount of money that is paid, usually every week, to an employee):
examples: When submitting a tax return, you must also include all your non-wage income.
The non-wage costs that employers are obliged to pay amount to an additional 40% on top of the wage bill.

meanings.definition: the lack of war, or a war that does not actually take place:
examples: There has been a lot of posturing but this period of non-war seems certain to continue.
The series of military escalations which turn out to be non-wars between the two states seems set to continue.

meanings.definition: not relating to war:
examples: Non-war spending has soared in recent years in an attempt to shore up the domestic economy.
The army is said to lack vital equipment needed for war and nonwar situations.

meanings.definition: a person who is not white:
examples: Non-whites were not welcome in the club.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who is not white:
examples: He is one of only two non-white players in the squad.
Non-white Britons are disproportionately concentrated among the working class and poor.

meanings.definition: involving or relating to people who are not white:
examples: Non-white voter registration increased by 17.3 percent statewide.
His outspoken attitude on the issue of non-white immigration came to national attention in 1968.

meanings.definition: not winning or not involving winning anything:
examples: It was no great surprise when the manager was sacked after a disastrous, non-winning season.
Hold on to any non-winning lottery tickets as they entitle you to enter a special one-off draw.

meanings.definition: Non-woody plants do not have hard stems:
examples: The potato is the tuber of a non-woody plant native to South America.
Herbaceous plants are always non-woody and die at the end of a growing season.

meanings.definition: something that is not work, or a time when someone does not work:
examples: It seems cruel that caring for family members is classified as non-work.
Poor managers make it difficult for employees to balance work and nonwork.

meanings.definition: not relating to work:
examples: He spends most of his non-work time playing video games.
We are still tied to the office during nonwork hours by our mobile phones.
She has a wide range of non-work activities, from running to volunteering.

meanings.definition: someone who does not work or does not have a paid job:
examples: Non-workers are only allowed admission to the factory if accompanied by a member of staff.
There are income support schemes available for older nonworkers.

meanings.definition: not having a job:
examples: Non-working members of the family need to contribute in other ways.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving work:
examples: She fills her non-working hours with a strict exercise regime and socializing.
This is my first nonworking holiday in five years.

meanings.definition: not operating:
examples: Non-working traffic lights at the junction caused long tailbacks.
They collect working and nonworking mobile phones for charity.
If any part of the system turns out to be non-working, contact us for an immediate replacement.

meanings.definition: someone who is not a writer:
examples: Non-writers are always fascinated by the different processes that writers use when they are being creative.
As a non-writer, I have never understood how authors can just start writing with a blank screen or piece of paper in front of them.

meanings.definition: that does not turn yellow:
examples: Make sure that you use paints with non-yellowing additives for the woodwork to get that professional look.
In a final step, she applied a non-yellowing varnish to the painting to protect it and bring out the colours.

meanings.definition: A nonabsorbable substance cannot be absorbed, especially by the body:
examples: a nonabsorbable antibacterial agent
Close the wound with a non-absorbable nylon suture.

meanings.definition: A nonaccrual loan does not involve an increase in the amount of interest (= money charged for borrowing) owed over time:
examples: There was a decline in nonaccrual loans.
the transfer of existing loans to non-accrual status

meanings.definition: not able to change to suit changing conditions:
examples: Such people might be conservative in temperament and be generally non-adaptive .

meanings.definition: Non-adaptive features or changes do not make an organism more suited to its environment:
examples: It has been suggested that deer's antlers may be non-adaptive features.

meanings.definition: a person who is between 90 and 99 years old
relating to a nonagenarian:
examples: He looks after the business affairs of his nonagenarian mother.
The nonagenarian artist creates the kind of sculptures that inhabit our nightmares.

meanings.definition: not behaving in an angry, violent way:
examples: You should reinforce with your child the need to resolve conflict in a nonaggressive way.
He is a non-aggressive, very gentle person, who would always try to avoid confrontation.

meanings.definition: A nonaggressive disease, especially cancer, does not spread quickly and has a good chance of being cured:
examples: She was diagnosed with nonaggressive skin cancer.
We are trying to develop a protocol to identify non-aggressive prostate cancers.

meanings.definition: a flat shape with nine straight sides
not caused by, made from, or relating to bacteria:
examples: Antibiotics will not help if you have a nonbacterial infection.

meanings.definition: not connected with the natural processes of living things:
examples: The fluid contains a combination of nonbiological materials.
One research group has produced similar crystals using non-biological techniques.

meanings.definition: not related by birth:
examples: In some cases, courts will award custody of children to nonbiological parents.
She still has a good relationship with her non-biological daughter.

meanings.definition: Nonbiological washing powder or liquid does not use enzymes (= substances that cause chemical change) to remove dirt:
examples: This mild, nonbiological washing powderlaundry detergent is made from natural ingredients.
Using a non-biological washing powder can help to reduce itchiness.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not connected with the natural processes of living things:
examples: The components of RNA can be produced nonbiologically.
They tried to prove that artificial flight can be done non-biologically.

meanings.definition: Nonbiologically related people are not related by birth:
examples: The family network may sometimes be widened to include nonbiologically related persons.
This process is usually undertaken by two non-biologically related people.

meanings.definition: If a loan (= borrowed money) is noncallable, the organization that lends the money cannot ask for it to be paid back before the end of a certain time:

an issue of 7.5% non-callable notes

meanings.definition: used to describe bonds, shares, etc. that cannot be sold before the end of an agreed period of time:

meanings.definition: a debenture (= type of loan) that cannot be paid back before the end of an agreed period:

meanings.definition: borrowed money that cannot be paid back before the end of an agreed period of time:

meanings.definition: existing or happening away from the buildings of a college or university and the land that surrounds them:

meanings.definition: not involving the heart:

meanings.definition: not having or involving a cause:

meanings.definition: a person who commits a crime involving sex, especially sex with a child

connected to a telephone system by wires rather than by radio signals:

meanings.definition: not involving or made of cells:
examples: Plasma is the non-cellular portion of the blood.

meanings.definition: not in, at, from, or near the centre or most important part of something:
examples: The firm was unwilling to move its offices to a noncentral location.

meanings.definition: calm behaviour that suggests you are not interested or do not care:
examples: He leaned back in his chair with apparent nonchalance.

meanings.definition: behaving in a calm manner, often in a way that suggests you are not interested or do not care:
examples: a nonchalant manner/shrug

meanings.definition: behaving in a calm manner, showing that you are not worried or frightened:
examples: She waited her turn to audition, trying to look nonchalant.

meanings.definition: in a calm manner, often in a way that suggests you are not interested or do not care:
examples: "I'm sure I'll get into some uni," he said nonchalantly.

meanings.definition: not involving chemicals or chemistry:
examples: There are several nonchemical remedies which can help you to get a good night's sleep.
The company has developed a range of non-chemical weed-killers.

meanings.definition: not following the order in which a series of events happened:
examples: The book has a nonchronological structure.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a citizen (= a member of a particular country who has certain rights):
examples: Noncitizens cannot vote in national elections.

meanings.definition: not using force to persuade people to do things:
examples: The manual suggests a number of noncoercive tactics that you might use.

meanings.definition: not connected with thinking or conscious mental processes:

meanings.definition: not involving the act of having sex:
examples: In-vitro fertilization is a noncoital type of reproduction.

meanings.definition: A noncola soft drink (= one that does not contain alcohol) is a drink other than cola (= a sweet, brown drink):
examples: Noncola drinks have been selling well this summer.

meanings.definition: Noncollinear points do not lie on a single straight line:
examples: The points on the diagram are noncollinear.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         noncoloured
not having a colour or colours:
examples: The glass may be coloured or noncoloured.

meanings.definition: a person, especially in the armed forces, who does not fight in a war, for example a priest or a doctor
relating to a noncombatant:
examples: noncombatant troops/ships
About 100,000 noncombatant civilians died in that battle.

meanings.definition: a person who is part of a military group, but whose job does not include fighting:
examples: Medics, chaplains, and other noncombatants were part of the regiment.

meanings.definition: not able to burn easily:
examples: The roofs have to be built from noncombustible materials.

meanings.definition: not expressing an opinion or decision:
examples: The ambassador was typically noncommittal when asked whether further sanctions would be introduced.

meanings.definition: not expressing a clear opinion or decision:
examples: The ambassador was noncommittal about the introduction of further sanctions.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not express an opinion or decision:
examples: Pat shrugged noncommittally.
"Mmn," she replied non-committally.

meanings.definition: not sharing information with others by speaking, writing, moving your body, or using other signals:
examples: She is studying brain scans of noncommunicating children.
The scientists discussed how to search for non-communicating alien life.

meanings.definition: Noncommunicating things or parts of things have no connection that allows you to go directly from one into the other:
examples: They can break the reservoirs of oil into noncommunicating sections.

meanings.definition: not obeying a rule or law:
examples: The Health Department could take noncomplying water companies to court.

meanings.definition: not able to be pressed together or pressed into a smaller space:
examples: non-compressible, calcified blood vessels

meanings.definition: not based on abstract ideas or principles:
examples: These insights are quite different from the ordinary non-conceptual way of speaking about identity.

meanings.definition: a lack of concern:
examples: They're the victims of many years of nonconcern for human life.

meanings.definition: something that is not of interest or concern to someone:
examples: His state of alarm seemed such a non-concern to the interpreter.

meanings.definition: a gas that cannot easily be condensed (= changed into a liquid by cooling):
examples: The area was evacuated after a large quantity of noncondensable gas was expelled into the air.

meanings.definition: related to or involving play between teams that do not belong to the same conference (= a group of sports teams that play each other in organized competitions):
examples: The team has played a number of tough non-conference games this season.
The SEC has been criticized for playing weak non-conference schedules.

meanings.definition: in Christianity, a religious movement that is Protestant but does not belong to the Church of England:
examples: He was concerned by the growth of religious nonconformism.

meanings.definition: the quality of living and thinking in a way that is different from most other people:
examples: The tech company still has the aura of hippy nonconformism.
