meanings.definition: someone who lives and thinks in a way that is different from other people
a member of a Christian group that is Protestant but does not belong to the Church of England
having a way of thinking that is different from other people:
examples: nonconformist behaviour
He remains one of his generation's most nonconformist writers.

meanings.definition: relating to a Nonconformist, or to the religious group they belong to:
examples: a Nonconformist minister
Initially he was attracted to the nonconformist church.

meanings.definition: a person who does not live and think according to accepted customs and standards
the quality of living and thinking in a way that is different from other people:
examples: Her clothes were an immediate signal of her nonconformity.

meanings.definition: the practice of belonging to a Christian group that is Protestant but does not belong to the Church of England:
examples: Nonconformity was common in the seventeenth century.

meanings.definition: the condition of not acting or not thinking like other people, esp. in relation to religion:
examples: William Penn was expelled from Oxford for nonconformity.

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is unlikely to upset anyone or cause an argument:
examples: Many will prefer his nonconfrontational attitude to my more direct approach.
Drama is a holistic tool that is useful for addressing serious issues in an engaging, non-confrontational and inspiring way.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is no connection between people or things:
examples: Their relationship follows an unpredictable course of connection and nonconnection.

meanings.definition: not relating to, involving, or following the rules of a country's constitution (= the set of political principles by which it is governed):
examples: Cases should be decided on nonconstitutional grounds wherever possible.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving construction (= the work of building houses, bridges, etc.):
examples: The pool will remain open during nonconstruction hours.
Non-construction labourers include miners and manufacturing workers.

meanings.definition: not involving physical contact:
examples: The benefits of this treatment include its low cost, noncontact mode of therapy and the portability of the equipment.

meanings.definition: A non-contagious disease cannot pass from one person or animal to another:
examples: a noncontagious disease/infection/condition

meanings.definition: If a person or animal is noncontagious, they cannot pass a disease to another person or animal:
examples: Patients who are given the drug quickly become non-contagious.

meanings.definition: (of a subject, statement, etc.) which is unlikely to cause disagreement or argument :
examples: Most books about the city focus on noncontroversial topics like history and art.
The concept behind the proposal is relatively noncontroversial; I'm hoping people will get behind it.
The two presidents discussed a range of non-controversial issues, including funds to fight AIDS, malaria, hunger, and illiteracy.

meanings.definition: the fact of not providing insurance coverage (= financial protection that allows you to get money if something bad happens), in particular, for medical treatment:
examples: The proposed noncoverage of such therapies will prevent Medicare clients from accessing certain extremely effective treatment options.
New patients with painful wounds were unable to receive the best possible treatment due to non-coverage.

meanings.definition: not having the abilities or experience that make a person suitable for a particular job or activity, or not having official proof of your abilities or experience:
examples: In an age of blogs written by noncredentialed amateurs, there is much debate over what constitutes journalism.
Critics say noncredentialed teachers are being thrown into classrooms with little or no preparation.

meanings.definition: not easily crushed (= broken or having lost its shape from being pressed very hard):
examples: Place all the noncrushable items at the bottom of the bag; crushable ones go on top.
The tablets are made using a non-crushable formulation to prevent misuse of the drug.

meanings.definition: In a nondecreasing list of numbers or amounts, each number or amount is not less than the previous one:
examples: Let us consider a nondecreasing function f.
Throughout this article the term "increasing" is used instead of "non-decreasing" and "decreasing" instead of "non-increasing".

meanings.definition: especially of a young person, not delinquent (= behaving in a way that is illegal or not acceptable):
examples: There is no evidence that television turns a non-delinquent child into a delinquent one.
Offending is part of a broader pattern that usually starts with disruptive nondelinquent behaviour.

meanings.definition: not depressed (= unhappy and without hope), or not suffering from depression (= a mental illness in which a person is very unhappy and anxious for long periods and cannot have a normal life during these periods):
examples: Compared with children of nondepressed mothers, children of depressed mothers had higher levels of anxiety and social problems.
Depressed and non-depressed children have been found to differ in their perceptions of self-worth.
Don't forget that even non-depressed people get upset when bad or stressful things happen to them.

meanings.definition: very ordinary, or having no interesting or exciting features or qualities:
examples: Their offices are in a nondescript building on the edge of town.

meanings.definition: having no interesting or unusual features; ordinary:
examples: A nondescript couple sat next to her in the waiting room.

meanings.definition: behaving in a normal and acceptable way :
examples: nondeviant children/friends/peers/spouse
Increased association with non-deviant peers may help reduce disruptive behaviour across adolescence.

meanings.definition: A nondiversified investment company or fund invests most of its money in a single industry, etc. :
examples: A non-diversified fund is subject to more investment risk because it focuses on a limited number of issuers.
The Trust is a nondiversified investment company, and may be subject to greater risks than if it were diversified.

meanings.definition: A nondominant part of the body is not used as much as, or does not have as much effect as, a body part of the same type on the other side of the body:
examples: Use your nondominant hand.
the non-dominant hemisphere of the brain

meanings.definition: having fewer people or less influence, or often treated as less important, than anything else of the same type:
examples: nondominant cultures
individuals belonging to non-dominant groups

meanings.definition: (of genes and the physical qualities they control) only appearing in a child if both parents supply the controlling gene:
examples: A nondominant gene is known as recessive.

meanings.definition: without excitement, or not very noticeable:
examples: a series of nondramatic events

meanings.definition: Nondramatic pieces of writing are those which are not plays:
examples: She is better known for her nondramatic works.
nondramatic literature

meanings.definition: someone who cannot or chooses not to drive:
examples: The poor bus service in the village makes it difficult for nondrivers.
As a non-driver I am unable to benefit from this new road scheme.

meanings.definition: not involving the use of medical drugs:
examples: People concerned about side effects sometimes turn to nondrug alternatives.
Non-drug treatments are preferred.

meanings.definition: not involving illegal drugs:
examples: a defendant in a non-drug case
public corruption and other nondrug crimes

meanings.definition: Something that is nondurable is intended to be used immediately and last for a short time:
examples: Sales of non-durable items such as drinks and cleaning products have increased by over 10%.

meanings.definition: products like food and clothes that are intended to be used immediately and not last for a long time:
examples: The price of nondurable goods has been falling relative to the price of services.
nondurable goods such as cosmetics and cleaning products

meanings.definition: not one (of a group of people or things), or not any:
examples: None of my children has/have blonde hair.
"I'd like some more cheese." "I'm sorry there's none left".
"Do you have any idea how much this cost?" "None at all/None whatsoever."

meanings.definition: not one, or not any:
examples: None of my children has blue eyes.
“Is there any more orange juice?” “I’m sorry, there’s none left.”

meanings.definition: only:
examples: None but a dedicated scientist would want to read such a detailed report.

meanings.definition: said when you want to show that someone or something is a surprising or exciting choice or example:
examples: The first speech was given by none other than Clint Eastwood.

meanings.definition: the very famous or important person or thing:
examples: The speech was given by none other than the vice president.

meanings.definition: to not understand something: To be none the wiser also means to not be aware of something:
examples: I read the computer manual, but I’m still none the wiser.

meanings.definition: not damaged or harmed despite something:
examples: It was cold and windy during the parade but we were none the worse for the weather.

none-the-worse-better-richer-etc.name: none the worse, better, richer, etc.

meanings.definition: not any worse, better, richer, etc. than before:
examples: Luckily, the horse seemed none the worse for his fall.

meanings.definition: very little of something:
examples: "Did you get much rain while you were in Singapore?" "None to speak of."

meanings.definition: not very:
examples: He seemed none too happy/pleased at the prospect of meeting the family.

meanings.definition: not very:
examples: He seemed none too happy at the prospect of meeting the family.

meanings.definition: not producing or earning income:
examples: Nonearning assets include property which does not increase in value over time.
Non-earning members of the group need to contribute in other ways.

meanings.definition: not belonging to or connected with the Christian religion:
examples: The company is working with a number of nonecclesiastical charities on measures to reduce child poverty.

meanings.definition: a substance that dissolves in water to produce a liquid that electricity does not go through
a substance that dissolves in water to produce a liquid that electricity does not go through
a person without strong character, ideas, or influence:
examples: She was once a political nonentity, but has since won a formidable reputation as a determined campaigner.

meanings.definition: the fact that something or someone is not known about because of not having any strong character, ideas, or influence:
examples: This collection of essays is saved from nonentity by the stature of the contributors.

meanings.definition: a person or thing of no importance:
examples: It’s a low-budget film full of nonentities.

meanings.definition: the state of not being in balance:
examples: Non-market forces are often there to maintain nonequilibrium, such as wage differential by restriction on labour movement across nations.

meanings.definition: a state in which there is no chemical equilibrium (= when the reactants and products in a chemical reaction do not change because the rate of forward reaction is equal to the rate of reverse reaction):
examples: By supplying energy from external fluctuations or nonequilibrium chemical reactions, directed motion is possible.

meanings.definition: the fact of having a different amount, value, purpose, quality, etc.:
examples: The paper examines the nonequivalence in meanings of these words in a number of different contexts.
The non-equivalence between the two concepts has been well established.

meanings.definition: having a different amount, value, purpose, quality, etc.:
examples: Nonequivalent fractions are not equal to each other.
The translation reviewer identified a number of nonequivalent translations.

meanings.definition: in the ancient Roman calendar, the ninth day before the ides (= the middle day of the month):
examples: The nones of December dawned bright and cold.

meanings.definition: despite what has just been said or done:
examples: There are serious problems in our country. Nonetheless, we feel this is a good time to return.

meanings.definition: despite what has just been said or referred to; nevertheless:
examples: There are possible risks, but nonetheless, we feel it’s a sound investment.

meanings.definition: completely absent:
examples: Crime is virtually nonexistent around here.

meanings.definition: not relating to existence or being alive:
examples: The verb "to be" in these sentences has a nonexistential meaning.

meanings.definition: not having experienced or been in the same place as something that could be harmful or unpleasant:
examples: Cholesterol levels in the exposed group were much higher than in the nonexposed one.

meanings.definition: a failure to do something when there is a legal duty to do so, especially by a person in authority:
examples: The two marshals committed nonfeasance by refusing to answer questions from the investigator.

meanings.definition: writing that is about real events and facts, rather than stories that have been invented
the type of book or other writing that deals with facts about real people or events, not imaginary stories
not able to burn:
examples: nonflammable clothing

meanings.definition: A nonforfeitable benefit (= something that an employee receives in addition to money) is one that they will always have the right to claim:
examples: At normal retirement age, all benefits payable under this pension plan are nonforfeitable.

meanings.definition: the fact of not losing rights, property, or money:
examples: There are nonforfeiture provisions in the policy.

meanings.definition: a lack of pleasure and satisfaction because you are not happy with your life:
examples: After a lifetime of nonfulfillment, it was not surprising that he experienced bouts of rage.

meanings.definition: the failure to do something that someone wanted you to do or that you promised to do:
examples: The group was protesting against the nonfulfillment of their demands.

meanings.definition: not easy to exchange or mix with other similar goods or assets:
examples: non-fungible property/assets/funds

meanings.definition: not part of or controlled by the government:

meanings.definition: not part of or controlled by the government:

meanings.definition: an organization that tries to achieve social or political aims but is not controlled by a government
consisting of parts or people who are different from each other:
examples: The poetry collection is uneven as it is nonhomogeneous in terms of format and style.

meanings.definition: (of a chromosome) not containing similar information to another chromosome that it forms a pair with during meiosis (= a type of cell division), or involving such chromosomes:
examples: Nonhomologous chromosomes, such as XY sex chromosomes, have alleles on different genes.

meanings.definition: not taken to hospital and kept there for treatment:
examples: The project aims to ensure that nonhospitalized patients receive the medication they need.

meanings.definition: a fruit with pale yellow flesh and many small seeds, with a strong smell and a sour taste, that grows in southeast Asia, Australasia, and the Pacific islands. It is eaten as food and used in medicines:
examples: Tahitian noni juice

Noni are very hardy and can be grown just about anywhere.

meanings.definition: not having come to a different country in order to live there permanently:

meanings.definition: a person who has not come to a different country in order to live there permanently:
examples: Immigrants and non-immigrants are required to carry proof of their status with them at all times.

meanings.definition: the lack of freedom from control by other people, events, or things:
examples: They need to take into account the nonindependence of data from family members when drawing conclusions.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a country is governed or ruled by another country:
examples: The country's status of nonindependence has been a hot political topic for decades.

meanings.definition: not living in, or having lived for a long time in, an institution (= a place such as a hospital, care home, or prison):
examples: The researchers appealed for noninstitutionalized stroke survivors to participate in the study.

meanings.definition: not relating to teaching:

meanings.definition: not relating to or taking place in a law court:

meanings.definition: A non-jury legal case is not heard or decided by a jury (= a group of people who have been chosen to listen to all the facts in a trial in a law court and to decide if a person is guilty):

meanings.definition: not consisting of or relating to lines:

meanings.definition: involving a situation in which one thing does not change at the same rate as another, so that the relationship between them changes :
examples: A nonlinear relationship was observed between the changes in the glucose and sodium concentrations.

meanings.definition: A nonlinear equation (= mathematical statement) describes a situation in which one thing does not change at the same rate as another, so that the relationship between them changes. Nonlinear equations have the form of curves, rather than straight lines, on a graph:
examples: A nonlinear equation describes a process in which consequences are not proportional to causes.

meanings.definition: Nonlinear editing is a method of editing video, images, or audio (= sound) files by going directly to the part of the file you want to edit, rather then working through each part of the file in order:

a chemical element that is not a metal
better than any other:

meanings.definition: failure to pay an amount that is expected:

relating to mammals such as marsupials whose babies, which are not fully developed at birth, continue to develop outside the mother's uterus

meanings.definition: (of a substance) not able to cause illness or death if taken into the body:

describes a substance whose molecules do not have opposite positive and negative poles

examples: The company has nosed ahead of its closest rivals, claiming 33% market share.

meanings.definition: the front part of a spacecraft, aircraft, or missile (= flying weapon)
used to describe the way someone behaves when they think they are better than other people and do not want to speak to them:
examples: She walked past me with her nose in the air.

meanings.definition: to discover something by searching carefully:
examples: He soon nosed out the details of the accident by talking to people and making some phone calls.

meanings.definition: a small piece of jewellery connected to a short, thin piece of metal that passes through the side of the nose:
examples: She wondered if she should take out her nose stud for the job interview.

meanings.definition: in American football, a player on the defence who stands in the middle of the line of players at the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of a period of action):
examples: After the ball is snapped, the centre must guard against the nosetackle.
He excelled as a nose tackle on his high school football team.
He played both nose guard and offensive tackle in his first season in the league.

meanings.definition: the use of as many parts of an animal as possible in cooking, so that none of it is wasted:
examples: Nose to tail requires that even the unpopular parts of the animal be used.
Chris followed his nose-to-tail philosphy and cooked a pig's head as his main course.

meanings.definition: to increase slowly or by a small amount:
examples: Savings rates have been nosing up during the past few months.

meanings.definition: the wheel at the front of an aircraft
a bag for holding food that is hung around a horse's head
an occasion when blood comes out of a person's nose:
examples: She gets/has a lot of nosebleeds.

meanings.definition: a period of bleeding from the nose
having a nose of the type mentioned:
examples: sharp/snub/hook-nosed
a blunt-nosed missile

meanings.definition: a fast and sudden fall to the ground with the front pointing down:
examples: The plane roared overhead and went into a nosedive.

meanings.definition: a sudden fast fall in prices, value, etc.:
examples: There was alarm in the markets when the dollar took a nosedive.

meanings.definition: to suddenly fall to the ground with the front pointing down:
examples: Spectators in the crowd watched in horror as the plane nosedived.

meanings.definition: to suddenly fall in value, quickly and by a large amount:
examples: House prices nosedived without warning.

meanings.definition: (esp. of an aircraft) a fast and sudden fall to the ground with the front pointing down:
examples: fig. Stock prices took a nosedive (= a sudden fall in value).

meanings.definition: a sudden fast fall in price, value, etc.:
examples: Most analysts view the stock's recent nosedive as investor overreaction.
Shares on Wall Street took a nosedive last night.

meanings.definition: to suddenly fall in value, quickly and by a large amount:
examples: Market prices continue to nosedive this week.
