past simple and past participle of 
        
         nosedive
to suddenly fall to the ground with the front pointing down:
examples: Spectators in the crowd watched in horror as the plane nosedived.

meanings.definition: to suddenly fall in value, quickly and by a large amount:
examples: House prices nosedived without warning.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         nosedive
to suddenly fall to the ground with the front pointing down:
examples: Spectators in the crowd watched in horror as the plane nosedived.

meanings.definition: to suddenly fall in value, quickly and by a large amount:
examples: House prices nosedived without warning.

meanings.definition: a small bunch of cut flowers
a disease that affects bees
a disease that affects bees:
examples: How can beekeepers protect their hives from nosemosis?

meanings.definition: food or a meal:
examples: They serve good nosh in the cafeteria.

meanings.definition: a small amount of food eaten between meals or as a meal:
examples: I have a little nosh at about 10.30, so I don't overeat at lunch.

meanings.definition: to eat:
examples: We asked the waiter for something to nosh on while we waited for a table.

meanings.definition: a small amount of food eaten between meals or as a meal
a big, enjoyable meal:
examples: We had some good nosh-ups on holiday.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         nosh
to eat:
examples: We asked the waiter for something to nosh on while we waited for a table.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         nosh
to eat:
examples: We asked the waiter for something to nosh on while we waited for a table.

meanings.definition:
comparative of 
        
         nosy   disapproving

superlative of 
        
         nosy   disapproving
in a way that shows too much interest in what other people are doing or a wish to discover more about them than you should:
examples: "Who was that on the phone?" she asked nosily.
He looked around the room, nosily, for signs of wealth.

meanings.definition: the quality of being too interested in what other people are doing and wanting to discover too much about them:
examples: He was shocked by their nosiness.
She is fascinated by people - not out of nosiness but from a genuine interest in human beings.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         nose
to look around or search in order to discover something, especially something that other people do not want you to find:
examples: There were some reporters nosing about/around.
The police came in and started nosing into drawers and looking through papers.

meanings.definition: to (make a vehicle) move forwards slowly and carefully:
examples: The car nosed out of the side street, its driver peering anxiously around.
He carefully nosed his lorry into the small space.

meanings.definition: a feeling of pleasure and also slight sadness when you think about things that happened in the past:
examples: Some people feel nostalgia for their schooldays.
Hearing that song again filled him with nostalgia.
a wave (= sudden strong feeling) of nostalgia

meanings.definition: a feeling of pleasure and sometimes slight sadness at the same time as you think about things that happened in the past:
examples: Hearing her voice again filled him with nostalgia.

meanings.definition: feeling happy and also slightly sad when you think about things that happened in the past:
examples: Talking about our old family holidays has made me feel all nostalgic.
We'll take a nostalgic look at the musical hits of the 60s.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves thinking about things that happened in the past with happy and also slightly sad feelings:
examples: to look back/talk/think nostalgically
She looked back nostalgically to when all shopping was local.

meanings.definition: either of the two openings in the nose through which air moves when you breathe:
examples: The horses came to a halt, steam streaming from their nostrils.

meanings.definition: either of the two openings in the nose through which air moves
an account that a bank keeps for itself in a bank in another country, usually in that country's currency:
examples: Nostro accounts are maintained by Indian banks in foreign countries where they have operations for facilitating easy clearing of their transactions.

meanings.definition: an idea for solving a problem, especially one that is not very good:
examples: He refused to embrace any of the fashionable nostrums then current in development economics.

meanings.definition: too interested in what other people are doing and wanting to discover too much about them:
examples: She was complaining about her nosy parents.
A rather nosey woman once asked him about his personal life.

meanings.definition: too interested in what other people are doing and wanting to discover too much about them:
examples: I was a nosy kid.

meanings.definition: a person who is nosy
used to form a negative phrase after verbs like "be", "can", "have", "will", "must", etc., usually used in the short form "n't" in speech:
examples: He's not fat!
I won't tell her.
I can't go.
Don't you like her?
It isn't hard (= it is easy).
I'm just not interested.
He's not bad-looking (= he is fairly attractive).
He's not as tall as his father.

meanings.definition: used to give the next word or group of words a negative meaning:
examples: I told you not to do that.
I like most vegetables but not cabbage.
"Come and play, Dad." "Not now, Jamie."
It was Yuko who said that, not Richard.

meanings.definition: used after verbs like "be afraid", "hope", "suspect", etc. in short, negative replies:
examples: "Is he coming with us?" "I hope not."
"Are you done?" "I'm afraid not."

meanings.definition: sometimes used at the end of a statement to show that you did not mean what you have said:
examples: That was the best meal I've ever had - not!

meanings.definition: used to make a word or group of words negative, or to give a word or words an opposite meaning:
examples: Her life was not happy.
If it’s not yours, whose is it?
He’s not bad-looking (= He is attractive).
She was not only an excellent teacher but (also) a brilliant researcher (= she was both these things).
Not that I mind (= I do not mind), but why didn’t you call yesterday?

not-for-anything-in-the-world.name: not (do something) for anything (in the world)

meanings.definition: infml to not do something under any conditions:
examples: It was a fantastic party – I wouldn’t have missed it for anything.

meanings.definition: fairly good or satisfactory:
examples: "How are things?" "Not too bad, thanks."

meanings.definition: satisfactory; OK:
examples: "How are you?" "Not too bad, thanks - ready for my vacation to start!"

meanings.definition: no one:
examples: By the time I arrived there wasn't a soul there.
"Did you see anyone there?" "Not a soul."
I'd never seen the streets so empty - not a living soul out there.
"You didn't tell anyone, did you?" "Not a soul."
There wasn't a soul in sight.
It was so strange being there, knowing that there wasn't a living soul for miles around.

meanings.definition: said when a situation or event is very different from what you expected:
examples: I thought he would be sorry, but not a bit of it.

meanings.definition: not in any way:
examples: She wasn't a bit worried about the test.
"Are you getting tired?" "Not a bit."
I wasn't one bit surprised at the news, to be honest.
I don't regret leaving one bit.
"You're not upset about the party, are you?" "No, not a bit - don't worry."
He's not one bit like his brother.

meanings.definition: If there is not a chance that something will happen, it is impossible:
examples: There's not a chance that the party will win the election with a leader like him.
There was no chance of any of them accepting responsibility.
"Is there any chance of speaking to him?" "Not a chance, I'm afraid."

meanings.definition: nothing at all:
examples: We haven't heard a dicky bird from (= spoken to or received a letter from) Riza recently.

not-a-dry-eye-in-the-house.name: not a dry eye in the house

meanings.definition: used to mean that all the people at a particular place felt very emotional about what they had seen or heard and many of them were crying

not-a-hair-out-of-place.name: not a hair out of place

meanings.definition: If someone does not have a hair out of place, their appearance is very neat:
examples: She was as immaculate as ever - not a hair out of place.

meanings.definition: infmlvery annoyed or upset:
examples: The dog is sick, Jessie sprained her ankle, and the car won’t start – I am not a happy camper!

meanings.definition: not feeling completely well:
examples: I'm better than I was, but I'm still not a hundred percent.

meanings.definition: used to say that something happened when it was almost too late:
examples: Help arrived - and not a moment too soon.

meanings.definition: no money at all:
examples: It turns out his paintings aren't worth a red cent.

meanings.definition: nothing:
examples: "Did you find anything out?" "No, not a sausage."

meanings.definition: without any clothes:
examples: I don't have a stitch to wear (= I do not have anything suitable to wear) for this party tonight.
She ran down the hall to the bathroom without a stitch on (= naked).
At that time, he barely had a stitch of clothes to his name.
She strode into the room and discovered Basil sitting on the bed without a stitch on.
Neither of them had a stitch of clothing on.

meanings.definition: not at all or not even a small amount:
examples: Don't listen to her! There's not a jot of truth (= there is no truth) in what she's saying.
None of the committee's proposals will matter a jot (= they will not matter) if no one reads their report.
There wasn't a jot ofhumour in his speech.
They care not one jot for other people's feelings.
They're both dishonest. There isn't a jot of difference between them.

meanings.definition: If a situation does not add up, there is no reasonable or likely explanation for it:
examples: Why would she disappear the day before her holiday? It just doesn't add up.

meanings.definition: If a type of food or drink does not agree with you, it makes you feel slightly ill:
examples: Those onions I ate didn't agree with me.

not-all-it-s-cracked-up-to-be.name: not all it's cracked up to be

meanings.definition: not as good as something is said to be:
examples: This new radio station's not all it's cracked up to be.
Being famous isn't all it's cracked up to be.

meanings.definition: to not be as good as people have said:
examples: This software isn’t all it's cracked up to be.

meanings.definition: If a situation is not all roses, there are unpleasant things to deal with as well as the pleasant ones:
examples: Being in a relationship is not all roses, you know.

meanings.definition: not very:
examples: I'm not all that excited about going camping.

meanings.definition: not very, or not really:
examples: The game of football is not all that complicated

meanings.definition: to not become successful or important:
examples: He’s lazy, and he’ll never amount to anything.

meanings.definition: very much less:
examples: He isn't anywhere near as popular as he used to be.

meanings.definition: impossible to see or find:
examples: We searched the house, but it wasn't anywhere to be found.

meanings.definition: used as a polite reply after someone has thanked you: used to say "no" or "not" strongly:
examples: "Thanks for helping." "Not at all."
"I hope it wasn't too much hassle for you." "No, not at all."
I'm not at all happy about it.

meanings.definition: I do not mind:
examples: "Do you mind if I sit here?" "Not at all."

meanings.definition: used to say that you would never do something:
examples: I wouldn't invite her again at any price.

meanings.definition: very good:
examples: He was best in his age group - not bad, eh?

meanings.definition: to show no sign of surprise or worry when something unexpected happens:
examples: She told him she'd spent all her savings but he didn't bat an eye.

meanings.definition: to show no sign of surprise or worry when something unexpected happens:
examples: She told him she'd spent all her savings but he didn't bat an eyelid.

meanings.definition: to be annoyed about a situation:
examples: Her computer crashed an hour ago and she's lost a morning's work - she's not a happy camper at the moment.

not-be-a-patch-on.name: not be a patch on something

meanings.definition: to be much less good than something:
examples: This new washing machine isn't a patch on our old one.

meanings.definition: to be ugly or unpleasant to look at:
examples: I can tell you, first thing in the morning he's not a pretty sight.

not-be-all-fun-and-games.name: not be all fun and games

meanings.definition: If an activity is not all fun and games, parts of it are difficult or unpleasant:
examples: It's not all fun and games being a tour guide.

not-be-as-black-as-painted.name: not be as black as you are painted

meanings.definition: an old-fashioned phrase used to say that you are not as bad as people say you are, which may be considered offensive because it suggests that it is bad to have dark skin

not-be-beyond-the-wit-of-man.name: not be beyond the wit of man/someone

meanings.definition: to be possible to achieve:
examples: It shouldn't be beyond the wit of man to arrange for them both to be there at the same time.

meanings.definition: to not be stupid or easy to deceive:
examples: You don't fool me - I wasn't born yesterday.

meanings.definition: to not be fixed and able to be changed:
examples: These are just a few ideas - nothing is carved in stone yet.

not-be-cut-out-for.name: not be cut out for something

meanings.definition: to not be the right type of person for something:
examples: I'm not cut out for an office job.

meanings.definition: You say that a particular quality is not in your vocabulary if you never show it or experience it:
examples: Did you say "tact"? The word isn't in his vocabulary!

not-be-in-the-business-of.name: not be in the business of something

meanings.definition: If a person or organization is not in the business of doing something considered wrong, they do not normally do it:
examples: The intelligence agency is not in the business of routinely monitoring the activities of law-abiding citizens.

not-be-in-the-same-league.name: not be in the same league

meanings.definition: to be not as good as someone or something else:
examples: Her latest movie is quite watchable but it's not in the same league as her first two epics.

not-be-just-a-pretty-face.name: not be just a pretty face

meanings.definition: If someone is not just a pretty face, they are not only attractive but also intelligent:
examples: "How did you know that?" "Well, I'm not just a pretty face, you know."

meanings.definition: If you are not on speaking terms with someone, you refuse to speak to them because you are angry with them:
examples: They had an argument last night and now they're not on speaking terms (with each other).

meanings.definition: to be able to be changed:
examples: These are just a few ideas - nothing is set in stone yet.

not-be-short-of-a-bob-or-two.name: not be short of a bob or two

meanings.definition: to be rich:
examples: Did you see his car? He's not short of a bob or two!

not-be-cup-of-tea.name: not be someone's cup of tea

meanings.definition: If something is not your cup of tea, it is not the type of thing that you like:
examples: Thanks for inviting me, but ballet isn't really my cup of tea.

meanings.definition: If it is not your day, you are having a difficult or unpleasant day:
examples: This really isn't my day - my wallet was stolen and now I've lost my car keys.

not-be-the-boss-of.name: not be the boss of someone

meanings.definition: used, especially by children, to say that someone cannot tell another person what to do because they are not in charge of them:
examples: I used to shout "You're not the boss of me!" when my stepmum told me what to do.
Don't do it! He's not the boss of you.

not-be-the-end-of-the-world.name: not be the end of the world

meanings.definition: If something is not the end of the world, it will not cause very serious problems:
examples: I'm really hoping to win, but it won't be the end of the world if I don't.

meanings.definition: If a man is not the marrying kind, he does not want to be married. People sometimes use this phrase to mean that the man is gay.
to not be thinking clearly or using good judgment:
examples: I'm sorry, that was a stupid thing to do - I wasn't thinking straight.

meanings.definition: to not be of good quality:
examples: The food wasn't up to much.

meanings.definition: to be something you do not know much about:
examples: Programming really isn't my field - you'd better ask Phil.
Botany isn't really his field, but he likes to be able to identify plants when we go hiking.
Engineering isn't really my field - I was always more on the logistics side of things.
She's a confident singer, but surprisingly diffident when it comes to anything outside her field.
Byzantine history is totally outside my field.

meanings.definition: not to be, seem, or feel as happy or healthy as usual:
examples: Is Michelle all right? She doesn't seem quite herself at the moment.
She hasn't been herself since her dog died.
She isn't herself at the moment, not least because of her broken ankle.
The whole experience has been very tough and it's clear that Sara isn't feeling herself yet.
Georgia didn't seem herself when she came to visit last weekend.

meanings.definition: not to be, seem, or feel as happy or as healthy as usual:
examples: Is Tom all right? He doesn't seem quite himself this morning.
He hasn't been himself since a bad bout of flu last month.
Lucas wasn't himself for a long time after his sister died.
The last time I saw Greg, he didn't seem himself.
Adam stayed at home because he wasn't feeling himself that day.

meanings.definition: to be too unpleasant or frightening to think about:
examples: "What if she'd been driving faster?" "It doesn't bear thinking about."
A week without my art class to look forward to just wouldn't bear thinking about.
The effect of all this pollution scarcely bears thinking about.
He imagined sharing an office with his boss. The prospect didn't bear thinking about.
Luckily the bomb was intercepted. The consequences if it hadn't been hardly bear thinking about.

not-believe-a-word-of-it.name: not believe a word of it

meanings.definition: to not believe that something is true:
examples: He told me she was just a friend, but I don't believe a word of it!
I was telling everyone we were going to be all right while not believing a word of it.
She listened politely to what he said, but it was obvious that she didn't believe a word of it.
I told him I'd been working late, but the look on his face told me he didn't believe a word of it.
She claimed that the necklace had been her grandmother's but I didn't believe a word of it.

meanings.definition: to be very surprised:
examples: I could not believe my eyes when I saw the garden in full bloom.

meanings.definition: to be so surprised by what you see or hear that you think you are imagining it:
examples: I couldn't believe my ears when she said they were getting divorced.

meanings.definition: to be very surprised and very pleased
to not show any shock or surprise:
examples: When he was told I was expecting twins, Harry didn't even blink.

meanings.definition: If you are not bothered about something, it is not important to you or does not worry you:
examples: "Tea or coffee?" "Either - I'm not bothered."
I'm not bothered whether I go or not.
You choose something for dinner. I'm really not bothered.
Honestly, if you'd rather we didn't go to the party, I'm not bothered.
I told William to make a decision about which apartment to rent because I'm not bothered either way.
If you'd rather stay at home, I'm really not bothered.

meanings.definition: to not stop walking or running at the same speed:
examples: Without pausing for breath or breaking her stride, she pushed open the door of his private office.

not-bring-to-do-something.name: not bring yourself to do something

meanings.definition: to not be able to force yourself to do something that you think is unpleasant:
examples: I just couldn't bring myself to talk to him about it.

meanings.definition: not in any way:
examples: It wasn't as good as his first book - not by a long shot.

not-by-any-manner-of-means.name: not by any manner of means

meanings.definition: not in any way:
examples: I'm not satisfied with his excuse - not by any manner of means.

not-by-any-stretch-of-the-imagination.name: not by any stretch of the imagination

meanings.definition: even if you try, it is still difficult to accept:
examples: By no stretch of the imagination could you think of her as a real artist.

meanings.definition: to not like something or someone:
examples: I have to say I don't much care for modern music.
Your father thought she was nice but Camille and I didn't care for her.

meanings.definition: to not be at all worried by or interested in something:
examples: They can say what they like. I don't give a fig.

meanings.definition: to not be worried about other people's opinions or actions:
examples: I'm leaving and I don't give a sod (about) what Margaret thinks.
She doesn't care a sod about her reputation.

meanings.definition: to not care about something or someone in any way
to not care about something or someone:
examples: I don't give two hoots what she thinks.

meanings.definition: If you say that something does not come cheap, you mean that it is of good quality and is therefore expensive:
examples: If you want a qualified accountant, their services don't come cheap.

meanings.definition: in addition to something wrong or unpleasant you have done:
examples: Not content with having upset my parents, he then insulted my sister!

meanings.definition: If behaviour is not cricket, it is not fair, honest or moral:
examples: It's just not cricket to lie to a friend.

meanings.definition: to not be able to deal with problems or difficulties satisfactorily:
examples: We were playing against a more experienced team, and we just couldn't cut it.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to never come back to a place:
examples: Never darken my door again!

meanings.definition: to do something that is likely to have a bad effect on you or on another person:
examples: You're not well, and you're not doing yourself any favors by taking on extra work.
The government isn't doing the families of the victims any favors by hiding the truth about what really happened.

meanings.definition: to do something that is likely to have a bad effect on you or on another person:
examples: You're not well, and you're not doing yourself any favours by taking on extra work.
The government isn't doing the families of the victims any favours by hiding the truth about what really happened.

meanings.definition: If something is not said or treated lightly, it is said or treated in a serious way, after great thought:
examples: Accusations like these from a top minister are not made lightly.
She is a psychopath, and I don't use the term lightly.
That risks putting people out of work, which you certainly shouldn't do lightly.
Having a child wasn't a decision we took lightly.
I have complete confidence in this guy. And I don't say that lightly.

meanings.definition: If someone does not do things by halves, they put a lot of effort and enthusiasm into doing things, often more than is necessary:
examples: "I didn't realize you were decorating the whole house." "Oh, we don't do things by halves round here."

meanings.definition: If you say that something does not enter into something else, it is not an important or necessary part of it:
examples: The Council's opinion doesn't enter into it - it's up to us to make the decision.
Potential delays do not enter into the prosecutor's decisions on whether or not to seek the death penalty.
A jury's own prejudices should not enter into their verdicts.
We really enjoyed helping the old people. Virtue didn't enter into it.
She claims that acting is her passion and that money doesn't enter into it.

meanings.definition: used for saying that someone or something is slightly different from a particular way of describing them or it:
examples: He's not exactly good-looking, but he has a certain attraction.
It's not exactly the best picture of them, ut it's the best of the lot.
She wasn't exactly typecast as an ageing socialite, but it came close.
The system's not hard to learn but it's not exactly intuitive.
The book wasn't exactly dull, but I certainly wouldn't describe it as a page-turner.

meanings.definition: used for saying that something is not completely true:
examples: "So you gave her your iPod?" "Not exactly, I lent it to her."
"So the British won the war?" "Well, not exactly."
"You were planning on leaving the area." "Not exactly. I planned on coming back eventually."
Was he the first to cross the Sierra Nevada mountains? Not exactly - Native Americans traversed the mountain range regularly before Europeans arrived.
Has my retirement been relaxing? Well, I've started building a new house, so not exactly.

meanings.definition: used for saying that something is the opposite of a particular way of describing it:
examples: Answer the question - it's not exactly difficult.
Journalists aren't exactly known for their compassion.
Smoked salmon and fresh figs aren't exactly the kind of things we eat most days.
He's a drug dealer and a liar. Not exactly what I was hoping for in a boyfriend.
Our camper van's not exactly speedy, but we love it.

meanings.definition: to not feel any pain:
examples: "Did it hurt?" "Not at all - I didn't feel a thing."
I must have run into something, given the bruise, but I didn't feel a thing.
The injection won't hurt at all. You won't feel a thing.
I was badly injured, but the shock meant that I didn't feel a thing.
He can walk over hot coals apparently without feeling a thing.

meanings.definition: used to say that you do not think or do something at all:
examples: I don't believe that story for a moment.

meanings.definition: certainly not:
examples: I'm not suggesting for one minute that she meant to cause any trouble.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is unpleasant, and will upset people who are squeamish:
examples: "The Silence of the Lambs" is an entertaining movie but is not for the squeamish.

meanings.definition: never; not in any situation:
examples: If I took that job I'd have to leave the kids and I wouldn't do that for the world.

meanings.definition: including:
examples: This is where we keep all the books, not forgetting the magazines and newspapers.
In London I was living above a bar and it was constant traffic noise, day and night, not forgetting police sirens and people arguing in the street below.
With its style and romance (not forgetting its coffee and croissants), the capital has been a favorite holiday destination for years.
Once you've paid the solicitor and the estate agent (not forgetting the removals people) you may not have much money left over for such luxuries.
With a big garden there are so many jobs to do: the weeding and the cutting back, not forgetting the watering during dry spells.

not-get-a-word-in-edgeways.name: not get a word in edgeways

meanings.definition: to not be able to say anything because someone else is talking all the time:
examples: Rosa was talking so much that nobody else could get a word in edgeways!

not-get-a-word-in-edgewise.name: not get a word in edgewise

meanings.definition: to not be able to say anything because someone else is talking all the time:
examples: Roz was talking so much that nobody else could get a word in edgewise!

meanings.definition: to not make progress toward a goal:
examples: His parents tried to talk him out of joining the army, but they didn’t get anywhere.

meanings.definition: When you say that you can't get over something, you mean that you are very surprised by it:
examples: I can't get over the way he behaved at your party - it was appalling!

meanings.definition: to not be able to start doing what you intend to do:
examples: We need financing for this project, but we can’t get to first base with the banks.

meanings.definition: If you are not getting/going anywhere, you are not improving or advancing a particular situation:
examples: I've been sorting out my study all day, but it's such a mess I don't feel I'm getting anywhere.

meanings.definition: If you don't/couldn't give a monkey's about something, you are not at all worried by it:
examples: "Chrissie won't like it." "I don't give a monkey's."

meanings.definition: to not be interested in or worried about something or someone:
examples: I don't give a shit what he thinks.

meanings.definition: to not be interested in or worried about something or someone:
examples: I couldn't give a tinker's cuss about what they think.

meanings.definition: to not be interested in or worried about something or someone:
examples: I don't give a tinker's damn about what they think.

not-give-much-for-chances.name: not give much for someone's chances

meanings.definition: to not believe someone will succeed:
examples: I wouldn't give much for his chances in the next race.

not-give-the-time-of-day.name: not give someone the time of day

meanings.definition: to not be friendly to someone and not speak to or help that person:
examples: He kept pestering me to go out with him, but I wouldn’t give him the time of day.

meanings.definition: to think that something will not succeed:
examples: I wouldn't give tuppence for their chances of winning the match.

meanings.definition: to not change your opinion:
examples: She's definite that she wants to do it, and she'll not give an inch, however hard you try to persuade her.

meanings.definition: used as a way of saying you do not care about something, especially the annoying things that someone else is doing or saying:
examples: I don't give a damn what he thinks of me!

meanings.definition: to not be worried at all by something:
examples: I don't give a toss what he thinks.

meanings.definition: If something might/would not go amiss, it would be useful and might help to improve a situation:
examples: A word of apology might not go amiss.
A sense of proportion would not go amiss in all of this.
A bit more time spent on preparation wouldn't have gone amiss.
I think a little advice on healthy living wouldn't go amiss.
A few more hooks for bags and coats might not go amiss.

meanings.definition: to dislike something:
examples: I don't go much on white wine.

meanings.definition: to not start to think about or discuss a subject:
examples: "Then there's the guilt I feel about leaving her for seven hours every day." "Don't even go there!"

meanings.definition: not nearly as:
examples: It wasn't half as good as that other restaurant we went to.
It's not half as easy as it looks.

meanings.definition: used in spoken English to express a positive statement more strongly:
examples: It wasn't half crowded in the club last night (= it was very crowded).
She didn't half shout at him (= she shouted a lot at him).
"You enjoyed yourself last night, didn't you?" "Not half !" (= Very much!)

not-have-a-bad-dishonest-racist-etc-bone.name: not have a bad/dishonest/racist, etc. bone in your body

meanings.definition: to not be bad, dishonest, racist, etc. in any way:
examples: Jimmy did not have a bad bone in his body.
He respects the truth. I don't think he has a dishonest bone in his body.
You can't insist that you do not have a racist bone in your body and then make speeches about Britain being turned into a "foreign land".
She can't understand my need for children because she doesn't have a maternal bone in her body.

not-have-a-bar-of.name: not have a bar of something

meanings.definition: to refuse to accept or have anything to do with something:
examples: Karen called her mother and asked her to come and stay, but Mum wouldn't have a bar of it.
She wants reform but voters are not having a bar of it.
The baby would fall asleep on me but wouldn't have a bar of the bassinet.
One of my sons is doing very well at karate but my other one is not having a bar of it.

meanings.definition: to have no money:
examples: He doesn't have a bean, other than what we give him.

not-have-a-cat-in-hell-s-chance.name: not have a cat in hell's chance

meanings.definition: to be completely unable to achieve something:
examples: They haven't a cat in hell's chance of getting over the mountain in weather like this.

not-have-a-civil-word-to-say-about.name: not have a civil word to say about someone

meanings.definition: to not be able to think of anything good to say about someone
to have no knowledge about something, or to be unable to remember something:
examples: I don’t have a clue what I did with my baseball glove.
He doesn’t have a clue about how to fix a car.

not-have-a-clue-have-no-clue.name: not have a clue/have no clue

meanings.definition: to be completely unable to guess, understand, or deal with something:
examples: "Who invented algebra?" "I don't have a clue."
Don't ask your father which key to press - he hasn't got a clue about computers.

not-have-a-hope-in-hell.name: not have a hope in hell

meanings.definition: to have no possibility of doing or achieving something:
examples: We were so outclassed - we didn't have a hope in hell of winning.

not-have-a-leg-to-stand-on.name: not have a leg to stand on

meanings.definition: to be in a situation in which you cannot prove something:
examples: If you have no witnesses, you don't have a leg to stand on.

meanings.definition: to have no good arguments to support your position:
examples: They settled the lawsuit because they did not have a leg to stand on.

not-have-a-penny-to-name.name: not have a penny to your name

meanings.definition: to be very poor

not-have-a-pot-to-piss-in.name: not have a pot to piss in

meanings.definition: to be very poor:
examples: Any help we can offer them will be appreciated. They don't have a pot to piss in.

meanings.definition: to have no chance of succeeding:
examples: She hasn't a prayer of winning the competition.

not-have-a-snowball-s-chance-in-hell.name: not have a snowball's chance in hell

meanings.definition: to have no chance of succeeding:
examples: If he can't afford a good lawyer, he doesn't have a snowball's chance in hell of winning the case.

not-have-a-the-ghost-of-a-chance.name: not have a/the ghost of a chance

meanings.definition: to have no chance at all:
examples: They don't have a ghost of a chance of winning.

not-have-any-concept-have-no-concept-of.name: not have any concept/have no concept of something

meanings.definition: to not understand about something:
examples: I don't think you have any concept of the pain you have caused her.
Nobody here has any concept of what a good diet consists of.
The people who make these laws don't have any concept of how normal people live.
People here seem to have no concept of the rules of the road.
She's just a child - she has no concept of how much things cost.

meanings.definition: to be completely unwilling or to refuse:
examples: I asked him to help out, but he wasn't having any of it.

meanings.definition: to not be very intelligent:
examples: People think he hasn't got much upstairs but in fact he is very intelligent when it comes to computers.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something:
examples: "Is she going to stay?" "I haven't the faintest idea."
I don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about!
Neither of them had the faintest idea of how to be a parent.
As to what I'm going to do now, I haven't the faintest idea.
I don't think Steve had the faintest idea about what was happening around him.

meanings.definition: to not know or understand something at all:
examples: I didn't have the foggiest idea what he was talking about.

not-have-the-heart-to.name: not have the heart to do something

meanings.definition: to feel unable to do something because you feel it would be unkind:
examples: She asked me to go with her and I didn't have the heart to refuse.

meanings.definition: to lack the desire or strength to do something:
examples: I didn’t have the heart to tell him that his injury would prevent him from playing football.

meanings.definition: to not know at all:
examples: "Who's that?" "I haven't the remotest idea."

not-have-the-stomach-for.name: not have the stomach for something

meanings.definition: to not feel brave or determined enough to do something unpleasant:
examples: I didn't have the stomach for another fight.

not-hear-a-peep-out-of.name: not hear a peep out of someone

meanings.definition: to not hear someone speak or make a sound, especially when this is surprising:
examples: She hasn't heard a peep out of him in more than 10 days.
We didn't hear a peep out of them until Sunday morning.
When the other couple lived here, we never heard a peep out of them.
There's an election next month and we've barely heard a peep out of any of the candidates.
The kids were in the games room and we didn't hear a peep out of them all evening.

meanings.definition: If you say you will not hear of something, you mean you will not allow it, usually when you want to do something good for someone:
examples: I wanted to pay but she wouldn't hear of it.

not-hear-the-end-last-of.name: not hear the end/last of something

meanings.definition: to be told repeatedly about something:
examples: We'll never hear the last of it if they win that competition.

not-hold-a-candle-to.name: not hold a candle to someone/something

meanings.definition: to not be as good as someone or something else:
examples: Her latest book can’t hold a candle to her earlier works.

meanings.definition: to not approve of an idea or activity

not-in-a-month-of-sundays.name: not in a month of Sundays

meanings.definition: If you say that something will not happen in a month of Sundays, you mean that it is very unlikely to happen:
examples: He's never going to get that finished in a month of Sundays!

meanings.definition: If you say you know someone but not in the biblical sense, you mean you have not had sex with them:
examples: "Did you know her?" "Yes - not in the biblical sense, of course."

meanings.definition: not in any way:
examples: "Are you dissatisfied with the results?" "Not in the least."

meanings.definition: not nearly as good as something or someone else:
examples: She's a brilliant golfer - I'm not in the same league.

meanings.definition: not at all:
examples: "Does it worry you?" "Not in the slightest."
It doesn't bother him in the slightest.
It wouldn't surprise me in the slightest to learn that Johnson was involved.
He's let it be known that he wasn't offended in the slightest by the remark.
In any case, she wouldn't have cared in the slightest if he hadn't turned up.
She isn't the world's best singer and yet for this show, it doesn't matter in the slightest.

meanings.definition: to have never met someone and not know anything about them:
examples: Why should she lend me money? She doesn't know me from Adam.

not-know-the-first-thing-about.name: not know the first thing about something

meanings.definition: to know nothing about a subject:
examples: I'm afraid I don't know the first thing about car engines.

meanings.definition: to know nothing about something:
examples: I don’t know the first thing about physics.

not-know-the-half-of-it.name: not know the half of it

meanings.definition: If someone does not know the half of it, they know that a situation is bad but do not know how serious it is:
examples: "I hear things aren't going too well at work." "You don't know the half of it!"

not-know-the-meaning-of-the-word.name: not know the meaning of the word

meanings.definition: If you are talking about a quality or an activity and you say that someone doesn't know the meaning of the word, you mean they do not have that quality or have no experience of that activity:
examples: Work? He doesn't know the meaning of the word!
And the irony of Phil talking about ethics. He doesn't know the meaning of the word.

not-know-what-has-hit.name: not know what has hit you

meanings.definition: to be shocked and surprised because something unpleasant suddenly and unexpectedly happens to you:
examples: You wait till he starts working for Michael - he won't know what's hit him!

meanings.definition: to be suddenly shocked and confused by something:
examples: When he said I was fired, I didn’t know what hit me.

meanings.definition: to feel shocked or confused because something bad has happened to you suddenly when you were not expecting it

not-know-what-sees-in.name: not know what someone sees in someone/something

meanings.definition: to not understand why someone likes a particular person or thing:
examples: He's so boring - I don't know what she sees in him.

not-know-where-to-put.name: not know where to put yourself

meanings.definition: to feel very embarrassed:
examples: And then he started to sing. Well, I didn't know where to put myself.

not-know-where-which-way-to-turn.name: not know where/which way to turn

meanings.definition: to not know what to do or who to ask for help:
examples: When both her parents died, she didn't know which way to turn.

not-know-whether-to-laugh-or-cry.name: not know whether to laugh or cry

meanings.definition: to not know how to react in a particular situation:
examples: When she told me they were getting married I didn't know whether to laugh or cry.

not-know-whether-are-coming-or-going.name: not know whether you are coming or going

meanings.definition: to be in a very confused state:
examples: I'm so busy, I don't know whether I'm coming or going.

not-know-arse-from-elbow.name: not know your arse from your elbow

meanings.definition: an offensive phrase meaning to be stupid and unable to understand very simple things

not-know-ass-from-elbow.name: not know your ass from your elbow

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to be stupid and unable to understand very simple things:
examples: My boss has proven time and again that he doesn't know his ass from his elbow.

meanings.definition: to fail or be unsuccessful very soon:
examples: You won't last long in your job if you carry on being so rude to the customers.
He wouldn't last five minutes in the police force - it's far too tough for him.

meanings.definition: to not make any effort:
examples: He just watches TV and never lifts a finger to help with the dishes.

meanings.definition: to not make any effort to help:
examples: He never lifts a finger to help with the housework.

meanings.definition: certainly not!:
examples: "Do you want to come running with me?" "Not likely!"
"Are you coming to the extra science class?" "Not likely!"
"Are you going to ask her on another date?" "Oh, not likely."
"Do you want to help Peter clean his car?" "Not likely."

meanings.definition: If someone is not long for this world, they will die soon.
to not change a situation in any way:
examples: You can ask him again if you want, but it won't make any difference - he'll still say no.
It makes no difference where you put the plants - they won't grow in this soil.

meanings.definition: to not be important:
examples: It doesn't matter tuppence what you think.

meanings.definition: to say what you mean clearly and directly, even if you upset people by doing this:
examples: The report does not mince words, describing the situation as "ludicrous".

meanings.definition: to say what you mean as clearly and directly as possible:
examples: The report does not mince words, describing the situation as extremely serious.

meanings.definition: said about someone who never fails to notice and take advantage of a good opportunity:
examples: Jonathan doesn't miss a trick! If there's a bargain to be had, he'll find it.

meanings.definition: said when something you failed to see or experience was not important or special:
examples: "I didn't manage to see that programme." "Don't worry, you didn't miss much."

meanings.definition: to not pause or show any uncertainty, usually when this is surprising: to do something without any mistakes or failures:
examples: "That's what I thought," replied Olivia, without missing a beat.
He lost the arguments and, without skipping a beat, went on to implement the very policies he had just lobbied against.
The player hasn't missed a beat this year, scoring three touchdowns in his first three games.

meanings.definition: to stay completely still:
examples: She sat without moving a muscle as the nurse put the needle in.

meanings.definition: not very good:
examples: His last book wasn't much cop.

meanings.definition: a lot less:
examples: She's not nearly as beautiful as you said she was.
My cold isn't nearly so bad as it was.
In fact, the whole experience isn't nearly as scary as might be imagined.
The issue isn't nearly as clear-cut as people think.
I think you'll find the process isn't nearly so bad as you're expecting.
Though it sold more copies than her first novel, it isn't nearly as funny.

meanings.definition: much less than you want or need:
examples: There's not nearly enough food for all these people!
There still wasn't nearly enough evidence to convict him.
There's not nearly enough money in the system.
Not nearly enough attention is paid to these matters.
With so many children in the classroom, there's not nearly enough time to get through the syllabus.

meanings.definition: said as a way of strongly refusing someone's suggestion or request:
examples: "So you're going to bring Kev, are you?" "Not on your life!"

meanings.definition: not very intelligent:
examples: He was not over-bright, but he was good at sport and popular with the other boys.
Her first children's book told the story of a not overbright troll and his best friend.
Our not over-bright dog often forgot how to play fetch, and regularly growled at his own reflection in the mirror.
He engineered a meeting between her and his attractive but not over-bright son.

meanings.definition: to not claim something that is false:
examples: I don't pretend to be an expert on the subject.
I don't pretend to understand his motives.
He was very honest in insisting that he didn't pretend to know all the answers.
She doesn't pretend to think that her son is perfect.
The book doesn't pretend to offer a balanced discussion of the issue.

meanings.definition: to speak in an honest way without trying to be kind:
examples: Her image is that of an investigative reporter who doesn't pull any punches.
She doesn't pull her punches when talking about lazy people.
My father is very direct and pulls no punches.

meanings.definition: to not make any mistakes

not-put-it-past-to-do.name: not put it past someone (to do something)

meanings.definition: to not be surprised if someone does something bad, because it is a typical thing for that person to do:
examples: Perhaps Helena told him - I wouldn't put it past her.

meanings.definition: If you cannot put a book down, you are unable to stop reading it until you reach the end:
examples: It was so exciting from the first page I couldn't put it down.

meanings.definition: used to express that you are not certain about something:
examples: I don't quite know what to say.
I didn't quite catch what he said.
I still don't quite understand what's happening.
She didn't quite know what all the fuss was about.
I'm afraid I didn't quite grasp the rules.
"Is this the color you were thinking of?" "Not quite? I think it's close, though."
She didn't quite get it at first, but after I'd explained what I was doing, she got a better idea.

meanings.definition: too rude or offensive to be said again:
examples: What he said next is not repeatable on TV.
What she said to Maria isn't repeatable in polite company.
He said a lot of stuff on the tennis courts and, to be honest, most of it isn't repeatable here.
He used a very emphatic phrase to describe the president - not repeatable here.
Some of the comments she made weren't even repeatable.
It was a really funny joke but it's not repeatable.

meanings.definition: to not say anything, especially to not complain or protest: to be very nervous and easily frightened:
examples: People want to keep their jobs, so nobody says boo.
If the person in the image had been a man, nobody would have said boo.
You didn't say boo to me about going to your mother's this weekend.
She's actually a shy wallflower who wouldn't say boo to a goose.
I like artists that make bold statements and challenge "good taste", rather than those who are afraid to say boo.

meanings.definition: to say nothing: to be very nervous and easily frightened
examples: You didn't say boo to me about going to your mother's this weekend.

meanings.definition: to not care that something you do is morally wrong or likely to have bad results:
examples: He wouldn't scruple to cheat his own mother if there was money in it for him.
She did not scruple to bend the truth if it suited her.
Notoriously mean with his own money, he didn't scruple to take it from others.
She did not scruple to use questionable means to defend her reputation.
He certainly didn't scruple to betray his friends when push came to shove.

meanings.definition: to have all your attention on something and therefore be unable to consider other things:
examples: The government cannot see beyond next year's election.

not-see-hide-nor-hair-of.name: not see hide nor hair of someone

meanings.definition: to not see someone at all over a period of time:
examples: I haven't seen hide nor hair of her since last Friday.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone leaving quickly in order to avoid something:
examples: If you let him know that Margaret's coming, you won't see him for dust.

not-see-the-forest-for-the-trees.name: not see the forest for the trees

meanings.definition: to be unable to get a general understanding of a situation because you are too worried about the details

not-see-the-wood-for-the-trees.name: not see the wood for the trees

meanings.definition: to be unable to get a general understanding of a situation because you are too worried about the details

not-see-look-etc-beyond-past-the-end-of-.name: not see/look, etc. beyond/past the end of your nose

meanings.definition: to only consider what is very close to you, what is very obvious, or what is happening in the near future:
examples: In financial planning you need to look beyond the end of your nose.
I don't think his vision for the company goes beyond the end of his nose.

not-set-the-world-on-fire.name: not set the world on fire

meanings.definition: to not be very exciting or successful:
examples: He has a nice enough voice but he's not going to set the world on fire.

meanings.definition: to be difficult for someone to agree with or accept:
examples: The principal's decision did not sit well with many parents.

meanings.definition: to not sleep at all:
examples: I didn't sleep a wink last night with all that noise.

meanings.definition: used to refer back to something that has been mentioned, saying that it is less true for someone or something else :
examples: If you like it, fine, but for me, not so much.
I'm ready to start eating more healthily. My husband, not so much!

not-so-much-as.name: not so much something as something

meanings.definition: If you say that something is not so much one thing as something else, you mean it is more the second thing:
examples: They're not so much lovers as friends.
I don't feel angry so much as sad.

meanings.definition: used for saying that something is good:
examples: It was a not so shabby week for the team, who had three wins.

meanings.definition: to not become involved in something unpleasant or bad:
examples: These were top lawyers, the kind who wouldn't normally soil their hands with police work or criminal law.

meanings.definition: to refuse to accept bad or silly behaviour:
examples: The new teacher won't stand any nonsense.

meanings.definition: to have very little patience with people who you think are stupid or have stupid ideas

not-take-a-blind-bit-of-notice.name: not take a blind bit of notice

meanings.definition: to pay no attention to something:
examples: He didn't take a blind bit of notice of what I said.

meanings.definition: to not like something:
examples: After years of being looked after by his mother, he didn't take kindly to being told to cook for himself.

meanings.definition: to act or happen over a short period of time:
examples: I'm just going to the shops - I won't take long.
It didn't take long before we realized our mistake.
It didn't take the police long to catch the thief.
It doesn't take long to run up a huge bill in a place like this.
Loading the trucks didn't take long.

meanings.definition: to refuse to be treated badly by someone:
examples: He can't treat you like that! Surely you're not going to take that lying down!

meanings.definition: to complain about a situation rather than accepting it:
examples: I can’t take that criticism lying down.

not-take-eyes-off.name: not take your eyes off someone/something

meanings.definition: to not stop looking at someone or something:
examples: He was so handsome - I couldn't take my eyes off him.

meanings.definition: used when answering a question to mean that, judging from the information you have, the answer is no:
examples: "Is she especially unhappy at school?" "Not that I know of."

meanings.definition: used to say you are not suggesting something: used to say you do not think something is important:
examples: She wouldn't tell me how much it cost - not that I was really interested.
Not that I mind, but why didn't you call yesterday?

meanings.definition: not socially acceptable:
examples: Smoking during a meal is not the done thing.

not-the-end-of-the-world.name: not the end of the world

meanings.definition: not the worst thing that could happen:
examples: We’re hoping to win, but if we finish second it won’t be the end of the world.

meanings.definition: used for emphasis with nouns:
examples: I haven't the least idea (= I do not know) who he was.
She hasn't the least interest (= she has no interest) in the project.

meanings.definition: not as good:
examples: You can make shortbread with margarine instead of butter, but it isn't the same.

meanings.definition: not socially acceptable:
examples: Smoking during a meal is not the thing to do.

meanings.definition: to have a low opinion of someone or something:
examples: I don’t think much of this techno music.

meanings.definition: to be unable to use your mind in an effective way:
examples: I was so tired, I couldn't think straight.

meanings.definition: to do something immediately, without considering if it is a good idea:
examples: They didn't think twice about laying off hundreds of employees.

meanings.definition: not wanting someone else to do something better than you:
examples: Pat was wearing an outrageous purple dress, so, not to be outdone, I put on my new gold suit.

meanings.definition: If you say that something, especially an amount of money, is not to be sneezed at, you mean that it is a large enough amount to be worth having:
examples: Well, a five percent pay increase means an extra $700 a year, which is not to be sneezed at!

meanings.definition: valuable or worth having:
examples: A £2 million profit is not to be sniffed at.

meanings.definition: used when you want to emphasize something that you are adding to a list:
examples: He's one of the kindest and most intelligent, not to mention handsome, men I know.

meanings.definition: and something else, even more than the first thing:
examples: Bananas were scarce, not to mention mangoes.

not-to-put-too-fine-a-point-on.name: not to put too fine a point on

meanings.definition: to be completely direct and honest:
examples: I think she's wrong - not to put too fine a point on it.

meanings.definition: and possibly even:
examples: It would be unwise, not to say stupid, to leave your first job after only six months.

meanings.definition: said to show that you are not worried or upset because something has gone wrong or something unexpected has happened:
examples: Not to worry - maybe you'll be able to come next week instead.

meanings.definition: to not trust someone at all:
examples: Make sure you tell him as little as possible about what happened. And don't trust him an inch.
Politicians promise all sorts of things but I wouldn't trust them an inch.
She can be charming and persuasive, but I don't trust her one inch.

meanings.definition: to not show any emotion when you are told something bad or when something bad happens:
examples: I was expecting him to be horrified when he heard the cost but he didn't turn a hair.

meanings.definition: not before a particular time or event:
examples: We didn't eat until past midnight.
Once he starts painting a room he won't stop until it's done.
He didn't learn to read until he was twenty.
It wasn't until August that we finally moved into the house.
You don't have to commit to the scheme until you've read all the documentation.

meanings.definition: If someone does not waste words, they talk only about what is important using as few words as possible:
examples: He explained the whole system in about 30 seconds - he doesn't waste words, does he?

not-worth-the-paper-is-printed-written-o.name: not worth the paper something is printed/written on

meanings.definition: If a document or agreement is not worth the paper it is written/printed on, it is of very little value.
a bad day when things do not happen as you would like them to:
examples: I missed my bus and forgot my glasses – I guess it’s just not my day.

meanings.definition: not feeling well or not acting in your usual way:
examples: I'm sorry for crying – I'm not myself today.

not-make-heads-or-tails-of.name: (not) make heads or tails of something

meanings.definition: to not be able to understand something at all:
examples: We couldn’t make heads or tails of your directions.

meanings.definition: (not) true:
examples: If that is the case then I will be very disappointed.
Tom says that they don't have enough staff but I'd be surprised if that's the case.
If these people needed money, we could help them out, but that isn't the case.
She said they can't afford to heat the home, and if that's the case, it's terrible.
He claimed he was the most qualified candidate for the job, but that simply wasn't the case.

meanings.definition:
→

examples: There has been a large increase in the number of organizations in the not-for-profit sector.
They concluded that the not-for-profits are basically managed well.

meanings.definition: nonprofit adjective :
examples: Bethel New Life is a not-for-profit community development founded by Bethel Lutheran Church.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         nonprofit noun :
examples: This section deals with the tax-exempt status of not-for-profit organizations.

meanings.definition: the idea that a product, system, etc. that was developed somewhere else cannot be as good as one that a company, etc. develops itself:
examples: Many organizations suffer from the not-invented-here syndrome; developers like to invent and are not keen on re-use.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is better than anything you could imagine or hope for:
examples: Never in my wildest dreams did I imagine that one day I would run a marathon.

meanings.definition: to have all the basic things you need to lead a satisfactory life:
examples: As children we never wanted for anything.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize how small an amount is:
examples: There are beautiful mountains not more than ten minutes' drive away.

meanings.definition: very little, or nothing that is important or interesting:
examples: I had nothing much to do that day.
"What did she have to say?" "Not much, really."

meanings.definition: the state of being important and deserving attention, because of being very good or interesting:
examples: A restaurant has to have sufficient notability to be included in the guidebook.
It was a burning desire for fame and notability that drove him on.

meanings.definition: important and deserving attention, because of being very good or interesting:
examples: a notable collection of rare plants
Getting both sides to agree was a notable achievement.
This attractive building is particularly notable for its woodland setting.

meanings.definition: an important or famous person:
examples: Other notables among his pupils were the kings of Saudi Arabia and Thailand.

meanings.definition: important and deserving attention:
examples: She worked with many notable musicians.

meanings.definition: especially or most importantly:
examples: The company is beginning to attract investors, most notably big Japanese banks.

meanings.definition: to an important degree, or in a way that can or should be noticed:
examples: The newspapers are notably biased.

meanings.definition: related to the work of a notary public (= a type of lawyer who has the legal authority to see that documents are correctly signed or that they are true copies):
examples: notarial services
notarial fees

meanings.definition: the act or process of having a public official such as a lawyer sign a letter or other document :
examples: We cannot accept applications without prior notarization.
The state no longer charges a fee for paper notorizations.

meanings.definition: If a letter or other document is notarized, it is signed by a notary public:
examples: a notarized affidavit
The airline requires children travelling alone to have a notarized letter of consent from one or both parents.

meanings.definition: if a document is notarized, it is signed by a notary public in order to make it official or legal:
examples: Your request must be signed and notarized.
a notarized document/affidavit

meanings.definition: a system of written symbols used especially in mathematics or to represent musical notes:
examples: musical/scientific notation

meanings.definition: the system of written symbols used esp. in mathematics
Musical notation is the system of symbols used to write music.
a V-shaped cut in a hard surface:
examples: The stick has two notches, one at each end.

meanings.definition: a hole or mark on the edge of a body part:
examples: a cardiac notch

meanings.definition: an imaginary point or position in a system of comparing values, where a higher position is better and a lower position is worse:
examples: Among current players, she is rated a notch above (= is better than) the rest.

meanings.definition: to cut a notch in something
a cut in a hard surface:
examples: The rope had jammed in a V-shaped notch.

meanings.definition: an imaginary point or position in a comparison of amounts or values; degree:
examples: Suddenly he raised his voice a notch.

meanings.definition: to achieve or keep a record of something:
examples: Her band notched another Grammy Award last night.

meanings.definition: to cut a notch in a hard surface:
examples: He notched the end of the beam.

meanings.definition: a point or position in a system that is used to compare values:
examples: The unemployment rate crept up another notch in September.

meanings.definition: to achieve something:
examples: She has recently notched up her third win at a major ski event.

meanings.definition: to achieve something:
examples: Interest in the stock helped it notch up an 8p rise to 277.25p.
This year she'll have notched up 20 years with the firm.
