a short piece of writing:
examples: He left a note to say he would be home late.
There's a note on the door saying when the shop will open again.

meanings.definition: a short explanation or an extra piece of information that is given at the bottom of a page, at the back of a book, etc.:
examples: For more information see Note 3.

meanings.definition: a single sound at a particular level, usually in music, or a written symbol that represents this sound:
examples: high/low notes
She played three long notes on the piano.
The engine noise suddenly changed its note and rose to a whine.

meanings.definition: an emotion or a way of expressing something:
examples: There was a note of caution in her letter.
His speech struck just the right note.
The meeting ended on an optimistic note.

meanings.definition: a piece of paper money:
examples: a €20 note
He took a wad of notes from his pocket.

meanings.definition: importance, or the fact that something deserves attention:
examples: There was nothing of note in the latest report.

meanings.definition: to notice something:
examples: They noted the consumers' growing demand for quicker service.
Please note (that) we will be closed on Saturday.
Note how easy it is to release the catch quickly.

meanings.definition: to give your attention to something by discussing it or making a written record of it:
examples: He said the weather was beyond our control, noting that last summer was one of the hottest on record.
In the article, she notes several cases of medical incompetence.

meanings.definition: a short piece of writing:
examples: a handwritten note
Make a note to phone him (= Write it down so you remember).

meanings.definition: A note is a piece of information that you write down while something is happening:
examples: Be sure to take notes in class (= write down information).

meanings.definition: a single sound, esp. in music, or a written symbol which represents this sound:
examples: Her soprano voice intoned the low, first notes of the song.

meanings.definition: fig. Note also means the particular quality of an emotion or feeling:
examples: The meeting ended on an optimistic note.

meanings.definition: importance or fame:
examples: There was nothing of note in the report.

meanings.definition: to take notice of, give attention to, or make a record of something:
examples: Please note that we will be closed on Saturday.

meanings.definition: a piece of paper money:
examples: a €500 note
He gave me £100 in £10 notes.
I had no change; I only had notes.
Can you change a €20 note?

meanings.definition: a written agreement that one person, organization, etc. will pay a particular amount of money to another person, etc. by a particular date:
examples: The note for your loan comes due on 1 June.
a two-year note

meanings.definition: a short letter, or something that you write down in order to remember something:
examples: I'll send you a note about this but please do put it on your calendars.
The bank said in a note to investors that the operation would make strategic sense.
I got a note from the CEO congratulating me on the deal.
I made a note to review the matter in a month's time.

meanings.definition: a short official document:
examples: They can get out of the requirement with a note from their doctor confirming their diagnosis.
Please check the goods before signing the delivery note.

meanings.definition: to notice or realize something:
examples: They noted the consumers' growing demand for quicker service.
Please note that we will be closed on Saturday.

meanings.definition: to mention something so that people are aware of it:
examples: In her report, she notes several cases of poor practice on the part of management.

meanings.definition: a small folded sheet of paper or card, usually with a picture on the front, inside which you write a short letter:
examples: a box of note cards

meanings.definition: a small piece of card or thick paper that you write notes on for speeches, school work, etc.:
examples: Put each question on a note card, with the answer on the back.

meanings.definition: an arrangement in which a group of banks agree to find buyers for notes (= agreements to pay a certain amount of money) from a borrower if the borrower is not able to sell them. If the banks cannot find buyers, they agree to buy the notes themselves:
examples: A note issuance facility is a facility provided by banks to companies who wish to raise capital by issuing short-term securities or "notes".

meanings.definition: the act by a government or bank of printing an amount of new paper money and making it available to use:
examples: Neither the Federal Reserve Act nor any other law ever explicitly established note issue in the United States as a monopoly of the federal government.

meanings.definition: the total value of paper money in a country at a particular time:
examples: After 1931 Britain left the Gold Standard, and the note issue was no longer backed by gold.

meanings.definition: an offer to buy bonds or other forms of debt:
examples: The company will use proceeds from a recent $200 million note issue for general corporate purposes.

meanings.definition: a document that relates to money that a company owes, especially money that must be paid back within a year or less:
examples: About $111 million in notes payable will be canceled.

meanings.definition: a document that relates to money that is owed to a company, especially money that must be paid back within a year or less:
examples: The average interest rate charged on notes receivable was 8.7%.

meanings.definition: to write something so that you do not forget it:
examples: I noted down his phone number.

meanings.definition: to write something so that you do not forget it:
examples: I noted down the time and place of the meeting.

meanings.definition: information added to a company's accounts that explains something in them:
examples: In addition, five and a half pages of notes to the accounts give valuable extra information.

meanings.definition: a book of plain paper or paper with lines, for writing on:
examples: She was jotting things down in a little notebook.

meanings.definition: a very small computer that you can carry easily
a book of paper for writing on:
examples: She wrote everything down in her notebook.

meanings.definition: a small, light computer
a very small computer that you can carry with you easily:
examples: our latest stylish ultra-mobile notebook

meanings.definition: a small book containing sheets of paper, for writing in:
examples: a journalist's notebook
She kept a record in a little notebook of what was said at meetings with her boss.

meanings.definition: known by many people, especially because of particular qualities:
examples: Summerhill school was noted for its progressive policies.
She's not noted for her patience (= she is not a patient person).

meanings.definition: a person, bank, or organization that has lent money, for example in the form of a mortgage or bonds:
examples: The company could be placed in administration if the noteholders did not agree to the plan.
Some noteholders have discovered that the mortgagor is not even living there and is renting the home out to a friend or family member.

meanings.definition: a small folded sheet of paper or card, usually with a picture on the front, inside which you write a short letter:
examples: a box of notelets

meanings.definition: a set of sheets of plain or lined paper, joined at the top edge, for writing on:
examples: He took out a notepad and pretended to write.
a plain/ruled notepad
a reporter's notepad

meanings.definition: a computer program used for making notes:
examples: I always copy what I say and paste it in a notepad before posting it.
There is a built-in notepad which lets you attach your own thoughts, ideas and memos to a specific map.

meanings.definition: a type of very small computer that you can carry easily. This type of computer is no longer commonly used. :
examples: She was repairing an Amstrad notepad computer from the 1990s.

meanings.definition: a set of sheets of paper joined at the top edge, for writing on:
examples: a plain/ruled notepad
a reporter's notepad

meanings.definition: a very small computer that you can carry easily
plain paper for writing letters on:
examples: three sheets/pieces of notepaper
headed notepaper

meanings.definition: information written on paper:
examples: The wind blew my notes all over the room.
The reporter took notes throughout the interview.
I made a few notes in the meeting.
I found a folder full of handwritten notes between my grandparents.
He'd added one or two explanatory notes.
She kept referring to her notes as she spoke.

meanings.definition: in a way that deserves attention because of being important or interesting:
examples: Noteworthily, there was no apparent reduction in the drug's efficacy after 6 months.
He was a noteworthily honest man in a business that is usually associated with criminals.

meanings.definition: deserving attention because of being important or interesting:
examples: a noteworthy example/event
It is noteworthy that one third of students do not pay any tuition fees.
King Darius I was noteworthy for his administrative reforms, military conquests, and religious toleration.

meanings.definition: deserving attention because of being important or interesting:
examples: Two noteworthy films open this week.

meanings.definition: not anything:
examples: There's nothing in the drawer - I took everything out.
Nothing I could say would cheer her up.
I have nothing new to tell you.
There's nothing else (= no other thing) we can do to help.
There's nothing much (= not very much) to do in our town.
The story was nothing but (= only) lies.
The score is Yankees three, Red Sox nothing (= no points).

meanings.definition: in no way:
examples: He had two letters of refusal but, nothing daunted (= not discouraged), he tried again.

meanings.definition: someone of no value or importance:
examples: He's a nothing, a low-down, useless nobody.

meanings.definition: not anything:
examples: There’s nothing in the drawer – I took everything out.
Money means nothing to him (= is not important).
The score is Yankees three, Red Sox nothing (= no points).
The story was nothing but (= only) lies.

meanings.definition: People say something is nothing as a polite answer when they are thanked:
examples: “Thanks for the tickets.” “Oh, it’s nothing.”

meanings.definition: only; no more than:
examples: This car has been nothing but trouble - it's always breaking down!
His story was dismissed by all who heard it as nothing but a pack of lies.

nothing-could-be-further-from-the-truth.name: nothing could be further from the truth

meanings.definition: used to say that what has been suggested is completely untrue:
examples: People say we're splitting up, but nothing could be further from the truth.

meanings.definition: what has been suggested is completely untrue:
examples: I’m certainly not in love with him – nothing could be further from the truth!

nothing-could-have-been-further-from-my-.name: nothing could have been further from my mind/thoughts

meanings.definition: used to say that you certainly did not intend something:
examples: I certainly wasn't trying to get money from him - nothing could have been further from my mind!

meanings.definition: still confident and enthusiastic despite a failure or problem:
examples: She was rejected the first time she applied to the university, but, nothing daunted, reapplied the following year and was accepted.

meanings.definition: used to mean "no", especially when said in answer to a request:
examples: We asked if she'd come over and help us, but she said, "Nothing doing".

meanings.definition: only a particular quality in something, and not worse: Nothing less than something is also used to show something is very important or serious:
examples: The chef will accept nothing less than perfection from his kitchen staff.
The president proposed nothing less than a complete overhaul of the tax system.

meanings.definition: not at all similar to someone or something:
examples: Instant coffee is nothing like the real thing.
He looks nothing like his brother.

meanings.definition: not nearly as good as:
examples: Instant coffee is OK, but it’s nothing like the real thing.

meanings.definition: only:
examples: He dismissed Bryan as nothing more than an amateur.

meanings.definition: very little:
examples: "What’s up?" "Nothing much."
I had nothing much to do that day.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize a negative statement:
examples: I told him nothing of the kind (= I did not tell him anything like that).

meanings.definition: no clothes on your body:
examples: She sleeps with nothing on.
I couldn't come to the door - I had nothing on!
I never walk around the house with nothing on.
I had nothing on except my pants so I couldn't come out of the bathroom.
He'd quite happily do the gardening with nothing on if he knew no one could see him.

meanings.definition: no arrangements for a stated period:
examples: I checked my calendar and I have nothing on on Tuesday afternoon.
There's nothing on next Friday - we could have the meeting then.
We've got nothing on tonight - do you want to pop by for a drink?
Make sure you schedule the appointment for when you've got nothing else on.

meanings.definition: neither very good nor very bad:
examples: Dinner was nothing special.

meanings.definition: something that deserves serious attention, esp. an amount of money:
examples: An extra two thousand bucks a year is nothing to sneeze at.

meanings.definition: not exciting or special:
examples: Their performance was nothing to write home about.

meanings.definition: You have to take a risk in order to get something good.
a state where nothing is present, or where nothing exists that is important or gives meaning to life
a state or place where nothing is present, or where nothing important is present
to see or become conscious of something or someone:
examples: I noticed a crack in the ceiling.
Mary waved at the man but he didn't seem to notice.
He noticed (that) the woman was staring at him.
Did you notice how she did that?

meanings.definition: to bring someone to the attention of the public, usually because of an unusual skill, etc.:
examples: She was first noticed by the critics at the age of twelve, and went on to become a world-famous violinist.

meanings.definition: (a board, piece of paper, etc. containing) information or instructions:
examples: There was a large notice on the wall saying "No Parking".
I saw a notice in the paper announcing their marriage.

meanings.definition: information or a warning given about something that is going to happen in the future:
examples: The next time you visit, can you give me more notice?
The first responders are ready to spring into action at a moment's notice.
The building is closed until further notice (= until another official announcement is made).

meanings.definition: the period of time that you must work after you have said that you are leaving your job, or after you have been asked to leave:
examples: Do I have to work out my notice?

meanings.definition: attention:
examples: It has come to/been brought to my notice (= I have been told) that you have been late for work every day this week.

meanings.definition: to become aware of, esp. by looking; to see:
examples: Mary waved but he didn’t seem to notice.
He noticed that she was staring at him.

meanings.definition: something written or printed that gives information or instructions:
examples: We got a notice about recycling in the mail.
This building is closed until further notice (= until official instructions are given).

meanings.definition: Notice is also warning that something will happen or needs to happen:
examples: I can’t cancel my plans on such short notice/at a moment’s notice (= immediately).

meanings.definition: Notice is also an official statement saying you are leaving your job or telling you your job has ended:
examples: I got my 30-day notice yesterday at work.

meanings.definition: attention:
examples: Twain first attracted notice as a humorist.

meanings.definition: a piece of written information on paper, a board, a website, etc.:
examples: There was a notice about the proposed reorganization on all the office noticeboards.

meanings.definition: information or a warning about something that is going to happen in the future, or the period of time before it happens:
examples: An inspection can take place at any time without notice.
We hereby give notice that we have been appointed official receivers for the assets of the above-named company.
You will need to give a month's notice if you want to withdraw any of the cash.
These offices will remain closed until further notice.

meanings.definition: a letter or a statement saying that an employee will or must leave their job after a particular period of time:
examples: The situation at work was so bad that I decided to hand in my notice.
Many of the junior staff were given notice to leave.

meanings.definition: the period of time that an employee works in their job after they have said that they are leaving, or after they have been asked to leave:
examples: In this type of job you usually only have a week's notice.
They paid me for the two weeks instead of making me work out my notice.

meanings.definition: a formal document or statement that tells someone to do something, or gives them information about something:
examples: The tenants refused to leave and have now been served with notices of eviction by the landlord.
All the redundancy notices have now gone out to the members of staff affected.

meanings.definition: a savings account that does not allow you to take out money without telling the bank first, a particular amount of time before you want the money:
examples: The bank has a 60-day notice account offering 4% interest.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         deficiency notice  :
examples: It is not unusual for problems relating to a notice of deficiency to be resolved without fully litigating the issue in the Tax Court.

meanings.definition: the period between the time that you are told about something and the time that it must happen or be done:
examples: The senator's bill lengthens the notice period before a layoff to 90 days.
Legal eviction proceedings cannot begin until after the 60-day legal notice period is over.

meanings.definition: the period of time that an employee must work in their job after they have said that they are leaving, or after they have been asked to leave:
examples: a notice period of two months

meanings.definition: easy to see or recognize:
examples: There has been a noticeable improvement in Tim's cooking.

meanings.definition: easy to see or recognize:
examples: There’s a noticeable improvement in your grades.

meanings.definition: in a way that is easy to see or recognize:
examples: Ellen had become noticeably thinner.

meanings.definition: a board on a wall on which notices can be fixed:
examples: I've put the list of players up on the noticeboard.

meanings.definition: a board on a wall on which pieces of paper containing written information can be fixed:
examples: The reception desk at their headquarters is dominated by a large noticeboard giving the company's daily share price.

meanings.definition: an area on a website where messages containing information for other users can be left:
examples: online noticeboards

meanings.definition: a belief or idea:
examples: The show's director rejects the notion that seeing violence on television has a harmful effect on children.
I have only a vague notion of what she does for a living.

meanings.definition: a belief or idea:
examples: Nast helped form the American notion of Santa Claus.

meanings.definition: existing only as an idea, not as something real:
examples: Almost everyone will have to pay a higher tax bill than the notional amount suggested by the Treasury Secretary.

meanings.definition: existing only as an idea, or as an approximate amount:
examples: Diamonds only retain their notional value through strict control of the market.
Almost everyone will have to pay a higher tax bill than the notional amount suggested by the government.
They are converting debt into enough shares at a notional 8.6p each to give them 60% of the equity.

meanings.definition: in a way that exists only as an idea, not as something real:
examples: He is only notionally responsible for the project; in reality the technical director takes all the decisions.
The new tax rate is notionally eight percent, but in practice very few people will pay that.
The husband was, notionally, the head of the family; but really the wife made most of the family and household decisions.

meanings.definition: cloth, pins, thread, etc. used for sewing, or a shop or a department of a large store that sells these:
examples: There's a fabric store there that sells notions.
They sell fabric but as far as I know, they don't sell notions.
You can buy notions for patchwork and quilting.
They carry a good range of dressmaking notions.
I was looking online for some sewing notions.
You'll find zippers over in Notions.

meanings.definition: a long, narrow structure of cells in the embryos (= animals that are developing in their mother's body) of humans and some animals that develops into the spine (= the line of bones down the centre of the back that provides support for the body):
examples: The notochord usually disappears before birth, though a few cells may remain embedded in the bones of the spine.
The notochord is a temporary structure and forms a central axis, around which the segments of the vertebral column are developed.

meanings.definition: a long, narrow structure that can bend that is found in the body of some animals:
examples: The swim bladder was located below the notochord and above the digestive tract.

meanings.definition: relating to the notochord (= a structure in humans and some animals before they are born that develops into the spine):
examples: In an embryo, the notochord is a rod of cells surrounded by a thin notochordal sheath.
In humans, notochordal cells in the intervertebral discs become increasingly sparse after birth and disappear altogether by adolescence.

meanings.definition: the state of being famous for something bad:
examples: He achieved/gained notoriety for being difficult to work with as an actor.

meanings.definition: the state of being famous for doing something, esp. something immoral or bad:
examples: The public is unhappy about the notoriety of the mayor.

meanings.definition: famous for something bad:
examples: one of Mexico's most notorious criminals
The company is notorious for paying its bills late.

meanings.definition: famous for something immoral or bad:
